headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Marathon Oil Corporation 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Katie, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I'll now turn the call over
componenttext:
Welcome to the Marathon Oil Corporation 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Katie, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. 
I'll now turn the call over to Chris Phillips. Mr. Phillips, please go ahead.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katie. Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil Corporation's fourth quarter and full 2015 earnings and 2016 capital program conference call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations. Also joining me on the call this morning are Lee
componenttext:
Thank you, Katie. Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil Corporation's fourth quarter and full 2015 earnings and 2016 capital program conference call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations. Also joining me on the call this morning are Lee Tillman, President and CEO; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Mitch Little, Vice President, Conventional; Lance Robertson, Vice President, Resource Plays; and Zach Dailey, Director of Investor Relations.
As has become our custom, we released prepared remarks last night in connection with the earnings release. You can find those remarks on the associated slides on our website at marathonoil.com. We will begin this morning with additional prepared remarks discussing our 2016 capital program. We issued a separate press release detailing our 2016 capital program last evening. We posted a second slide presentation earlier today for the company's this morning's prepared remarks that can also be found on our website.
After our remarks, the remainder of the call will be available for Q&A. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. 
Slide 2 contains a discussion of forward-looking statements and other information included in this presentation. Our review will contain forward-looking statements subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements.
We have identified in our latest annual report on Form 10-K and other filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission a number of important factors that could cause future outcomes to differ materially from those set forth in those forward-looking statements.
Please refer to the quarterly investor packet on our website for reconciliations of the non-GAAP financial measures discussed in this presentation to their most recently comparable GAAP financial measures.
With that, I will turn the presentation over to Lee, who will begin on Slide 3.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris. I'd like to extend my welcome to those listening. Last night, we announced a reduced capital program for 2016 that reflects the current challenging environment and our clear objective of balance sheet protection. Our $1.4 billion program in
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris. I'd like to extend my welcome to those listening. Last night, we announced a reduced capital program for 2016 that reflects the current challenging environment and our clear objective of balance sheet protection. Our $1.4 billion program in 2016 is over 50% lower than last year's program and 75% lower than 2014.
As the chart illustrates, we have responded as oil prices have fallen dramatically, and are doing the same in 2016 with our capital program calibrated to a view of WTI in the upper 30s and assume success in our noncore asset sales program.
Our business planning and budgeting are not static but rather, decisions are being made in realtime, in large part facilitated by the optionality afforded by our short cycle investments. We have designed our 2016 programs to maximize capital allocation to the short cycle investments in our U.S. resource plays, complete long cycle projects that contribute production and minimize allocation to conventional exploration. Guided by these principles of the foundation of our plan, production volumes were, by design and outcome, not an objective, and we are forecasting a total company production decline of 6% to 8% year-over-year adjusted for divestitures.
This program provides us the optionality to further adjust our short cycle investments if needed based on commodity prices and the outcome of our noncore asset sales.
Last year, we achieved over $300 million of noncore asset sales toward our original goal of at least $500 million. When we set that original target, we were transparent that the noncore assets under consideration far exceeded $500 million. Based on the transactions announced today as well as progress on the remaining assets, we've increased our target to a range of $750 million to $1 billion. This year's capital allocation is designed to position the company for a sustained period of low commodity prices while maintaining the capability to be flexible in a dynamic environment.
Slide 4 illustrates the allocation of our 2016 program in a bit more detail. As I mentioned, the majority of our 2016 program, about 70% will be directed to the Eagle Ford, SCOOP STACK and Bakken. For each of our 3 core resource plays, we have set a specific objectives for our 2016 investment. Namely, maintaining the efficiencies our Eagle Ford team has worked so hard to capture, protecting our leasehold in the STACK while continuing to improve our understanding of the Oklahoma Resource Basin and focusing on our base business in the Bakken with operated D&C greatly reduce. All of this, of course, while continuing to focus on sustainable cost reduction that will be maintained through the commodity cycle. Across the remainder of the portfolio, we will be completing several long cycle projects in 2016. Most notably, our operated compression project in EG. This project will extend plateau production from the Alba Field by an additional 2 years and allow us to develop in excess of $130 million netball equivalent barrels of proven reserves.
In addition to the EG compression project, we expect first oil this year from investments in 2 outside operated projects, Gunflint in the Gulf of Mexico and Atrush in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq. We're forecasting about $40 million of sustaining CapEx toward our nonoperated working interest in the oil sands this year. We, along with the operator and other JV partner, are intensely focused on building upon the structural cost improvements and better uptime reliability achieved in 2015.
Finally, we've significantly reduced our conventional exploration CapEx this year to $30 million, down about 90% from last year, following the strategic decision we made last fall to scale back in this space. This year spend is largely limited to existing commitments in the Gulf of Mexico and Gabon, with no new exploration wells planned in 2016.
As we enter another year with reduced capital investment, we again look to our short cycle U.S. resource plays to continue providing the operational flexibility to adapt to changing market conditions.
With that, I'll turn it over to Lance to review the resource plays in a bit more detail.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lee. I'll continue with the broad overview of the 2016 program for U.S. resource plays on Slide 5. Consistent with our focus on prioritizing the balance sheet this year, our allocation to the resource plays is anticipated at $1 billion, down about
componenttext:
Thanks, Lee. I'll continue with the broad overview of the 2016 program for U.S. resource plays on Slide 5. Consistent with our focus on prioritizing the balance sheet this year, our allocation to the resource plays is anticipated at $1 billion, down about 50% from 2015. As Lee said, the short cycle nature of these assets allows us to be flexible in a volatile commodity market. If needed, we have the option to reduce spending down further with substantially all of our acreage held by production in the Bakken, the Eagle Ford and in the SCOOP Woodford. We also have relatively few leases with continuing pulling obligations and no long-term rig commitments in these plays.
The pie charts on the slide depict our operated drilling and completions, our nonoperated drilling and completions and other spend across each basin. Through the budget planning process, our intent was to maximize the allocation to drilling and completions opportunities. The nonoperated drilling and completions component of the budget is our current best estimate of the spend based on recent engagement with partners. In the current commodity environment, we are closely scrutinizing each project proposal for costs and returns. When prudent, we will not consent discretionary projects that do not deliver adequate returns. Given the continuing decline in industry rig counts across our 3 basins, the expected bias in the non-operated estimates is lower. For reference, the other spend category broadly consist of diverse nondiscretionary items for direct support and development activity such as centralized facilities expansions, data gathering and other items not directly included in drilling and completions costs but essential parts of an operation.
Turning to the Eagle Ford, we are down to 7 rigs, and we'll be scaling down further to 5 rigs near the end of the first quarter. Additionally, we will be racing to a single Phrack crew for much of the year that will match drilling activity. Consistent with our past practices, we plan to maintain sufficient inventory to keep the completion crew operationally efficient. This activity level retains our execution capability and core competencies, allowing us to continue codeveloping the highest value, Austin Chalk, Upper and Lower Eagle Ford Horizons across our core acreage position. A continued focus on enhancing well productivity through stimulation design and technology application has recently yielded encouraging early results in our high GOR oil areas. As this activity matures, we anticipate sharing more details throughout the year. 
In the Oklahoma resource basins, our capital spend will focus on retaining term leases in the core of the STACK Meramec as we continue to delineate the rich condensate window and optimize stimulation designs. While maintaining leases will be our primary objective across Oklahoma this year, based on the success of our first operated Springer oil well in the fourth quarter in the SCOOP, we will also continue to progress limited Springer activity to delineate the down dip aerial extent of this play.
In the Bakken, we are focused on the base business where we will complete our ongoing water gathering system later this year to further reduce our largest single expense, water handling. Based on the current commodity price environment, we recently released our last operated rig in the Bakken, and plan to have intermittent development activity later in the year, primarily to address continuing drilling obligations. With this reduced level of activity and at recent reprising, we anticipate Bakken achieves cash flow neutrality and 2016.
The $75 million earmarked for outside operated activity in Bakken is our current best estimate of AFEs we expect to receive from partners this year, and each will be scrutinized closely given the current low commodity environment.
Despite reduced resource play activity, we continue to balance our current actions with the need to be responsive when more constructive pricing occurs.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Mitch to review capital activities outside the resource plays.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lance. Referring to Slide 6, I'll provide a brief overview of 2016 activities across our remaining portfolio, where we continue to moderate capital spend, while delivering profitable long cycle projects during the year. Starting with our OSM
componenttext:
Thank you, Lance. Referring to Slide 6, I'll provide a brief overview of 2016 activities across our remaining portfolio, where we continue to moderate capital spend, while delivering profitable long cycle projects during the year. 
Starting with our OSM segment, we've achieved a step-change reduction in sustaining capital levels and our 2016 CapEx at about $40 million as well below historical averages. Along with the operator and our JV partner, our focus remains on maintaining the improved reliability, while lowering operating and sustaining capital costs to reposition the business for profitable operation within the current environment. Despite challenging pricing in the third and fourth quarters last year, OSM was cash flow positive, thanks to offering cost that averaged less than $30 per barrel of synthetic crude oil for the 2 consecutive quarters. But the more consistent operations, our 3 highest net production quarters in the history of the operation occurred last year, leading to 2015 annual production volumes net of royalty at an all-time high while unplanned downtime with an all-time low.
Outside of OSM, we expect to complete 3 long cycle projects in 2016, bringing incremental cash flow is starting in the second half of the year. Beginning with our operated business in EG, we completed a successful and incident free installation campaign of the combined 10,000 tons jacket and topsides for the album v3 Compression Project in mid-January. The project remains on budget and on schedule. Following hookup and commissioning activities, we expect a midyear startup of the new facility. The installation will have 72,000-horsepower of compression and associated processing equipment facilities, which allow us to significantly extend Alba Field life to beyond 2030 with minimal future capital requirements.
In the Gulf of Mexico, we expect startup of the outside operated Gunflint, 2 well subsea development also by midyear.
Finally, in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq, developments are progressing within the Atrush and Sarsang outside operated blocks. 
In the Atrush block, installations of the Phase I 30,000-barrel per day facility is progressing with first oil expected later this year. 4 existing wells will feed the facility and future development decisions will be evaluated following the assessment from well and reservoir performance.
In late 2015, a second well and wellsite production facility were brought online in the Sarsang block. 2016 activity is focused on bringing additional wells online to utilize existing facility capacity while further expansion will be evaluated in light of the current macro environment.
Across the portfolio, we continue to focus on cost management and delivering high operational availability in an effort to defend margins within the challenging commodity price environment.
With that brief summary, I'll pass it back to Lee.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Well, thank you, Mitch. Capital discipline and balance sheet protection have driven the decision supporting our reduced 2016 capital program and slide 7 provides our production guidance. As I mentioned earlier, we're forecasting total company p
componenttext:
All right. Well, thank you, Mitch. Capital discipline and balance sheet protection have driven the decision supporting our reduced 2016 capital program and slide 7 provides our production guidance. As I mentioned earlier, we're forecasting total company production in 2016 to decline 6% to 8% from 2015, adjusted for our divestitures in the Gulf of Mexico and East Texas, North Louisiana.
For the first quarter 2016, our total E&P guidance includes 2 extraordinary downtime events. First, we expect downtime in EG of approximately 20,000 net BOE per day associated with the installation of the jacket and topsides for the ALBA compression project as well as planned maintenance. Installation was completed in January and the ALBA field and on sure plants returned to a full production earlier this month.
Second, late December, the Brae off insulation experienced a pipe failure and first quarter totally E&P production guidance includes the impact of the approximately 7,000 net BOE per day of U.K. production that remains shut-in while repairs are underway. Resumption of full production is expected in the second quarter.
Wrapping up on slide 8. We anticipate 2016 will require a similar level of flexibility to adapt to the uncertain macro environment as is last year. In 2015, we lowered production in G&A expenses over $435 million, we reduced our workforce by over 20%, which will generate about $160 million of annualized net savings and we decreased our quarterly dividend as women increasing annual free cash flow on more than $425 million. We've became even more efficient operators in each of our basins, decreasing completed well costs everywhere through a combination of commercial savings and execution of efficiency.
2016 where a request same level of focus and discipline, and our $1.4 billion capital program is designed with balance sheet protection as our top priority. The plan continues to direct the lion's share of capital to our short cycle resource plays, which provide the most flexibility. The remainder of the portfolio includes completely long cycle projects that contribute production volumes to the company as well as keeping committed capital obligations to a minimal level.
We will continue lowering our cost structure, enhancing operational productivity and progressing toward our newly revised noncore asset sales target of $750 million to $1 billion.
Finally, our $4.2 billion in liquidity at year-end, which includes $1.2 billion in cash in end undrawn $3 billion revolving credit facility, positions us well for the reality of sustained low commodity prices.
That concludes our remarks, and I will now hand back to Chris.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We, I'm afraid the topic this year is obviously balance sheet strength, credit metrics and obviously the credit agencies' somewhat onerous prices on target. What additional steps are you prepared to take to basically get market from balance sheet can be m
componenttext: We, I'm afraid the topic this year is obviously balance sheet strength, credit metrics and obviously the credit agencies' somewhat onerous prices on target. What additional steps are you prepared to take to basically get market from balance sheet can be managed this downturn underprepared to allow your credit rating to slide to some investment-grade? And I've got a follow-up.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me kind of take the first part and then maybe let J.R. jump in a little bit on just our view from a credit metrics standpoint in the ratings agencies. But our plan, Doug, as we stated in our opening remarks, was really designed with the view of
componenttext: Okay. Let me kind of take the first part and then maybe let J.R. jump in a little bit on just our view from a credit metrics standpoint in the ratings agencies. But our plan, Doug, as we stated in our opening remarks, was really designed with the view of kind of a high $30 WTI, and assumes success in our noncore asset sales target. But we still have implicit, quite a bit of flexibility within our capital program to really adjust further as we see changes in price changes in the macro as well as we see the outcome from our noncore asset sales. I think we demonstrated last year our certainly, our willingness to use every label lever available to us to ensure that we do in fact protect the balance sheet. I think there are a few of those in my opening remarks, but the adjustment to the dividend, I think even the reduction in our capital budget last year of about $500 million, the strong steps that we took earlier in the cycle in both production expenses and G&A costs, including a basically a 700 reduction in our workforce, all of these, I think, are demonstrative of the action that we are prepared to take to ensure that we are putting balance sheet protection first and foremost. Maybe with respect to the credit agencies and the credit metrics. Perhaps I'll just let J.R. chime in on those.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, as you've indicated, clearly, we have had actions already taken by 2 of the 3 rating agencies today. And those 2 have taken action. We remain investment-grade. Clearly, there's one is still remaining outstanding. You're right, and that they have tak
componenttext: Doug, as you've indicated, clearly, we have had actions already taken by 2 of the 3 rating agencies today. And those 2 have taken action. We remain investment-grade. Clearly, there's one is still remaining outstanding. You're right, and that they have taken arguably significantly different view with regard to the commodity price outlook and seemed to be fundamentally approaching the industry different than historically and candidly the outcome is uncertain. But what I would tell you is that Lee indicated, we're going to continue to make the decisions that are in the best interest of all the stakeholders to support the balance sheet and the outcome with regard to the agencies will be the outcome. But we're going to continue to make sure that we've got sufficient liquidity and appropriate balance sheet so that we can continue to be successful in terms of developing the resources that we have at this company.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, I think as we have said, there's no doubt in the current environment that the balance sheet is our top priority. We have to maintain as much financial and operational flexibility as we can to adjust to these very dynamic market conditions. We're con
componenttext: Doug, I think as we have said, there's no doubt in the current environment that the balance sheet is our top priority. We have to maintain as much financial and operational flexibility as we can to adjust to these very dynamic market conditions. We're constantly reassessing in realtime and capital budget from our noncore asset sales, our overall balance sheet strength as well as our liquidity and I think although our business plan assumes the successful execution of our noncore assets program to really contribute to our goal of free cash flow neutrality, we have to continue to keep all options on the table and available to us to give us that financial flexibility going forward. So again, you should expect us to continue to consider and access all of the levers available to us going forward.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next version comes from Edward Westlake from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next version comes from Edward Westlake from Credit Suisse.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the divestiture program. Maybe just give us some ideas as to why you can think you can be confident to hit that $750 million to $1 billion total program.
componenttext: Just on the divestiture program. Maybe just give us some ideas as to why you can think you can be confident to hit that $750 million to $1 billion total program.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. First, maybe, I'll just acknowledge that the market, no doubt, has softened since we embarked on our noncore asset program. There's no question that the sales market is much more challenging than it was even last year. But I'll go back and say
componenttext: Absolutely. First, maybe, I'll just acknowledge that the market, no doubt, has softened since we embarked on our noncore asset program. There's no question that the sales market is much more challenging than it was even last year. But I'll go back and say, as a reminder, when we initially said our noncore asset target last year, we stated that we had identified a pretty broad pool of noncore assets that were well in excess of that original $500 million. And what I'll say is, based on our progress to date, the transactions that we've been able to complete and the quality as well as the diversity of the identified noncore assets that we still have in the hopper, we're comfortable increasing that target to that $750 million to $1 billion. The way I would kind of describe the asset add is that they're primarily U.S. upstream and midstream. They are both operated and nonoperated, but the list is very diverse and we are very satisfied taking some singles and doubles. Some will be bigger, but there's quite a few that will be smaller. And thus far, the market has shown an ability to digest some of those smaller transactions quite readily. Timing for us, we would expect to progress toward our revised target, really through the balance of 2016.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a follow-up would be around 2017, getting a little depressing about recession risks, they are clearly rising, we'll see if 1 actually occurs. But you'll end up with say $1.2 billion or maybe whatever that number is at the end of the year, dependi
componenttext: And then a follow-up would be around 2017, getting a little depressing about recession risks, they are clearly rising, we'll see if 1 actually occurs. But you'll end up with say $1.2 billion or maybe whatever that number is at the end of the year, depending on the asset sales program and the reduction capital. But again, if you were looking into 2017, it would still feel if there was a recession that you'd need to do some shoring up of the balance sheet for that year, so what will be next in terms of the order if we had 2 years of low prices?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Of course, we're trying to, of course, manage through '16 now. But as we have looked ahead to 2017, there's no question, Ed, that the majority of our capital will still be directed to the short cycle investments. And as such, that still gives us a gr
componenttext: Yes. Of course, we're trying to, of course, manage through '16 now. But as we have looked ahead to 2017, there's no question, Ed, that the majority of our capital will still be directed to the short cycle investments. And as such, that still gives us a great deal of flexibility within our capital program and our capital spend. That activity though is going to largely depend upon where commodity prices are. And just to maybe level set a little bit, at the kind of current contango in the strip, that would equate to us to about $500 million of incremental free cash flow in 2017. And then at that point, as incremental cash flow might be realized, it would be capital allocation decision based on the highest and best use as to whether that goes to balance sheet strengthening or and/or into organic investment. I don't see those 2 as necessarily being mutually exclusive. The other thing that I would add to is that although we do have some long cycle projects that Mitch addressed rolling off in 2016, we do have a little bit of an offset. And that we do have a remaining Deepwater GOM commitment, recommitment that will come back to us in 2017. So largely those 2 somewhat balance off of 1 another.

componenttext: And our next question comes from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

componenttext: Just a follow-up on current and balance sheet, does your topic -- I understand you're protecting the balance sheet and it moves today, but how committed are you to investment-grade rating? And based upon those products conversations, I mean, the expected able to maintain it from -- I know you talked about Moody's, but from the other 2 agencies? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan, we have maintained the other 2 agencies. They've just recently published earlier this month. And so those have come out with investment-grade ratings. They were a notch lower than where they were, but we have maintained it there. As for the out
componenttext: Yes, Evan, we have maintained the other 2 agencies. They've just recently published earlier this month. And so those have come out with investment-grade ratings. They were a notch lower than where they were, but we have maintained it there. As for the outstanding rating evaluation, honestly, Evan, I don't know what they're going to define as what it means to be an investment-grade anymore. Remember what it used to be throughout most of my career. And based on my historical understanding, I would say we still meet the metrics that they used to lay out there. But honestly, those are changing. And so I just -- anyone to predict what they will ultimately do. But at the end of the day, I'm still investment-grade, I'm still going to be part of the IG indices from a bond trading standpoint. There really isn't any significant impact on us if that 1 rating agency were to not rate us investment grade. I mean, clearly, there's going to be cost issue and in periods that are highly volatile and access issue, but all of that is completely manageable.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: And then how do you weigh that? I mean, how do you weigh the impact of an even deeper CapEx cut or dilutive equity raise against a loss of that status? I mean, this just seems to be a primary debate amongst many of your peers.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, I don't think that ultimately you can necessarily solve for just 1 equation here. I got to make decisions on the best interest of all of the stakeholders, and we're going to continue to do that. But as I said before, the way we've got the capital s
componenttext: Again, I don't think that ultimately you can necessarily solve for just 1 equation here. I got to make decisions on the best interest of all of the stakeholders, and we're going to continue to do that. But as I said before, the way we've got the capital structure set up, the depth of our liquidity that exists, that I'm very comfortable that whether we ultimately have an investment-grade rating from the remaining agency or not is not going to impact our ability to remain stronger in this commodity price cycle.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to stay on the usual suspect topic here. I think what we're probably trying to get at here is, what -- how do you define success from a balance sheet perspective? What are you trying -- where are you trying to take the company here? What is the ke
componenttext: So just to stay on the usual suspect topic here. I think what we're probably trying to get at here is, what -- how do you define success from a balance sheet perspective? What are you trying -- where are you trying to take the company here? What is the key metric you're trying to use that is driving your decision? It sounds like it's not necessarily, but hopefully, investment-grade? Is it leverage? Is it liquidity for a couple of years, that $30 oil? Can you just kind of talk to how you would define success from a balance sheet perspective?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, Brian, I mean, honestly the way we're thinking about it is really just to focus on managing the balance sheet throughout the full cycle. So historically, I've always tried to focus on liquidity when you're at the bottom of the cycle. And again, h
componenttext: Yes. No, Brian, I mean, honestly the way we're thinking about it is really just to focus on managing the balance sheet throughout the full cycle. So historically, I've always tried to focus on liquidity when you're at the bottom of the cycle. And again, historically, that was the way it was measured. It's whether or not you have enough liquidity to get you through the bottom of the cycle. As Lee indicated in his remarks, our goal here in 2016 is free cash flow neutrality. So to be able to manage the outspend with the success in the noncore asset sale program and not add debt to the balance sheet. And as I indicated, we're going to maintain ample liquidity to support the business. And in addition, I want to make sure, in not only liquidity but the cash component of that liquidity to maintain the option associated with just delevering the balance sheet in late '17 when we have a relatively modest amount of debt that becomes due, about $700 million. So clearly, I think we've said multiple times, the noncore asset sale program and the flexibility of the capital program are really going to be the key levers on that. But one thing I do want to go to on this issue of leverage metrics and what really highlight what Lee said before, just the embedded oil price leverage and the impact the cash flows, and candidly the leverage metrics is significant. And we just set them if just assuming the forward contango that exists today, so whatever that is from a current standpoint, probably about $7, sometime around there, it's about $500 million of free cash flow and a significant step change in what you're leverage would be on a net debt-to-EBITDA standpoint. So we're focus on managing through the cycle and again, I as indicated to Evan, really destroyed to make the decisions are in the best interest of the business.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: My follow-up is perhaps the surprise operational resource question. You acquired some additional acreage in SCOOP and STACK here over the last year. And I wondered if you could tell us a little bit more, a, what that does to make your position more contig
componenttext: My follow-up is perhaps the surprise operational resource question. You acquired some additional acreage in SCOOP and STACK here over the last year. And I wondered if you could tell us a little bit more, a, what that does to make your position more contiguous? And then, how you would think about and at what price you would allocate more capital and where you would go first within your key onshore shell place?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. This is Lance. I think you should think about those acres that we're constantly looking particularly in Oklahoma, which is in a cycle in the play relative to others to vote as you describe, core op that position and secure resources. We were
componenttext: Sure, Brian. This is Lance. I think you should think about those acres that we're constantly looking particularly in Oklahoma, which is in a cycle in the play relative to others to vote as you describe, core op that position and secure resources. We were very successful over the last year primarily, organically, through a small local auction processes in the BIA and the CLO and other organization as well as just doing small leasing opportunities with peers and accumulated 14,000 acres in Oklahoma, the overwhelming majority of that is in the STACK play focused in the core, primarily Blaine County. What we found over the balance of that year is that the core of the Meramec has shifted in the western direction, which is where most of that acreage was acquired and we managed to secure all that for about $3,000 an acre, which is very competitive. Referencing where we would go in terms of activity and allocate the capital, I think we're always going to take that broadly within our overall capital allocation process. We certainly want to be able to continue to delineate Oklahoma because we have more to learn there perhaps than other basins. I think we're going to have to wait and see how the commodity market really evolves before we can make those capital allocations beyond 2016.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

So we're going to measure all of those capital allocation decisions and determine which ones make the best sense for the enterprise. Clearly, you got to do that, you got to do that thoughtfully. That's a great example in response to some of the earlier questions where that might be in the best interest of the company, rating agencies may view that transaction differently in terms of the way an investment grade company should manage their business with the fundamental premise is that your shareholders will be paid off at far. Again, we're going to make those decisions in the best interest to all stakeholders and it will be something that we would consider.

componenttext: Okay, thanks. And then my follow-up is the 2017 maturity. It's later in 2017, so you've got some time. headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Yes. As I indicated probably you missed it, Harry, earlier, I really want to be in a position to have the flexibility and the optionality just to pay that down, pay it off, in other words. Clearly, I've got the liquidity to where I could bridgette on my facility, but I really want to be in a position if the market is what it is today, as the forward curve nearly slides into 2017 to be able to pay that off.

componenttext: So just thinking about the Eagle Ford program. You've basically been running kind of flat in net wells the last couple of quarters. Can you just talk about the pacing of net wells in 2016 as you dropped to 5 rigs? And kind of the -- particularly given the shape of the commodity curve, do you get slower earlier and then pickup? How do you think through as kind of the bad basin and really just the other basins as well?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, David, this is Lance. I think perhaps as we articulated in the capital and the remarks this morning that we're prepared that we're already moving into the activity reductions in Eagle Ford. We actually released our first rig recently this month down
componenttext: Sure, David, this is Lance. I think perhaps as we articulated in the capital and the remarks this morning that we're prepared that we're already moving into the activity reductions in Eagle Ford. We actually released our first rig recently this month down at the end of this quarter, we'll be down to 5 rigs and then we're going to stay at that flat activity level moving forward. I think as a desire as we look at the balance sheet prioritization overall, we want to take those decisions early in the year and we have. And so you'll see us go down that level and then maintain that activity level moving forward. And from quarter-to-quarter, you'll see those net 2 wells to sales moderate as we have diverse working interest across it, but it will be relatively level from that point forward. Similarly, we're going to continue to run effectively the 2 rigs we had all in 2015 through Oklahoma the managed lease of legations and continue to delineate and learn in the Springer, the things we need to. And then we've retread I think we mentioned earlier, we've actually released our Bakken activity talisman returns with that present so we're going to have limited activity for the rest of the year in the Bakken.

componenttext: Yes, David, this is Lee. As I say and you noted, this primarily U.S. assets that are local downstream. But if you look at the characteristics of what we already moved out of the portfolio, you can have a sense for just the diversity and even some of the scale of some of those actions that might occur in going forward. For instance, the East Texas Louisiana deal was on the order of 4,000 oil equivalent barrels per day. The GOM assets, were only order of about 10,000-ish barrels a day. So those are kind of the ballparks now. Those are some kind of the small to midsize assets we might talk about now. There could be some larger more material assets that do ultimately come into play and of course, the midstream assets, the advantage there is there really is no volumetric impact per se, but you have, of course, to absolutely concerned about making sure that you have the right operational transition there to ensure security of your barrels. So I don't know, but hopefully that helped a little bit.

componenttext: Yes. Without giving too much into the specifics, Roger, we certainly have a good idea of the pool of assets that we're prepared to put into the market. The uncertainty is just how -- which of those assets may impact in fact be transactable. And then each of those has a finite, I would say probability of occurrence. And it really comes down to connecting the assets to the correct buyers and the call for the diversity of these assets, they do appeal to a very, I would say broad and diverse range of buyers potentially as well. So we do -- that's one of the reasons why we kind of bracketed the range the way that we did. It's a little bit of the reflection of some of that uncertainty. And certainly not only just stands at, which transactions will move forward but also just the ultimate valuations that we're able to secure in those transactions as well.

componenttext: Sure, Roger. I think it's pretty clear that we've taken the activity down both in 2015 and 2016. They have to be declined in there. I think importantly, in the Eagle Ford, for example from Q3 to Q4, we held flat with effectively flat wells to sales, which indicates all the horizons we've been developing there are producing well and meet our expectations. And then I think you should think of the resource plays from annual '15 to annual '16 who's going to have an overall decline in the low teens.

componenttext: And John, so I think the Springer is pretty early in the SCOOP area. What we found are 2 different distinct areas where it's been tested today, it's sort of the northern core and the southern core. The newbie while we drilled and brought online last quarter was in that southern core area, where there's probably from the most data, we expected that to be well by us in that area I think we have a lot of confidence going in, the results so far more net out. The performance from that well has been very strong to begin with and it actually is similar to the underlying Woodford, elevated reservoir pressure, the accumulative 30, 60 day production tend to be relatively flat. That same connection behavior been born out in the spring of thus far. So it's actually very consistent with our expectations why we're excited about it. What we also see is the opportunity to delineate of this play down there from the core oil areas that we'll explore in our us look at today was average condensate window perhaps. So you'll see us continue to test that in a limited way, the Springer across 2016.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Great. Next one for me, J.R., you mentioned liquidity not being like the past. If you look at your overall liquidity relative to market value, in the past, when commodity parties were down, you would have a much lower percentage of overall liquidity relative to market cap, but seems like a lot of company's are getting penalized today for the straight question perhaps on the strategy or leverage or whatever. The ever recall a time when there was this much wealth of liquidity to market cap from equity gap?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great point, John. Obviously, there's been a shift and happened maybe toward the latter part of last year. I think it was a point in which liquidity was being rewarded in terms of equity valuations but then it quickly shifted to almost a singular
componenttext: That's a great point, John. Obviously, there's been a shift and happened maybe toward the latter part of last year. I think it was a point in which liquidity was being rewarded in terms of equity valuations but then it quickly shifted to almost a singular focus on leverage without regard to liquidity. And so I don't recall that when you've got a long history as well, John, in terms of that being the market behavior historically. Candidly, I'm very thankful for the early moves that we did with regard to showing up that liquidity, the early moves we did with regard to extending debt maturities and feel like we're well situated for both '16 and '17 on the liquidity front, but it is interesting that the anomalies that we're seeing in the new ones as compared to previous market corrections.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one from me. You mentioned that the current year CapEx is predicated on high 30s average. If, per chance, we were to see a recovery, let's say into the 50s towards the middle of the year, would you be inclined to upsize your activity level in the sec
componenttext: Just one from me. You mentioned that the current year CapEx is predicated on high 30s average. If, per chance, we were to see a recovery, let's say into the 50s towards the middle of the year, would you be inclined to upsize your activity level in the second half and in particular, would you return to drilling in the Bakken?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think as we saw that kind of recovery and we're convinced of the stability of it, I think it goes back to a point J.R. made earlier, it's going to be a capital allocation decision around do we feel that areas is still balance sheet repair that need
componenttext: Yes. I think as we saw that kind of recovery and we're convinced of the stability of it, I think it goes back to a point J.R. made earlier, it's going to be a capital allocation decision around do we feel that areas is still balance sheet repair that needs to be done at that stage? And that would not be mutually exclusive to putting capital back to work into the short cycle investments in the resource plays. When we think about capital allocation organically, certainly, our ability to maintain the scale efficiencies in the Eagle Ford and the strong economics there would make it a viable candidate for that incremental capital. But strategically, because of its role in our future growth driving more capital as well into Oklahoma would be one of our preferred pathways also. From an execution capacity and a competency standpoint, we feel that we're more than prepared to take that step in the event that, that incremental cash flow comes available for investment.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: But I think you raise a great point and that is because your picked 50s a hypothetical example, I mean, Bakken and 50 is dramatically different in the Bakken today and the leverage to crude oil changes dramatically. To even beginning at that level all of
componenttext: But I think you raise a great point and that is because your picked 50s a hypothetical example, I mean, Bakken and 50 is dramatically different in the Bakken today and the leverage to crude oil changes dramatically. To even beginning at that level all of a sudden, the capital allocation decisions for us with whatever limited additional capital to chose to go to a drill bit versus the balance sheet becomes much tougher at that point in time and high-class a problem to deal with but you're exactly right to highlight that leverage of commodity prices in the Bakken.

componenttext: And I would also add as well that some of the success that Lance and his team have had in Western Myrmidon near the has been pretty dramatic. And I think as we saw a recovery in pricing, I believe those opportunities would certainly come back into playing.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: I understand of these are tough times and you're very much circling the wagons. But could you just outlined the bull case  -- the equity bull case in Marathon in some and maybe suggest me how I should pitch the stock?

componenttextpreview: Sure, Paul. Think when you consider more constructive pricing, our leveraging up to crude oil, which is of course been a bit painful on the way down, that's going to feel a little bit different as we start seeing that more constructive pricing. And then I
componenttext: Sure, Paul. Think when you consider more constructive pricing, our leveraging up to crude oil, which is of course been a bit painful on the way down, that's going to feel a little bit different as we start seeing that more constructive pricing. And then I think it's the strength of our organic inventory across the 3 core basins, which now account for $3.6 billion of 2P resource. That's really the investment case. Not only the scale, the economies of scale that we have in development mode in the Eagle Ford but certainly the potential for growth both midterm and long-term in Oklahoma as well as the very solid oil position in Bakken. And I think a proven execution model where we have been able to not only drive capital efficiencies but also operating efficiencies and all of that being supported, I think by still some very good conventional assess as well, including Equatorial Guinea, which we just chatted about the project there, the compression project.

componenttext: Well, certainly that question is always out there. I think in the current environment, you haven't seen even a lot of a small even asset level activity. I think largely speaking because of the volatility and the dislocation between of the bid-ask spread has just really not facilitated that. Certainly, where the market sits today consolidation and the synergy that can be generated from that are very material relative to market cap as they stand today. So that case even beyond say, an improvement of overall portfolio and possibly even balance sheet upside, I think there is probably a case out there. For some flareups that might be based on the synergy benefits alone.

componenttext: I think for that level of outspend, which to me is getting in a much more manageable zip code, I think will look again on kind of those core levers that we can control and they would be the capital program continued, I would say capital efficiency as well as operating efficiency. headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Marathon Oil Corporation 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Katie, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I'll now turn the call over
componenttext:
Welcome to the Marathon Oil Corporation 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Katie, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. 
I'll now turn the call over to Chris Phillips. Mr. Phillips, please go ahead.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katie. Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil Corporation's fourth quarter and full 2015 earnings and 2016 capital program conference call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations. Also joining me on the call this morning are Lee
componenttext:
Thank you, Katie. Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil Corporation's fourth quarter and full 2015 earnings and 2016 capital program conference call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations. Also joining me on the call this morning are Lee Tillman, President and CEO; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Mitch Little, Vice President, Conventional; Lance Robertson, Vice President, Resource Plays; and Zach Dailey, Director of Investor Relations.
As has become our custom, we released prepared remarks last night in connection with the earnings release. You can find those remarks on the associated slides on our website at marathonoil.com. We will begin this morning with additional prepared remarks discussing our 2016 capital program. We issued a separate press release detailing our 2016 capital program last evening. We posted a second slide presentation earlier today for the company's this morning's prepared remarks that can also be found on our website.
After our remarks, the remainder of the call will be available for Q&A. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. 
Slide 2 contains a discussion of forward-looking statements and other information included in this presentation. Our review will contain forward-looking statements subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements.
We have identified, in our latest annual report on Form 10-K and other filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, a number of important factors that could cause future outcomes to differ materially from those set forth in those forward-looking statements. Please refer to the quarterly investor packet on our website for reconciliations of the non-GAAP financial measures discussed in this presentation to their most recently comparable GAAP financial measures.
With that, I will turn the presentation over to Lee, who will begin on Slide 3.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris. I'd like to extend my welcome to those listening. Last night, we announced a reduced capital program for 2016 that reflects the current challenging environment and our clear objective of balance sheet protection. Our $1.4 billion program in
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris. I'd like to extend my welcome to those listening. Last night, we announced a reduced capital program for 2016 that reflects the current challenging environment and our clear objective of balance sheet protection. Our $1.4 billion program in 2016 is over 50% lower than last year's program and 75% lower than 2014.
As the chart illustrates, we have responded as oil prices have fallen dramatically, and are doing the same in 2016 with our capital program calibrated to a view of WTI in the upper 30s and assume success in our noncore asset sale program.
Our business planning and budgeting are not static but rather, decisions are being made in realtime, in large part facilitated by the optionality afforded by our short cycle investments. We have designed our 2016 programs to maximize capital allocation to the short cycle investments in our U.S. resource plays, complete long cycle projects that contribute production and minimize allocation to conventional exploration. Guided by these principles as the foundation of our plan, production volumes were, by design and outcome, not an objective, and we are forecasting a total company production decline of 6% to 8% year-over-year adjusted for divestitures.
This program provides us the optionality to further adjust our short cycle investments if needed based on commodity prices and the outcome of our noncore asset sales.
Last year, we achieved over $300 million of noncore asset sales toward our original goal of at least $500 million. When we set that original target, we were transparent that the noncore assets under consideration far exceeded $500 million. Based on the transactions announced today as well as progress on the remaining assets, we've increased our target to a range of $750 million to $1 billion. This year's capital allocation is designed to position the company for a sustained period of low commodity prices while maintaining the capability to be flexible in a dynamic environment.
Slide 4 illustrates the allocation of our 2016 program in a bit more detail. As I mentioned, the majority of our 2016 program, about 70% will be directed to the Eagle Ford, SCOOP STACK and Bakken. For each of our 3 core resource plays, we have set specific objectives for our 2016 investment. Namely, maintaining the efficiencies our Eagle Ford team has worked so hard to capture; protecting our leasehold in the STACK while continuing to improve our understanding of the Oklahoma Resource Basin; and focusing on our base business in the Bakken with operated D&C greatly reduced. All of these, of course, while continuing to focus on sustainable cost reduction that will be maintained through the commodity cycle. Across the remainder of the portfolio, we will be completing several long cycle projects in 2016. Most notably, our operated compression project in EG. This project will extend plateau production from the Alba Field by an additional 2 years and allow us to develop in excess of $130 million netball equivalent barrels of proven reserves.
In addition to the EG compression project, we expect first oil this year from investments in 2 outside operated projects: Gunflint in the Gulf of Mexico; and Atrush in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq. We're forecasting about $40 million of sustaining CapEx toward our nonoperated working interest in the oil sands this year. We, along with the operator and other JV partner, are intensely focused on building upon the structural cost improvements and better uptime reliability achieved in 2015.
Finally, we've significantly reduced our conventional exploration CapEx this year to $30 million, down about 90% from last year, following the strategic decision we made last fall to scale back in this space. This year's spend is largely limited to existing commitments in the Gulf of Mexico and Gabon, with no new exploration wells planned in 2016.
As we enter another year with reduced capital investment, we again look to our short cycle U.S. resource plays to continue providing the operational flexibility to adapt to changing market conditions.
With that, I'll turn it over to Lance to review the resource plays in a bit more detail.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lee. I'll continue with the broad overview of the 2016 program for U.S. resource plays on Slide 5. Consistent with our focus on prioritizing the balance sheet this year, our allocation to the resource plays is anticipated at $1 billion, down about
componenttext:
Thanks, Lee. I'll continue with the broad overview of the 2016 program for U.S. resource plays on Slide 5. Consistent with our focus on prioritizing the balance sheet this year, our allocation to the resource plays is anticipated at $1 billion, down about 50% from 2015. As Lee said, the short cycle nature of these assets allows us to be flexible in a volatile commodity market. If needed, we have the option to reduce spending down further with substantially all of our acreage held by production in the Bakken, the Eagle Ford and in the SCOOP Woodford. We also have relatively few leases with continuing drilling obligations and no long-term rig commitments in these plays.
The pie charts on the slide depict our operated drilling and completions, our nonoperated drilling and completions and other spend across each basin. Through the budget planning process, our intent was to maximize the allocation to drilling and completions opportunities. The nonoperated drilling and completions component of the budget is our current best estimate of the spend based on recent engagement with partners. In the current commodity environment, we are closely scrutinizing each project proposal for costs and returns. When prudent, we will not consent discretionary projects that do not deliver adequate returns. 
Given the continuing decline in industry rig counts across our 3 basins, the expected bias in the non-operated estimates is lower. For reference, the other spend category broadly consist of diverse, nondiscretionary items for direct support and development activity, such as centralized facilities expansions, data gathering and other items not directly included in drilling and completions costs but essential parts of an operation.
Turning to the Eagle Ford, we are down to 7 rigs, and we'll be scaling down further to 5 rigs near the end of the first quarter. Additionally, we will be racing to a single frac crew for much of the year that will match drilling activity. Consistent with our past practices, we plan to maintain sufficient inventory to keep the completion crew operationally efficient. This activity level retains our execution capability and core competencies, allowing us to continue codeveloping the highest value Austin Chalk, Upper and Lower Eagle Ford horizons across our core acreage position. 
A continued focus on enhancing well productivity through stimulation design and technology application has recently yielded encouraging early results in our high GOR oil areas. As this activity matures, we anticipate sharing more details throughout the year. 
In the Oklahoma resource basins, our capital spend will focus on retaining term leases in the core of the STACK Meramec as we continue to delineate the rich condensate window and optimize stimulation designs. While maintaining leases will be our primary objective across Oklahoma this year, based on the success of our first operated Springer oil well in the fourth quarter in the SCOOP, we will also continue to progress limited Springer activity to delineate the down dip aerial extent of this play.
In the Bakken, we will focus on the base business where we will complete our ongoing water gathering system later this year to further reduce our largest single expense, water handling. Based on the current commodity price environment, we recently released our last operated rig in the Bakken and plan to have intermittent development activity later in the year, primarily to address continuing drilling obligations. With this reduced level of activity and at recent strip pricing, we anticipate Bakken achieves cash flow neutrality in 2016.
The $75 million earmarked for outside operated activity in Bakken is our current best estimate of AFEs we expect to receive from partners this year, and each will be scrutinized closely given the current low commodity environment.
Despite reduced resource play activity, we continue to balance our current actions with the need to be responsive when more constructive pricing occurs.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Mitch to review capital activities outside the resource plays.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lance. Referring to Slide 6, I'll provide a brief overview of 2016 activities across our remaining portfolio, where we continue to moderate capital spend, while delivering profitable long cycle projects during the year. Starting with our OSM
componenttext:
Thank you, Lance. Referring to Slide 6, I'll provide a brief overview of 2016 activities across our remaining portfolio, where we continue to moderate capital spend, while delivering profitable long cycle projects during the year. 
Starting with our OSM segment. We've achieved a step-change reduction in sustaining capital levels, and our 2016 CapEx at about $40 million is well below historical averages. Along with the operator and other JV partner, our focus remains on maintaining the improved reliability, while lowering operating and sustaining capital costs to reposition the business for profitable operation within the current environment. Despite challenging pricing in the third and fourth quarters last year, OSM was cash flow positive, thanks to operating cost that averaged less than $30 per barrel of synthetic crude oil for the 2 consecutive quarters. 
With the more consistent operations, our 3 highest net production quarters in the history of the operation occurred last year, leading to 2015 annual production volumes net of royalty at an all-time high, while unplanned downtime was at an all-time low.
Outside of OSM, we expect to complete 3 long cycle projects in 2016, bringing incremental cash flow starting in the second half of the year. Beginning with our operated business in EG, we completed a successful and incident free installation campaign of the combined 10,000-ton jacket and topsides for the Alba B3 compression project in mid-January. The project remains on budget and on schedule. Following hook-up and commissioning activities, we expect a midyear startup of the new facility. The installation will add 72,000 horsepower of compression and associated process equipment and utilities, which allow us to significantly extend Alba Field life to beyond 2030 with minimal future capital requirements.
In the Gulf of Mexico, we expect startup of the outside operated Gunflint, 2 well subsea development also by midyear.
Finally, in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq, developments are progressing within the Atrush and Sarsang outside operated blocks. In the Atrush block, installations of the Phase 1 30,000-barrel per day facility is progressing with first oil expected later this year. 4 existing wells will feed the facility and future development decisions will be evaluated following the assessment from well and reservoir performance.
In late 2015, a second well and wellsite production facility were brought online in the Sarsang block. 2016 activity is focused on bringing additional wells online to utilize existing facility capacity, while further expansion will be evaluated in light of the current macro environment.
Across the portfolio, we continue to focus on cost management and delivering high operational availability in an effort to defend margins within the challenging commodity price environment.
With that brief summary, I'll pass it back to Lee.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Well, thank you, Mitch. Capital discipline and balance sheet protection have driven the decision supporting our reduced 2016 capital program and slide 7 provides our production guidance. As I mentioned earlier, we're forecasting total company p
componenttext:
All right. Well, thank you, Mitch. Capital discipline and balance sheet protection have driven the decision supporting our reduced 2016 capital program and slide 7 provides our production guidance. As I mentioned earlier, we're forecasting total company production in 2016 to decline 6% to 8% from 2015, adjusted for our divestitures in the Gulf of Mexico and East Texas, North Louisiana.
For the first quarter 2016, our total E&P guidance includes 2 extraordinary downtime events. First, we expect downtime in EG of approximately 20,000 net BOE per day associated with the installation of the jacket and topsides for the Alba compression project as well as planned maintenance. Installation was completed in January in the Alba Field and on-shore plants returned to full production earlier this month.
Second, late December, the Brae off insulation experienced a process pipe failure, and first quarter total E&P production guidance includes the impact of the approximately 7,000 net BOE per day of U.K. production that remains shut-in while repairs are underway. Resumption of full production is expected in the second quarter.
Wrapping up on slide 8. We anticipate 2016 will require a similar level of flexibility to adapt to the uncertain macro environment as with last year. In 2015, we lowered production in G&A expenses over $435 million; we reduced our workforce by over 20%, which will generate about $160 million of annualized net savings; and we decreased our quarterly dividend, increasing annual free cash flow by more than $425 million. We became even more efficient operators in each of our basins, decreasing completed well costs everywhere through a combination of commercial savings and execution efficiencies.
2016 will require that same level of focus and discipline, and our $1.4 billion capital program is designed with balance sheet protection as our top priority. The plan continues to direct the lion's share of capital to our short cycle resource plays, which provide the most flexibility. The remainder of the portfolio includes completing long cycle projects that contribute production volumes to the company as well as keeping committed capital obligations to a minimal level.
We will continue lowering our cost structure, enhancing operational productivity and progressing toward our newly revised noncore asset sales target of $750 million to $1 billion.
Finally, our $4.2 billion in liquidity at year end, which includes $1.2 billion in cash in an undrawn $3 billion revolving credit facility, positions us well for the reality of sustained low commodity prices.
That concludes our remarks, and I will now hand back to Chris.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Lee, I'm afraid the topic this year is obviously balance sheet strength, credit metrics and obviously the credit agencies' somewhat onerous [indiscernible] some would argue. What additional steps are you prepared to take to basically get market comfort th
componenttext: Lee, I'm afraid the topic this year is obviously balance sheet strength, credit metrics and obviously the credit agencies' somewhat onerous [indiscernible] some would argue. What additional steps are you prepared to take to basically get market comfort that your balance sheet is -- can be managed through this downturn and whether you're prepared to allow your credit rating to slide to some investment-grade? I've got a follow-up.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me kind of take the first part and then maybe let J.R. jump in a little bit on just our view from a credit metrics standpoint and the ratings agencies. Our plan, Doug, as we stated in our opening remarks, was really designed with the view of kin
componenttext: Okay. Let me kind of take the first part and then maybe let J.R. jump in a little bit on just our view from a credit metrics standpoint and the ratings agencies. Our plan, Doug, as we stated in our opening remarks, was really designed with the view of kind of a high $30 WTI, and assumes success in our noncore asset sales target. But we still have implicit, quite a bit of flexibility within our capital program to really adjust further as we see changes and price changes in the macro as well as we see the outcome from our noncore asset sales. I think we demonstrated last year our, certainly, our willingness to use every lever available to us to ensure that we do in fact protect the balance sheet. I ticked through a few of those in my opening remarks, but the adjustment to the dividend, I think even the reduction in our capital budget last year of about $500 million, the strong steps that we took early in the cycle on both production expenses and G&A costs, including a basically a 700 reduction in our workforce, all of these, I think, are demonstrative of the actions that we are prepared to take to ensure that we are putting balance sheet protection first and foremost. Maybe with respect to the credit agencies and the credit metrics, perhaps I'll just let J.R. chime in on those.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, as you had indicated, clearly, we have had actions already taken by 2 of the 3 rating agencies to date. At those 2 that have taken action, we remain investment-grade. Clearly, there is one still remaining outstanding. You're right, and that they hav
componenttext: Doug, as you had indicated, clearly, we have had actions already taken by 2 of the 3 rating agencies to date. At those 2 that have taken action, we remain investment-grade. Clearly, there is one still remaining outstanding. You're right, and that they have taken a arguably significantly different view with regard to the commodity price outlook and seemed to be fundamentally approaching the industry different than historically and candidly the outcome is uncertain. But what I would tell you is we're -- as Lee had indicated, we're going to continue to make the decisions that are in the best interest of all stakeholders to support the balance sheet, and the outcome with regard to the agencies will be the outcome. But we're going to continue to make sure that we've got sufficient liquidity and appropriate balance sheet so that we can continue to be successful in terms of developing the resources that we have at this company.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, you said you had a second question?
componenttext: Doug, you said you had a second question?
