headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Lee, I'm afraid the topic du jour is obviously balance sheet strength, credit metrics and obviously the credit agencies' somewhat onerous [indiscernible] some would argue. What additional steps are you prepared to take to basically give market comfort tha
componenttext: Lee, I'm afraid the topic du jour is obviously balance sheet strength, credit metrics and obviously the credit agencies' somewhat onerous [indiscernible] some would argue. What additional steps are you prepared to take to basically give market comfort that your balance sheet is -- can be managed through this downturn and whether you're prepared to allow your credit rating to slide to some investment-grade? I've got a follow-up.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me kind of take the first part and then maybe let J.R. jump in a little bit on just our view from a credit metrics standpoint and the ratings agencies. Our plan, Doug, as we stated in our opening remarks, was really designed with the view of kin
componenttext: Okay. Let me kind of take the first part and then maybe let J.R. jump in a little bit on just our view from a credit metrics standpoint and the ratings agencies. Our plan, Doug, as we stated in our opening remarks, was really designed with the view of kind of a high $30 WTI, and assumes success in our noncore asset sales target. But we still have implicit, quite a bit of flexibility within our capital program to really adjust further as we see changes and price changes in the macro as well as we see the outcome from our noncore asset sales. I think we demonstrated last year our, certainly, our willingness to use every lever available to us to ensure that we do in fact protect the balance sheet. I ticked through a few of those in my opening remarks, but the adjustment to the dividend, I think even the reduction in our capital budget last year of about $500 million, the strong steps that we took early in the cycle on both production expenses and G&A costs, including a basically a 700 reduction in our workforce, all of these, I think, are demonstrative of the actions that we are prepared to take to ensure that we are putting balance sheet protection first and foremost. Maybe with respect to the credit agencies and the credit metrics, perhaps I'll just let J.R. chime in on those.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, as you had indicated, clearly, we have had actions already taken by 2 of the 3 rating agencies to date. At those 2 that have taken action, we remain investment-grade. Clearly, there is one still remaining outstanding. You're right in that they have
componenttext: Doug, as you had indicated, clearly, we have had actions already taken by 2 of the 3 rating agencies to date. At those 2 that have taken action, we remain investment-grade. Clearly, there is one still remaining outstanding. You're right in that they have taken a arguably significantly different view with regard to the commodity price outlook and seemed to be fundamentally approaching the industry different than historically and candidly the outcome is uncertain. But what I would tell you is we're -- as Lee had indicated, we're going to continue to make the decisions that are in the best interest of all stakeholders to support the balance sheet, and the outcome with regard to the agencies will be the outcome. But we're going to continue to make sure that we've got sufficient liquidity and appropriate balance sheet so that we can continue to be successful in terms of developing the resources that we have at this company.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, you said you had a second question?
componenttext: Doug, you said you had a second question?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just can -- maybe if I could, if you don't mind, just a clarification on the first one as my second question, if that's okay. I'll be more direct about it. Obviously, we've seen some of your peers issue equity, is that a risk for Marathon in your vie
componenttext: Yes. Just can -- maybe if I could, if you don't mind, just a clarification on the first one as my second question, if that's okay. I'll be more direct about it. Obviously, we've seen some of your peers issue equity, is that a risk for Marathon in your views? Is it something you think would be the right move given where your stock is trading? Or can you rule that out for investors at this point? And I'll leave it there.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, I think as we have said, there's no doubt in the current environment that the balance sheet is our top priority. We have to maintain as much financial and operational flexibility as we can to adjust to these very dynamic market conditions. We're con
componenttext: Doug, I think as we have said, there's no doubt in the current environment that the balance sheet is our top priority. We have to maintain as much financial and operational flexibility as we can to adjust to these very dynamic market conditions. We're constantly reassessing in real time our capital budget, our noncore asset sales, our overall balance sheet strength, as well as our liquidity. And I think although our business plan assumes the successful execution of our noncore assets program to really contribute to our goal of free cash flow neutrality, we have to continue to keep all options on the table and available to us to give us that financial flexibility going forward. So again, you should expect us to continue to consider and access all of the levers available to us going forward.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Edward Westlake from Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Edward Westlake from Crdit Suisse.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the divestiture program, maybe just give us some ideas as to why you can think you can be confident to hit that $750 million to $1 billion total program.
componenttext: Just on the divestiture program, maybe just give us some ideas as to why you can think you can be confident to hit that $750 million to $1 billion total program.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, Ed, good morning. First, maybe I'll just acknowledge that the market no doubt has softened since we embarked on our noncore asset program. There's no question that the sales market is much more challenging than it was even last year. But I'll
componenttext: Absolutely, Ed, good morning. First, maybe I'll just acknowledge that the market no doubt has softened since we embarked on our noncore asset program. There's no question that the sales market is much more challenging than it was even last year. But I'll go back and say, as a reminder, when we initially set our noncore asset target last year, we stated that we had identified a pretty broad pool of noncore assets that were well in excess of that original $500 million. And what I'll say is, based on our progress to date, the transactions that we've been able to complete and the quality as well as the diversity of the identified noncore assets that we still have in the hopper, we're comfortable increasing that target to that $750 million to $1 billion. The way I would kind of describe the asset, Ed, is that they're primarily U.S. upstream and midstream. They're both operated and nonoperated, but the list is very diverse and we are very satisfied taking some singles and doubles. Some will be bigger, but there's quite a few that will be smaller. And thus far, the market has shown an ability to digest some of those smaller transactions quite readily. Timing for us, we would expect to progress toward our revised target, really through the balance of 2016.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a follow-up would be around 2017. Getting a little depressing about recession risks, they are clearly rising, we'll see if one actually occurs. But you'll end up with, say, $1.2 billion or maybe whatever the number is at the end of the year, depe
componenttext: And then a follow-up would be around 2017. Getting a little depressing about recession risks, they are clearly rising, we'll see if one actually occurs. But you'll end up with, say, $1.2 billion or maybe whatever the number is at the end of the year, depending on the asset sales program and the reduction in capital. But again, if you were looking into 2017, it would still feel if there was a recession that you'd need to do some shoring up of the balance sheet for that year, so what would be next in terms of the order if we had 2 years of low prices?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Of course, that's -- we're trying to, of course, manage through '16 now. But as we have looked ahead to 2017, there's no question, Ed, that the majority of our capital will still be directed to the short-cycle investments. And as such, that still giv
componenttext: Yes. Of course, that's -- we're trying to, of course, manage through '16 now. But as we have looked ahead to 2017, there's no question, Ed, that the majority of our capital will still be directed to the short-cycle investments. And as such, that still gives us a great deal of flexibility within our capital program and our capital spend. That activity, though, is going to largely depend upon where commodity prices are. And just to maybe level set a little bit, at the kind of current contango in the strip, that would equate to us to about $500 million of incremental free cash flow in 2017. And then at that point, as incremental cash flow might be realized, it would be capital allocation decision based on the highest and best use as to whether that goes to balance sheet strengthening or and/or into organic investment. I don't see those 2 as necessarily being mutually exclusive. The other thing that I would add, too, is that although we do have some long-cycle projects, that Mitch addressed, rolling off in 2016, we do have a little bit of an offset and that we do have a remaining Deepwater GOM commitment, recommitment that will come back to us in 2017. So largely those 2 somewhat balance off of one another.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up on credit and balance sheet, the du jour topic -- and I understand you're protecting the balance sheet in the moves today, but how committed are you to an investment-grade rating? And based upon those private conversations, I mean, did y
componenttext: Just to follow up on credit and balance sheet, the du jour topic -- and I understand you're protecting the balance sheet in the moves today, but how committed are you to an investment-grade rating? And based upon those private conversations, I mean, did you expect to be able to maintain it from, I know you talked about Moody's, but from the other 2 agencies? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, Evan, we have maintained that at the other 2 agencies. They've just recently published earlier this month. And so those have come out with investment-grade ratings. They were a notch lower than where they were, but we have maintained it there
componenttext: Yes, I mean, Evan, we have maintained that at the other 2 agencies. They've just recently published earlier this month. And so those have come out with investment-grade ratings. They were a notch lower than where they were, but we have maintained it there. As for the outstanding rating evaluation, honestly, Evan, I don't know what they're going to define as what it means to be an investment-grade anymore. I remember what it used to be throughout most of my career, and based on my historical understanding, I would say we still meet the metrics that they used to lay out there but honestly, those are changing. And so I just -- I don't want to predict what they will ultimately do but at the end of the day, I'm still investment-grade. I'm still going to be part of the IG indices from a bond trading standpoint. There really isn't any significant impact on us if that 1 rating agency were to not rate us investment grade. I mean, clearly, there's going to be a cost issue and in periods that are highly volatile and access issue, but all of that is completely manageable.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then how do you weigh that? I mean, how do you weigh the impact of an even deeper CapEx cut or dilutive equity raise against a loss of that status? I mean, it just seems to be a primary debate amongst many of your peers.
componenttext: And then how do you weigh that? I mean, how do you weigh the impact of an even deeper CapEx cut or dilutive equity raise against a loss of that status? I mean, it just seems to be a primary debate amongst many of your peers.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, I don't think that ultimately you can necessarily solve for just 1 equation here. I've got to make decisions on the best interest of all of the stakeholders, and we're going to continue to do that. But as I said before, the way we've got the capita
componenttext: Again, I don't think that ultimately you can necessarily solve for just 1 equation here. I've got to make decisions on the best interest of all of the stakeholders, and we're going to continue to do that. But as I said before, the way we've got the capital structure set up, the depth of our liquidity that exists, that I'm very comfortable that whether we ultimately have an investment-grade rating from the remaining agency or not is not going to impact our ability to remain stronger in this commodity price cycle.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to stay on the usual suspect topic here. I think what we're probably trying to get at here is, what -- how do you define success from a balance sheet perspective? What are you trying -- where are you trying to take the company here? What is the ke
componenttext: So just to stay on the usual suspect topic here. I think what we're probably trying to get at here is, what -- how do you define success from a balance sheet perspective? What are you trying -- where are you trying to take the company here? What is the key metric you're trying to use that is driving your decision? It sounds like it's not necessarily, but hopefully, investment-grade. Is it leverage? Is it liquidity for a couple of years at $30 oil? Can you just kind of talk to how you would define success from a balance sheet perspective?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, Brian, I mean, honestly the way we're thinking about it is really just to focus on managing the balance sheet throughout the full cycle. So historically, I've always tried to focus on liquidity when you're at the bottom of the cycle. And again, h
componenttext: Yes. No, Brian, I mean, honestly the way we're thinking about it is really just to focus on managing the balance sheet throughout the full cycle. So historically, I've always tried to focus on liquidity when you're at the bottom of the cycle. And again, historically, that was the way it was measured, is whether or not you had enough liquidity to get you through the bottom of the cycle. As Lee indicated in his remarks, our goal here in 2016 is free cash flow neutrality. So to be able to manage the outspend with the success in the noncore asset sale program and not add debt to the balance sheet. And as I indicated, we're going to maintain ample liquidity to support the business. And in addition, I want to make sure in not only liquidity but the cash component of that liquidity to maintain the option associated with just delevering the balance sheet in late '17 when we have a relatively modest amount of debt that becomes due, about $700 million. So clearly, I think we've said multiple times, the noncore asset sale program and the flexibility of the capital program are really going to be the key levers on that. But one thing I do want to go to on this issue of leverage metrics and what to really highlight what Lee said before, just the embedded oil price leverage and the impact to cash flows and candidly the leverage metrics is significant. And Lee just said if just assuming the forward contango that exists today, so whatever that is from a current standpoint, probably about $7, sometime around there, is about $500 million of free cash flow and a significant step change in what your leverage would be on a net debt-to-EBITDA standpoint. So to me, we're focused on managing through the cycle and again, as I indicated to Evan, really just trying to make decisions that are in the best interest of the business.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: My follow-up is perhaps a surprise operational resource question. You acquired some additional acreage in SCOOP and STACK here over the last year. And I wondered if you could tell us a little bit more, a, what that does to make your position more contiguo
componenttext: My follow-up is perhaps a surprise operational resource question. You acquired some additional acreage in SCOOP and STACK here over the last year. And I wondered if you could tell us a little bit more, a, what that does to make your position more contiguous. And then how you would think about and at what price you would allocate more capital and where you would go first within your key onshore shale plays.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. This is Lance. I think you should think about those acres that we're constantly looking particularly in Oklahoma, which is early cycle in the play relative to the others to both, as you describe, core up that position and just secure addition
componenttext: Sure, Brian. This is Lance. I think you should think about those acres that we're constantly looking particularly in Oklahoma, which is early cycle in the play relative to the others to both, as you describe, core up that position and just secure additional resources. And we are very successful over the last year, primarily organically, through a small local auction processes in the BIA and the CLO and other organization as well as just doing small leasing opportunities with peers and accumulated 14,000 acres in Oklahoma. The overwhelming majority of that is in the STACK play focused in the core, primarily Blaine County. What we found over the balance of that year is that the core of the Meramec has shifted western, in the western direction, which is where most of that acreage was acquired and we managed to secure all that for about $3,000 an acre, which is very competitive. Referencing where we would go in terms of activity and allocate that capital, I think we're always going to take that broadly within our overall capital allocation process. We certainly want to be able to continue to delineate Oklahoma because we have more to learn there perhaps than other basins. I think we're going to have to wait and see how the commodity market really evolves before we can make those capital allocations beyond 2016.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Harry Mateer from Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Harry Mateer from Barclays.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess back to the topic du jour on the balance sheet but a bit of a different approach. To the extent you raise additional capital from your noncore asset sales or other means, how do you think about deploying that? I mean, is it more about maximizing l
componenttext: I guess back to the topic du jour on the balance sheet but a bit of a different approach. To the extent you raise additional capital from your noncore asset sales or other means, how do you think about deploying that? I mean, is it more about maximizing liquidity right now? Or when you look at where your bonds are trading, you've got some bonds particularly out the curve trading at a pretty chunky discount to par. So do you think there are some opportunities to maybe reduce debt that way, and take advantage of the discount clearly in the market?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Harry, this is J.R. I mean, I would approach that the same way Lance was talking about whether we'd allocate capital to Oklahoma to buy acreage. It really is each one of these investment opportunities are measured against themselves, whether it's dri
componenttext: Yes, Harry, this is J.R. I mean, I would approach that the same way Lance was talking about whether we'd allocate capital to Oklahoma to buy acreage. It really is each one of these investment opportunities are measured against themselves, whether it's drill-bit capital, whether it's acquiring additional acres in Oklahoma or whether it's even considering buying back some debt at a discount. So we're going to measure all of those capital allocation decisions and determine which ones make the best sense for the enterprise. Clearly, you've got to do that, you've got to do that thoughtfully. That's a great example in response to some of the earlier questions where that might be in the best interest of the company, rating agencies may view that transaction differently in terms of the way an investment-grade company should manage their business with the fundamental premise is that your debtholders be paid off at par. But again, we're going to make those decisions in the best interest to all stakeholders and it would be something that we would consider.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up is the 2017 maturity. It's later in 2017, so you've got some time. But as you think about managing the business through the cycle, is your goal to be in a position where you can pay that down? Or is it something more where you would
componenttext: And then my follow-up is the 2017 maturity. It's later in 2017, so you've got some time. But as you think about managing the business through the cycle, is your goal to be in a position where you can pay that down? Or is it something more where you would like to be in a position to be able to refinance that?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As I indicated, probably you missed it, Harry, earlier, I really want to be in a position to have the flexibility and the optionality just to pay that down, pay it off, in other words. Clearly, I've got the liquidity to where I could bridge it on my
componenttext: Yes. As I indicated, probably you missed it, Harry, earlier, I really want to be in a position to have the flexibility and the optionality just to pay that down, pay it off, in other words. Clearly, I've got the liquidity to where I could bridge it on my facility but I really want to be in a position if the market is what it is today, if the forward curve merely slides into 2017 to be able to pay that off.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from David Heikkinen from Heikkinen Energy.
componenttext: And our next question comes from David Heikkinen from Heikkinen Energy.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just thinking about the Eagle Ford program. You've basically been running kind of flat net wells for the last couple of quarters. Can you just talk about the pacing of net wells in 2016 as you drop to 5 rigs and kind of the -- particularly given the sh
componenttext: So just thinking about the Eagle Ford program. You've basically been running kind of flat net wells for the last couple of quarters. Can you just talk about the pacing of net wells in 2016 as you drop to 5 rigs and kind of the -- particularly given the shape of the commodity curve, do you go slower earlier and then pick up? Or how do you think through as kind of the -- that basin, and then really for the other basins as well?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, David, this is Lance. I think perhaps as we articulated in the capital deck and the remarks this morning that were prepared that we're already moving into the activity reductions in Eagle Ford. We actually released our first rig recently this month
componenttext: Sure, David, this is Lance. I think perhaps as we articulated in the capital deck and the remarks this morning that were prepared that we're already moving into the activity reductions in Eagle Ford. We actually released our first rig recently this month down at the end of this quarter, we'll be down to 5 rigs and then we're going to stay at that flat activity level moving forward. I think as a desire as we look at the balance sheet prioritization overall, we want to take those decisions early in the year and we have. And so you'll see us go down to that level and then maintain that activity level moving forward. And from quarter-to-quarter, you'll see those net wells to sales moderate up or down a little bit as we have diverse working interest across it, but it will be relatively level from that point forward. Similarly, we're going to continue to run effectively the 2 rigs we had all in 2015 through Oklahoma to manage lease obligations, and continue to delineate and learn in the Springer, the things we need to. And then reiterate, I think, the one I mentioned earlier, so we've actually released our Bakken activity challenged by returns currently with that price and so we're going to have limited activity for the rest of the year in the Bakken.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first quarter will have more wells and then just kind of divide the rest of the wells through the remainder of the year pretty evenly in the Eagle Ford and just keep things kind of flat? There's no staging or duck games going on, is I guess what I'm ge
componenttext: So first quarter will have more wells and then just kind of divide the rest of the wells through the remainder of the year pretty evenly in the Eagle Ford and just keep things kind of flat? There's no staging or duck games going on, is I guess what I'm getting at.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's a great clarification, David, and that we've said all along that we're not really building a drilled but uncompleted inventory. We're going to continue to manage our inventory of wells to efficiently manage our completion operations wit
componenttext: No, I think that's a great clarification, David, and that we've said all along that we're not really building a drilled but uncompleted inventory. We're going to continue to manage our inventory of wells to efficiently manage our completion operations without really materially building or depleting that inventory.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then I know you don't want to get into details of volumes on the assets that you're selling but the numbers are getting big with $1 billion. Can you just goal-post us on U.S. upstream and midstream, a split of how much would be midstre
componenttext: That's helpful. And then I know you don't want to get into details of volumes on the assets that you're selling but the numbers are getting big with $1 billion. Can you just goal-post us on U.S. upstream and midstream, a split of how much would be midstream, how much could be upstream, an idea of just rough volumes? Anything could be helpful.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, this is Lee. As I stated and so you noted that this is primarily U.S. assets that are both upstream and downstream. But if you look at the characteristics of what weve already moved out of the portfolio, you can get a sense for just the div
componenttext: Yes, David, this is Lee. As I stated and so you noted that this is primarily U.S. assets that are both upstream and downstream. But if you look at the characteristics of what weve already moved out of the portfolio, you can get a sense for just the diversity and even some of the scale of some of those actions that might occur in going forward. For instance, the East Texas/North Louisiana deal was on the order of 4,000 oil equivalent barrels per day. The GOM assets were on the order of about 10,000-ish barrels a day. So those are kind of the ballparks. Now those are some of the kind of small to midsize assets we might talk about now. There could be some larger, more material assets that do ultimately come into play. And of course, the midstream assets, the advantage there is that there really is no volumetric impact per se but you have, to, of course, be absolutely concerned about making sure that you have the right operational transition there to ensure security of your barrels. So I don't know but hopefully that helps a little bit.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Roger Read from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Roger Read from Wells Fargo.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess maybe to follow up a little bit with Dave's question there on the potential sales that we should think about for volumes. Is it just that wide open based on price? Or do you at least have sort of a maybe high to low range of full year potential im
componenttext: I guess maybe to follow up a little bit with Dave's question there on the potential sales that we should think about for volumes. Is it just that wide open based on price? Or do you at least have sort of a maybe high to low range of full year potential impact of what's potentially being marketed out there? Or you have a data room open, that sort of thing?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, without getting too much into the specifics, Roger, we certainly have a good idea of the pool of assets that we're prepared to put into the market. The uncertainty is just how -- which of those assets may in fact be transactable. And then each of tho
componenttext: Yes, without getting too much into the specifics, Roger, we certainly have a good idea of the pool of assets that we're prepared to put into the market. The uncertainty is just how -- which of those assets may in fact be transactable. And then each of those has a finite, I would say, probability of occurrence. And it really comes down to connecting the assets to the correct buyers. And because of the diversity of these assets, they do appeal to a very, I would say, broad and diverse range of buyers potentially as well. So we do -- that's one of the reasons why we kind of bracketed the range the way that we did. It's a little bit of the reflection of some of that uncertainty. And its uncertainty not only just in which transactions will move forward but also just the ultimate valuations that we're able to secure in those transactions as well.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess it just sounds like from a buyer's perspective they're more interested in buying assets that generate cash flow, so just trying to get a feel for...
componenttext: Sure. I guess it just sounds like from a buyer's perspective they're more interested in buying assets that generate cash flow, so just trying to get a feel for...

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely.
componenttext: Absolutely.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Where the volumes might go along the...
componenttext: Where the volumes might go along the...

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that -- hey, Roger, this is J.R. I think that the question's fair. I think what Lee is trying to convey is we've got a lot of optionality here and we're still talking about a range, even the revised range but candidly is not reflective yet of the full
componenttext: No, that -- hey, Roger, this is J.R. I think that the question's fair. I think what Lee is trying to convey is we've got a lot of optionality here and we're still talking about a range, even the revised range but candidly is not reflective yet of the full potential of what we're looking at. And so we've got the ability to plug and play assets here. And because there's a midstream element to this, it's hard for us to be able to say exactly whether this asset ultimately goes or that asset goes. We're still very confident and comfortable with that $750 million to $1 billion, but, candidly, it's going to be asset-specific in terms of which ones we use to achieve that objective.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then probably more of a question for Lance, but decline rates in the Eagle Ford with such a ramp-down of drilling and well completions relative to the pace we were on, I understand, I recognize you would've studied it quite a bit
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then probably more of a question for Lance, but decline rates in the Eagle Ford with such a ramp-down of drilling and well completions relative to the pace we were on, I understand, I recognize you would've studied it quite a bit as you lay out the 6% to 8% decline for the year. But can you give us an idea of some of the confidence you have as some of the wells get older and fewer new wells coming in to sort of lay out the overall view here on the production side for '16?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Roger. And as you described, we've looked at a number of scenarios across the resource plays for activity in that and they all have their own implicit declines depending on the new wells coming to sales. I think, individually, in each of the basins,
componenttext: Sure, Roger. And as you described, we've looked at a number of scenarios across the resource plays for activity in that and they all have their own implicit declines depending on the new wells coming to sales. I think, individually, in each of the basins, we have a lot of confidence and understanding of the decline profiles of the areas. And so it just becomes a matter of what's the capital we're going to allocate to it, and then the production is the outcome from it in this case. I think it's pretty clear that we've taken the activity down both in 2015 and 2016. There have to be decline in there. I think importantly, in the Eagle Ford, for example from Q3 to Q4, we held flat with effectively flat wells to sales, which indicates all the horizons we've been developing there are producing well and meet our expectations. And then I think you should think of the resource plays from annual '15 to annual '16 are going to have an overall decline in the low teens.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from John Herrlin from Socit Gnrale.
componenttext: And our next question comes from John Herrlin from Socit Gnrale.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Regarding the Springer well, were you surprised to the degree of liquids cut?
componenttext: Regarding the Springer well, were you surprised to the degree of liquids cut?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, so I think the Springer is pretty early in the SCOOP area. And what we found are 2 different distinct areas where it's been tested today. It's sort of a northern core and a southern core. The well -- the newbie well we drilled and brought online las
componenttext: John, so I think the Springer is pretty early in the SCOOP area. And what we found are 2 different distinct areas where it's been tested today. It's sort of a northern core and a southern core. The well -- the newbie well we drilled and brought online last quarter was in that southern core area, where there's probably the most data. We expected that to be oil biased in that area. I think we had a lot of confidence going in, the results so far have borne that out. The performance from that well has been very strong to begin with and it actually is similar to the underlying Woodford, elevated reservoir pressure, the cumulative 30, 60 day production tend to be relatively flat. That same production behavior has been borne out in the Springer thus far. So it's actually very consistent with our expectations, that's why we're excited about it. What we also see is the opportunity to delineate this play down dip from the core oil areas that we explored and others have looked at today into a rich condensate window, perhaps. So you'll see us continue to test that in a limited way, the Springer, across 2016.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Next one for me, J.R., you mentioned liquidity not being like the past. If you look at your overall liquidity relative to market value, in the past, when commodity prices were down, you would have a much lower percentage of overall liquidity relati
componenttext: Great. Next one for me, J.R., you mentioned liquidity not being like the past. If you look at your overall liquidity relative to market value, in the past, when commodity prices were down, you would have a much lower percentage of overall liquidity relative to market cap but it seems like a lot of companies are getting penalized today for -- straight question perhaps on strategy or leverage or whatever. Do you ever recall a time when there was this much relative liquidity to market cap, equity cap?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great point, John. Honestly, there's been a shift and it happened maybe even toward the latter part of last year to where, I think, there was a point in which liquidity was being rewarded in terms of equity valuations but then it quickly shifted
componenttext: That's a great point, John. Honestly, there's been a shift and it happened maybe even toward the latter part of last year to where, I think, there was a point in which liquidity was being rewarded in terms of equity valuations but then it quickly shifted to almost a singular focus on leverage without regard to liquidity. And so I don't recall that and you've got a long history as well, John, in terms of that being the market behavior historically. Candidly, I'm very thankful for the early moves that we did with regard to shoring up that liquidity, the early moves we did with regard to extending debt maturities, and feel like we're well situated for both '16 and '17 on the liquidity front, but it is interesting that the anomalies that we're seeing or the nuances as compared to previous market corrections.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one from me. You mentioned that the current year CapEx is predicated on high 30s average. If, perchance, we were to see a recovery, let's say into the 50s towards the middle of the year, would you be inclined to upsize your activity level in the seco
componenttext: Just one from me. You mentioned that the current year CapEx is predicated on high 30s average. If, perchance, we were to see a recovery, let's say into the 50s towards the middle of the year, would you be inclined to upsize your activity level in the second half, and in particular would you return to drilling in the Bakken?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think as we saw that kind of recovery and we're convinced of the stability of it, I think it goes back to a point J.R. made earlier. It's going to be a capital allocation decision around do we feel that there is still balance sheet repair that need
componenttext: Yes. I think as we saw that kind of recovery and we're convinced of the stability of it, I think it goes back to a point J.R. made earlier. It's going to be a capital allocation decision around do we feel that there is still balance sheet repair that needs to be done at that stage? And that would not be mutually exclusive to putting capital back to work into the short cycle investments in the resource plays. When we think about capital allocation organically, certainly, our ability to maintain the scale efficiencies in the Eagle Ford and the strong economics there would make it a viable candidate for that incremental capital. But strategically, because of its role in our future growth driving more capital as well into Oklahoma, would be one of our preferred pathways also. From an execution capacity and a competency standpoint, we feel that we're more than prepared to take that step in the event that, that incremental cash flow comes available for investment.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pavel, I think you raised a great point and that is because you picked 50 as your hypothetical example, I mean, the Bakken at 50 is dramatically different than the Bakken today. And the leverage to crude oil changes dramatically. So even beginning at that
componenttext: Pavel, I think you raised a great point and that is because you picked 50 as your hypothetical example, I mean, the Bakken at 50 is dramatically different than the Bakken today. And the leverage to crude oil changes dramatically. So even beginning at that level, all of a sudden, the capital allocation decisions for us, with whatever limited additional capital we chose to go to a drill bit versus the balance sheet, becomes much tougher at that point in time and a high-class problem to deal with. But you're exactly right to highlight that leveraged commodity prices in the Bakken.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would also add as well that some of the success that Lance and his team have had in Western Myrmidon near the Nesson anticline has been pretty dramatic. And I think as we saw a recovery in pricing, I believe those opportunities would certainly come
componenttext: And I would also add as well that some of the success that Lance and his team have had in Western Myrmidon near the Nesson anticline has been pretty dramatic. And I think as we saw a recovery in pricing, I believe those opportunities would certainly come back into play.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I understand that these are tough times and you're very much circling the wagons but could you just outline the bull case, the equity bull case for Marathon in competitive terms, and maybe suggest to me how I should pitch the stock?
componenttext: I understand that these are tough times and you're very much circling the wagons but could you just outline the bull case, the equity bull case for Marathon in competitive terms, and maybe suggest to me how I should pitch the stock?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, absolutely, Paul. I think when you consider more constructive pricing, our leveraging up to crude oil, which has, of course, been a bit painful on the way down, that's going to feel a little bit different as we start seeing that more constructi
componenttext: Yes. Sure, absolutely, Paul. I think when you consider more constructive pricing, our leveraging up to crude oil, which has, of course, been a bit painful on the way down, that's going to feel a little bit different as we start seeing that more constructive pricing. And then I think it's the strength of our organic inventory across the 3 core basins, which now account for $3.6 billion of 2P resource. That's really the investment case. Not only the scale, the economies of scale that we have in development mode in the Eagle Ford but certainly the potential for growth both midterm and long-term in Oklahoma, as well as the very solid oil position in Bakken. And I think a proven execution model where we have been able to not only drive capital efficiencies but also operating efficiencies, and all of that being supported, I think, by still some very good conventional assets as well, including Equatorial Guinea, which we just chatted about the project there, the compression project.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's good. That's, I guess, primarily you're saying that you are dependent on pricing but you'd highlight a better organic inventory, was the second point.
componenttext: That's good. That's, I guess, primarily you're saying that you are dependent on pricing but you'd highlight a better organic inventory, was the second point.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say -- that I would say it's a strong high-quality inventory, very resilient, very oil-weighted. It's also one that we think is in 3 of the highest-quality plays here in the U.S., and all of those also at scale.
componenttext: Yes. I would say -- that I would say it's a strong high-quality inventory, very resilient, very oil-weighted. It's also one that we think is in 3 of the highest-quality plays here in the U.S., and all of those also at scale.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- just changing foot, is there any potential for mergers or acquisition as an alternate way to change the investment case?
componenttext: The -- just changing foot, is there any potential for mergers or acquisition as an alternate way to change the investment case?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly that question is always out there. I think in the current environment, you haven't seen even a lot of small, even asset-level activity. I think largely speaking because of the volatility and the dislocation between the bid-ask spread has j
componenttext: Well, certainly that question is always out there. I think in the current environment, you haven't seen even a lot of small, even asset-level activity. I think largely speaking because of the volatility and the dislocation between the bid-ask spread has just really not facilitated that. Certainly, where the market sits today, consolidation and the synergy that can be generated from that are very material relative to market cap as they stand today. So that case, even beyond say, let's say, an improvement of overall portfolio and possibly even balance sheet upside, I think there is probably a case out there for some pair-ups that might be based on the synergy benefits alone.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Marathon Oil Corporation's 2016 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sylvia and I will be the operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to C
componenttext: Welcome to the Marathon Oil Corporation's 2016 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sylvia and I will be the operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Chris Phillips. Mr. Phillips, you may begin.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sylvia. Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil's first quarter 2016 earnings call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations.  Joining me on the call this morning are Lee Tillman, President and CEO; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice Preside
componenttext:
Thank you, Sylvia. Good morning, and welcome to Marathon Oil's first quarter 2016 earnings call. I'm Chris Phillips, Director of Investor Relations.  Joining me on the call this morning are Lee Tillman, President and CEO; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO; Mitch Little, Vice President, Conventional; Lance Robertson, Vice President, Resource Plays; and Zach Dailey, Director of Investor Relations.  
Our earnings release, prepared remarks and associated slides are posted at marathonoil.com. 
As a reminder, today's call may contain forward-looking statements subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. Please read our disclosures in our earnings release and in our SEC filings for a discussion of these items. Reconciliations of any non-GAAP financial measures we discuss can be found in the quarterly information package on our website. 
With that, I will turn the call over to Lee.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris. Let me add my good morning. I'd like to take a few moments here to just offer some opening comments before we start taking your questions. Our first quarter results highlight our continued focus on resetting our cost structure across all
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris. Let me add my good morning. I'd like to take a few moments here to just offer some opening comments before we start taking your questions. 
Our first quarter results highlight our continued focus on resetting our cost structure across all elements of our business, reducing our capital program consistent with our plan and delivering production at the upper end of our guidance. Our capital program remains squarely focused on maximizing allocation to our lower risk, higher return U.S. resource play. 
In the Eagle Ford, we continue to see well performance uplift from tighter state spacing in our high, GOR oil wells while driving completed well cost down by about $2 million last year. 
In the Bakken, we released our remaining rig but base production outperformed our expectations supported by 2015 enhanced well completions all while decreasing production expense for oil equivalent barrel 35% year-over-year. 
And in Oklahoma, we progressed our operated drilling program for leasehold protection and delineation. 
Outside the U.S., the jacket and topsides for the EG compression project were successfully installed ahead of schedule and we remain on track for first production midyear. At OSM, the asset continued to perform well on both the cost and reliability fronts. On that subject, our thoughts go out to Fortenberry community today where wildfires continue to take their toll. Though not currently threatened, operations at the Muscag [ph] river and Jack Pine [ph] mines had been temporarily suspended to support emergency respond efforts. 
This year, we've continued to strengthen the balance sheet, first through the equity offering; and second, through the successful execution of our noncore asset sales program. In April we announced $950 [ph] million worth of noncore asset sales, bringing our total since last summer to $1.3 billion, far exceeding our target and delivering on this commitment early in the year.
With this success, we are on track to achieve our 2016 objective to live within our means inclusive of noncore asset sales. 
Looking ahead to the second quarter. Total company E&P production will be higher with EG and the U.K. Brayfill [ph] back online. We'll bring on twice the number of wells to sales in Oklahoma, 4 in the stack, 3 in the scoop and all in extended laterals. We'll have additional results from completion enhancements in the Eagle Ford, though at a reduced pace. And at the Bakken, we'll have our Clark's Creek pad online in West Myrmidon. 
Everything we've been doing for the last 18 months, lowering costs, workforce reductions, strengthening the balance sheet and executing noncore asset sales has been designed to provide us the flexibility to respond when we see constructive commodity prices and to derisk our business planning through 2017 in what remains an uncertain commodity price environment. 
While some positive trends are occurring, we're not yet confident that global supply and demand fundamentals are not supportive of sustained higher oil prices and we expect volatility to continue. As we strengthening to $50 and above, we are well-positioned to consider increasing activity levels. 
Having quality resource, execution capability and a strong balance sheet puts us in a favorable position beyond our front foot when the time comes. 
Before I close, I'd like to recognize Chris Phillips who will retire at the end of the month. Chris joined Marathon Oil in 1984 to help build the North Bray [ph] platform in the U.K. and has served in various roles within the company since, including the last 8 years in Investor Relations. My thanks to Chris for all of his contributions and we wish him all the best in his retirement. And Chris is leaving our IR team in good hands, so please contact Zach Dailey going forward for all IR related matters. 
With that, I'll hand it back to Chris to begin the Q&A.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lee. Before we open the call for questions, we'd like to request that you ask no more than 2 questions with associated clarifications, and you can reprompt as time permits. With that, Sylvia, you can open the line for questions.

With that, Sylvia, you can open the line for questions.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me also add my congratulations to Chris. It's been a pleasure, Chris, and I know we'll keep in touch going forward. Maybe we can just jump straight into the capital question. You got a fair amount of non, I guess, longer dated capital in 2016. I'm gue
componenttext: Let me also add my congratulations to Chris. It's been a pleasure, Chris, and I know we'll keep in touch going forward. Maybe we can just jump straight into the capital question. You got a fair amount of non, I guess, longer dated capital in 2016. I'm guessing some of that is going to fall away with the completion of some projects. I wonder if you could speak to your capital flexibility beyond that $50 ceiling that you mentioned or if you're able to look back to work, and how things might change as those spending commitments draw away?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely, Doug. On the longer cycle investments that we have in 2016 that will be wrapping up, first and foremost is the operated compression project in Equatorial Guinea, which as I mentioned we are still on track for start up in midyear. Secondly
componenttext: Yes, absolutely, Doug. On the longer cycle investments that we have in 2016 that will be wrapping up, first and foremost is the operated compression project in Equatorial Guinea, which as I mentioned we are still on track for start up in midyear. Secondly, of course, is our involvement in the nonoperated Gun Flint project in the Gulf of Mexico, which also will be starting up approximately midyear. And then finally, our nonoperated participation in the Atrush [ph] project in the Kurdistan region. So those 3 projects will essentially run their course from a capital program standpoint this year and would not be recurring in 2017. So as you state, that does give us some flexibility. If you think about our 2016 capital program, we have -- of the $1.4 billion budget that we've talked about, about $1 billion of that, of course, is targeting the U.S. resource play, the short cycle investments, and about $400 million is targeting the rest of the portfolio, of which those 3 long cycle projects are a material component of that $400 million. We do still have some commitments in the exploration space, commission exploration space, that will have potentially an offset to that. But largely speaking, those projects will come out and provide us a good deal more flexibility in 2017.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So basically, should we anticipate that the $50 number that you mentioned as kind of a ceiling -- or sorry, a starting point to go back to work? Does that assume that the overall spending levels stays the same next year?
componenttext: So basically, should we anticipate that the $50 number that you mentioned as kind of a ceiling -- or sorry, a starting point to go back to work? Does that assume that the overall spending levels stays the same next year?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think when we talk about the $50 number, Doug, for us that's really the constructive signal to start increasing our activity considering reinvestment back into the short cycle investments, and that would be on some type of ramp. I think the capita
componenttext: Well, I think when we talk about the $50 number, Doug, for us that's really the constructive signal to start increasing our activity considering reinvestment back into the short cycle investments, and that would be on some type of ramp. I think the capital program for '17 remains to be developed. But you would expect that we would be directing more than that $1 billion that we had this year toward the short cycle investments in that kind of constructive pricing case. And we believe that at that $50 number, Doug, that we would not only have the opportunity to flatten the declines coming out of the resource plays, but actually get back on a sequential quarter-on-quarter growth as we get toward the back end of 2017.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: My follow-up, hopefully a quick one, is just in terms of capital reallocation. Your SCOOP, STACK appears to be gravitating to the relative priority in terms of capital allocation. Is that a reasonable representation as to where [indiscernible] go first? A
componenttext: My follow-up, hopefully a quick one, is just in terms of capital reallocation. Your SCOOP, STACK appears to be gravitating to the relative priority in terms of capital allocation. Is that a reasonable representation as to where [indiscernible] go first? And if so, where are you in terms of commitments? And I'll leave it there.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I do think that as we do get a more constructive commodity price environment, sort of looking at that first kind of new dollar of capital allocation, that the Oklahoma resource bases in the SCOOP and the STACK are going to compete very strongly for
componenttext: Okay. I do think that as we do get a more constructive commodity price environment, sort of looking at that first kind of new dollar of capital allocation, that the Oklahoma resource bases in the SCOOP and the STACK are going to compete very strongly for that initial investment when it becomes available. Currently, we're running a 2-rig operated program. That in essence covers our HBP requirements. We're largely held in the SCOOP currently, but most of our leasehold activity is directed at the STACK. And of course, our Meramec drilling, in fact 2/3 of the Oklahoma program this year is directed towards the STACK and the Meramec. And we would expect that by the time we get to year-end 2016, we should be around 70% HBP'd with the rig activity that we currently have in place.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great question. This is Lance. I think in general from our organic leasing as well as our historical efforts in there, we have a large footprint in that what we view as the core of the Meramec, we see about 90% of our core acreage is underneath or inside
componenttext: Great question. This is Lance. I think in general from our organic leasing as well as our historical efforts in there, we have a large footprint in that what we view as the core of the Meramec, we see about 90% of our core acreage is underneath or inside that window that's overpressured from that volatile oil window to down dip. So a substantial portion of ours is over pressured. Part of the reason we've been growing, developing lease position in that area is to focus on that overpressure, high reservoir energy acreage.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Switching to the Eagle Ford. Obviously you mentioned in the first quarter results that you had seen some encouraging results. You give us data, 20% above on them offset wells from tighter cluster spacing, the safe spacing. Any sort of update on EURs for t
componenttext: Switching to the Eagle Ford. Obviously you mentioned in the first quarter results that you had seen some encouraging results. You give us data, 20% above on them offset wells from tighter cluster spacing, the safe spacing. Any sort of update on EURs for those wells? The completed well cost of 4.3 [ph] also seems quite low, so maybe just talk a bit about how you managed to get down there?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ed. So starting with the EURs, I think the group of wells we released this quarter is really a follow on from the group from the previous quarter. So we've seen consistently that tighter stage spacing, in some cases tighter cluster spacing is also dr
componenttext: Yes, Ed. So starting with the EURs, I think the group of wells we released this quarter is really a follow on from the group from the previous quarter. So we've seen consistently that tighter stage spacing, in some cases tighter cluster spacing is also driving well productivity. Most of that activity has been focused in the oil areas as we've looked to try to upgrade or improve the returns in our best acreage as well as lift some of our other acreage up to the highest year of returns, so we started on that, reflecting that if you recall about 60% of our future inventory is in that high GOR oil window. We've also had the opportunity now to move that stage spacing down in the condensate window. And although it's early we're encouraged from the response from the wells. You'll see us continue that. And I think what we'll find is as those wells mature, and speaking out the oil wells over the next months and this year, we expect the EURs to rise. We haven't reflected that yet because the production history is just too immature. But on the consistent response for that, I think its important to note that we effectively move that stage base into the basis of all our oil well completions and continuing to attest even down to 150-foot spacing today. And then on top of the capital, I think, the capital reflects really the focus in the team. They're continuing to drill the wells faster, and be efficient and focused on that. they're continuing to stimulate the wells faster. We average more than 200 stages per month from our primary frac crew in the first quarter, which is the most efficient we've ever been with that equipment set. And so those efficiencies that come to the bottom line helping to drive those cost down even as we spend more and invest more in the completions. Certainly, overall, I think I'd say that we're still getting a bit of commercial health. Most of these cost changes recently are driven focused by the efficiency drive within the team.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is on the asset monetizations. Your proceeds exceeded the high end of the guidance and still in motion. Any new guidance range here or maybe some color on how you arrived at the original guidance and what drove the excess, whether it be
componenttext: My first question is on the asset monetizations. Your proceeds exceeded the high end of the guidance and still in motion. Any new guidance range here or maybe some color on how you arrived at the original guidance and what drove the excess, whether it be risking on the program, more assets sold or better prices?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think, we've been, Evan, pretty consistent that noncore asset sales will just be part of what we do as part of our ongoing portfolio management with management strategy. As such, even though I think we have been successful in completing the s
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think, we've been, Evan, pretty consistent that noncore asset sales will just be part of what we do as part of our ongoing portfolio management with management strategy. As such, even though I think we have been successful in completing the sales against our published target, you should not deem that as us being finished or complete from a noncore asset standpoint. Yes, we're not putting out a new target. But certainly, the continued optimization of our portfolio is just part of what we want to be doing going forward. It's -- when we began that process, we had identified a population of noncore assets that we considered, did they compete for capital allocation? Could they potentially have higher-value in someone else's portfolio? That population, even on a risk-adjusted basis, allowed us to have confidence in putting that target, first target out there of $500 million and then ultimately, increasing that target to the $750 million, $1 billion mark. So I think what we've seen is that for these quality assets and a great example would be Wyoming, there is still a strong market out there that's willing to compete and pay very strong value for that type of asset. And again, it comes down to matching up very specific assets to very specific buyer pools. And I think that's what created our success this year.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. Maybe just the same question in a different way. The $1.3 [ph] billion sold, can you give me a percentage of what that was in your original guidance?
componenttext: That's great. Maybe just the same question in a different way. The $1.3 [ph] billion sold, can you give me a percentage of what that was in your original guidance?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Well, I mean what I would say is that we identified well in excess of that original -- of that completed $1.3 billion. And so there is still room for continued portfolio optimization. For us, it will just be a focus on timing and how do we maximize value to the shareholder from those future transactions.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's fair. Let me ask my second question on the Eagle Ford. You cite the ability to drill 97% within 20 feet. Maybe some color on where that was a year ago or where do you think the average is? I guess how that relates to both drilling speed and
componenttext: Great. That's fair. Let me ask my second question on the Eagle Ford. You cite the ability to drill 97% within 20 feet. Maybe some color on where that was a year ago or where do you think the average is? I guess how that relates to both drilling speed and well performance as I'm trying to mention the impact of that and where you think that maybe going?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Evan. I think you wouldn't be surprised if we articulated that, that target window has evolved over time to be a specific interval from a wider interval. And there would be positive tension on the size of that target versus how fast you can actually
componenttext: Sure, Evan. I think you wouldn't be surprised if we articulated that, that target window has evolved over time to be a specific interval from a wider interval. And there would be positive tension on the size of that target versus how fast you can actually drill a well. The team has gotten very consistent and been able to be focused in that target and still deliver the well at a very high efficiency within that. Part of that is repetition. They've had a lot of expense in the basin, a lot of practice if you will. And so they've gotten very effective at it. And we've been consistently in the mid-90% in terms of landing a target over time. I think when we look at it is we made the target smaller over the last quarters and years and they still been able to within that even as they increase the efficiency, which really speaks to the collaboration between the geosciences and the drilling engineering, that collaborative effort to work together to deliver those great results. If we expect to continue to be able to deliver those results consistently even if the efficiency will still drive upwards.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So I guess both elements are targeted to change, both the percentage that relates more to time. And I guess the size, the tightness as it relates to the oil subsequent well performance?
componenttext: Right. So I guess both elements are targeted to change, both the percentage that relates more to time. And I guess the size, the tightness as it relates to the oil subsequent well performance?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, to some degree. But also keep in mind come over the last 2 years, we've really pioneered the concept of a multi-horizon development in South Texas. The Austin Chalk, the Upper Eagle Ford and Lower Eagle Ford and we're doing all of those. And that per
componenttext: Yes, to some degree. But also keep in mind come over the last 2 years, we've really pioneered the concept of a multi-horizon development in South Texas. The Austin Chalk, the Upper Eagle Ford and Lower Eagle Ford and we're doing all of those. And that percentage reflects landing 3 different horizons drilled from the same pad in most cases, or more than one of those horizon from every pad in almost every case. So the team is doing done a really good job of targeting multihorizons in very complex trajectories. I think it just demonstrates the efficacy overall.

componenttext: Your SCOOP and STACK and maybe specifically, what is your focus for 2016? Obviously you've got HBP work that needs to be done.
