headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Guys, maybe we can just jump straight into the capital question. You've got a fair amount of non -- I guess, longer-dated capital in 2016. I'm guessing some of that's going to fall away with the completion of some projects. I wonder if you could speak to
componenttext: Guys, maybe we can just jump straight into the capital question. You've got a fair amount of non -- I guess, longer-dated capital in 2016. I'm guessing some of that's going to fall away with the completion of some projects. I wonder if you could speak to your capital flexibility beyond that $50 ceiling that you mentioned or were able to go back to work, and how things might change as those spending commitments fall away.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely, Doug. On the longer-cycle investments that we have in 2016 that will be wrapping up, first and foremost, is the operated compression project in Equatorial Guinea, which as I mentioned we are still on track for startup in midyear. Secondly
componenttext: Yes, absolutely, Doug. On the longer-cycle investments that we have in 2016 that will be wrapping up, first and foremost, is the operated compression project in Equatorial Guinea, which as I mentioned we are still on track for startup in midyear. Secondly, of course, is our involvement in the nonoperated Gunflint project in the Gulf of Mexico, which also will be starting up approximately midyear. And then finally, our nonoperated participation in the Atrush project in the Kurdistan region. So those 3 projects will essentially run their course from a capital program standpoint this year and would not be recurring in 2017. So as you state, that does gives us some flexibility. If you think about our 2016 capital program, we have -- of the $1.4 billion budget that we've talked about, about $1 billion of that, of course, is targeting the U.S. resource plays, the short cycle investments; and about $400 million is targeting the rest of the portfolio. Of which, those 3 long cycle projects are a material component of that $400 million. We do still have some commitments in the exploration space, conventional exploration space, that will have potentially an offset to that. But largely speaking, those projects will come out and provide us a good deal of more flexibility in 2017.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So basically, we would -- should anticipate that the $50 number that you mentioned as kind of a ceiling -- or sorry, a starting point to go back to work? Does that assume that the overall spending level stays the same next year?
componenttext: So basically, we would -- should anticipate that the $50 number that you mentioned as kind of a ceiling -- or sorry, a starting point to go back to work? Does that assume that the overall spending level stays the same next year?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think when we talk about the $50 number, Doug, for us, that's really the constructive signal to start increasing our activity, considering reinvestment back into the short cycle investments, and that would be on some type of ramp. I think the capi
componenttext: Well, I think when we talk about the $50 number, Doug, for us, that's really the constructive signal to start increasing our activity, considering reinvestment back into the short cycle investments, and that would be on some type of ramp. I think the capital program for '17 remains to be developed. But you would expect that we would be directing more than that $1 billion that we had this year toward the short cycle investments in that kind of constructive pricing case. And we believe that at that $50 number, Doug, that we would not only have the opportunity to flatten the declines coming out of the resource plays, but actually get back on a sequential quarter-on-quarter growth as we get toward the back end of 2017.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. My follow-up, hopefully, a quick one, is just in terms of capital reallocation. Your SCOOP, STACK area appears to be gravitating to the top of the -- the relative priority in terms of capital allocation. Is that a reasonable representation as to w
componenttext: Got it. My follow-up, hopefully, a quick one, is just in terms of capital reallocation. Your SCOOP, STACK area appears to be gravitating to the top of the -- the relative priority in terms of capital allocation. Is that a reasonable representation as to where new rigs would go first? And if so, where are you in terms of your HBP commitments? And I'll leave it there.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I do think that as we do get a more constructive commodity price environment, start looking at that first, kind of, new dollar of capital allocation, that the Oklahoma Resource Basins, the SCOOP and the STACK, are going to compete very strongly for
componenttext: Okay. I do think that as we do get a more constructive commodity price environment, start looking at that first, kind of, new dollar of capital allocation, that the Oklahoma Resource Basins, the SCOOP and the STACK, are going to compete very strongly for that initial investment when it becomes available. Currently, we're running a 2-rig operated program. That, in essence, covers our HBP requirements. We're largely held in the SCOOP currently, but most of our leasehold activity is directed at the STACK, and of course, our Meramec drilling. In fact 2/3 of the Oklahoma program this year is directed toward the STACK and the Meramec. And we would expect that by the time we get to year-end 2016, we should be around 70% HBP'd with the rig activity that we currently have in place.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. That was definitely meant to be a compliment. Anyway, a couple of quick operational ones. Just, obviously, the STACK is -- emerged as a very competitive play. The overpressured window is becoming more delineated by yourself and peers. You've got
componenttext: Yes, yes. That was definitely meant to be a compliment. Anyway, a couple of quick operational ones. Just, obviously, the STACK is -- emerged as a very competitive play. The overpressured window is becoming more delineated by yourself and peers. You've got some good maps, sort of showing how much acreage you have there. I mean, how much sort of in total of net acres would you have in that sort of overpressured window, however you wanted to define it roughly?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ed. Great question. This is Lance. I think, in general, we have -- from our organic leasing as well as our historical efforts in there, we have a large footprint in that. Within the -- what we view as the core of the Meramec, we see about 90% of our
componenttext: Sure, Ed. Great question. This is Lance. I think, in general, we have -- from our organic leasing as well as our historical efforts in there, we have a large footprint in that. Within the -- what we view as the core of the Meramec, we see about 90% of our core acreage is underneath or inside that window that's overpressured from that volatile oil window to down dip. So a substantial portion of ours is over pressured. Part of the reason we've been growing, developing the lease position is in that area, to focus on that overpressured, high-reservoir energy acreage.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just switching to the Eagle Ford. Obviously, you're talking -- you've mentioned in the first quarter results that you were seeing some encouraging results, and you gave us some data, 20% above on offset wells, some tighter cluster spacing. The --
componenttext: And then just switching to the Eagle Ford. Obviously, you're talking -- you've mentioned in the first quarter results that you were seeing some encouraging results, and you gave us some data, 20% above on offset wells, some tighter cluster spacing. The -- stage spacing. The -- any sort of update on EURs for those wells? And the completed well cost of $4.3 million also seems quite low. So maybe just talk a bit about how you managed to get down there?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ed. So starting with the EURs, I think the group of wells we released this quarter is really a follow-on to a group from the previous quarter. So we've seen consistently that tighter stage spacing, in some cases tighter cluster spacing is also drivin
componenttext: Yes, Ed. So starting with the EURs, I think the group of wells we released this quarter is really a follow-on to a group from the previous quarter. So we've seen consistently that tighter stage spacing, in some cases tighter cluster spacing is also driving well productivity. Most of that activity has been focused in the oil areas as we've looked to try to upgrade or improve the returns of our best acreage as well as lift some of our other acreage up to the highest year of returns. So we started on that, reflecting that, if you'll recall, about 60% of our future inventory is in that high GOR oil window. We've also had the opportunity now to move that stage spacing down into the condensate window. And although it's early, we're encouraged with the response from the wells. So you'll see us continue that. And I think what we'll find is as those wells mature, speaking out of the oil wells, over the next months and this year, we expect the EURs to rise. We haven't reflected that yet because the production history is just too immature. But on the consistent response for that, I think it's important to note that we've effectively moved that stage space into the basis of all our oil well completions and continuing to attest even down to 150-foot stage spacing today. And then on top of the capital, I mean I think the capital reflects, really, the focus in the team. They're continuing to drill the wells faster and be efficient and focus on that. They're continuing to stimulate the wells faster. We average more than 200 stages per month from our primary frac crew in the first quarter, which is the most efficient we've ever been with that equipment set. And so those efficiencies come right to the bottom line and are helping to drive those cost down, even as we spend more, invest more in the completions. And certainly, overall, I think -- I'd say that we're still getting a bit of commercial help. Most of these cost changes recently are driven -- focused by the efficiency drive within the team.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next question comes from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: I'd like to add my best wishes to Chris in retirement.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Evan.
componenttext: Thanks, Evan.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is on the asset monetizations. Your proceeds have already exceeded the high end of your guidance and still in motion. Any new guidance range here or maybe some color on how you arrived at the original guidance? And what drove the excess,
componenttext: My first question is on the asset monetizations. Your proceeds have already exceeded the high end of your guidance and still in motion. Any new guidance range here or maybe some color on how you arrived at the original guidance? And what drove the excess, whether it be risking on the program, more assets sold or better prices?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think, we've been, Evan, pretty consistent that noncore asset sales will just be part of what we do. It's part of our ongoing portfolio management with -- management strategy. As such, even though I think we have been successful in completing
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think, we've been, Evan, pretty consistent that noncore asset sales will just be part of what we do. It's part of our ongoing portfolio management with -- management strategy. As such, even though I think we have been successful in completing the sales against our published target, you should not deem that as us being finished or complete from a noncore asset standpoint. We're not putting out a new target. But certainly, the continued optimization of our portfolio is just part of what we want to be doing going forward. It's -- when we began that process, we had identified a population of noncore assets. Then we considered did they compete for capital allocation? Could they potentially have higher-value in someone else's portfolio? That population, even on a risk-adjusted basis, allowed us to have confidence in putting that target -- first target out there at $500 million. And then ultimately, increasing that target to the $750 million, $1 billion mark. So I think what we've seen is that for these quality assets, and a great example would be Wyoming, there is still a strong market out there that's willing to compete and pay very strong value for that type of asset. And again, it comes down to matching up very specific assets to very specific buyer pools. And I think that's what's created our success this year.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And maybe just the same question in a different way. The $1.3 billion sold, can you give me a percentage of what that was in your original guidance?
componenttext: That's great. And maybe just the same question in a different way. The $1.3 billion sold, can you give me a percentage of what that was in your original guidance?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well -- I mean, what I would say is that we identified well in excess of that original -- of that completed $1.3 billion. And so there is still room for continued portfolio optimization. For us, it will just be a focus on timing and how do we maximize val
componenttext: Well -- I mean, what I would say is that we identified well in excess of that original -- of that completed $1.3 billion. And so there is still room for continued portfolio optimization. For us, it will just be a focus on timing and how do we maximize value to the shareholder from those future transactions.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's fair. Let me ask my second question on the Eagle Ford. And you cite the ability to drill 97% within 20 feet. Maybe just some color on where that was a year ago? Or where you think the industry average is? I'm just -- how that relates to both
componenttext: Great. That's fair. Let me ask my second question on the Eagle Ford. And you cite the ability to drill 97% within 20 feet. Maybe just some color on where that was a year ago? Or where you think the industry average is? I'm just -- how that relates to both drilling speed and well performance as I'm trying to just trying to dimension the impact of that and where you think that may be going?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Evan. I think you wouldn't be surprised if we, again, articulated that, that target window has evolved over time to be a specific interval from a wider interval. And then there would be positive tension on the size of that target versus how fast you
componenttext: Sure, Evan. I think you wouldn't be surprised if we, again, articulated that, that target window has evolved over time to be a specific interval from a wider interval. And then there would be positive tension on the size of that target versus how fast you can actually drill a well. The team has gotten very consistent of being able to be focused in that target and still deliver the well at a very high efficiency within that. Part of that is repetition. They've had a lot of experience in the basin, a lot of practice, if you will. And so they've gotten very effective at it. And we've been consistently in the mid-90% in terms of landing a target over time. I think when we look at it is we made the target smaller over the last quarters and years, and they still been able to within that even as they increase the efficiency, which really speaks to the collaboration between the geosciences and the drilling engineering, that collaborative effort to work together to deliver those great results. If we expect to continue to be able to deliver those results consistently, even as the efficiency will still drive upwards.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So the -- so I guess both elements are targeted to change, both the percentage that relates more to time and I guess the size -- the tightness as it relates to all subsequent well performance?
componenttext: Right. So the -- so I guess both elements are targeted to change, both the percentage that relates more to time and I guess the size -- the tightness as it relates to all subsequent well performance?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, to some degree. But -- and also keep in mind, over the last 2 years, we've really pioneered the concept of a multi-horizon development in South Texas: the Austin Chalk, the Upper Eagle Ford and Lower Eagle Ford, and we're doing all of those. And that
componenttext: Yes, to some degree. But -- and also keep in mind, over the last 2 years, we've really pioneered the concept of a multi-horizon development in South Texas: the Austin Chalk, the Upper Eagle Ford and Lower Eagle Ford, and we're doing all of those. And that percentage reflects landing 3 different horizons drilled from the same pad in most cases, or in more than one of those horizon from every pad in almost every case. So the team's doing a really good job of targeting multi-horizon's very complex trajectories. I think it just demonstrates their efficacy overall.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Scott Hanold from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Scott Hanold from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, again, congrats. You'll probably hear that many times today.
componenttext: Chris, again, congrats. You'll probably hear that many times today.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott.
componenttext: Thank you, Scott.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can we go to STACK and SCOOP? And maybe specifically, what is your focus for 2016? Obviously, you've got some HBP work that needs to be done. But when you step back and look at your asset base, what is your focus? So for 2017, if prices improve and you pu
componenttext: Can we go to STACK and SCOOP? And maybe specifically, what is your focus for 2016? Obviously, you've got some HBP work that needs to be done. But when you step back and look at your asset base, what is your focus? So for 2017, if prices improve and you put some more capital at work, you can be more toward development or maybe even that's too soon for that?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, this is Lance. I think our focus this year, first and foremost, is that at lower activity to manage our capital spend, we're going to protect our valuable leasehold in SCOOP and STACK. And second to that, we're going to delineate the phase windows
componenttext: Scott, this is Lance. I think our focus this year, first and foremost, is that at lower activity to manage our capital spend, we're going to protect our valuable leasehold in SCOOP and STACK. And second to that, we're going to delineate the phase windows within those 2 basins. I think there's some key tertiary parameters we're also going to test that will be important for us this year. This year, we're going to go from 6 operated wells historically in all of the last 2 years in STACK to almost triple that, which will give us a much larger operated data set. Importantly, within that, over half of those wells are XLs, which gives us a chance to see the long lateral performance as well as some of the shorter laterals we've had historically, and those wells are very much positioned in the core of the play, the highest value part of the STACK to drive results. Similarly in the SCOOP, although we're not entirely held by production, we certainly have more flexibility this year. And so all of our wells will be longer laterals, 1.5 mile-plus laterals, and give us the chance to really test that value of that longer lateral. So I think those are all key objectives that we can accomplish this year even at lower activity.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay then. And then just to clarify too, is the plan preparing yourselves for -- I don't know if early '17's the right time frame to think about more development once you've figured it out? Or do we still have more time of delineating each HBP?
componenttext: Okay then. And then just to clarify too, is the plan preparing yourselves for -- I don't know if early '17's the right time frame to think about more development once you've figured it out? Or do we still have more time of delineating each HBP?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think I speaking of our operated acreage and we're certainly learning and preparing for full-scale development with those activities. But also, we continue to leverage the OBO activity that's material for us in Oklahoma, both in SCOOP and STACK. A
componenttext: Well, I think I speaking of our operated acreage and we're certainly learning and preparing for full-scale development with those activities. But also, we continue to leverage the OBO activity that's material for us in Oklahoma, both in SCOOP and STACK. And that gives us an opportunity this year to participate in some high density tests, some unique multi-horizon tests at scale. And so we're learning from those, and integrating that data, just as if we're operating it effectively. And so I think those things prepare us and help us get ready for that full-scale development and to outgrow the activity. I think, broadly speaking, in Oklahoma and in the rest of our resource play assets, we've taken this opportunity to work and high-grade our staff over the last year, but also retain capacity to respond to what Lee described. So as we see that constructive pricing and the opportunity to return to both, first, flatten and then sequential growth, we've got the core technical staff still in place to do that, doing special projects or other things in the interim so we're ready to respond to that, that need.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, that's good clarity. And if I could follow-up with -- the balance sheet looks -- it looks pretty strong right now with a lot of the work that you all have done. Can you speak to -- again, if I were to stick on this STACK and SCOOP, do you all
componenttext: Okay. Okay, that's good clarity. And if I could follow-up with -- the balance sheet looks -- it looks pretty strong right now with a lot of the work that you all have done. Can you speak to -- again, if I were to stick on this STACK and SCOOP, do you all think you've got the acreage position appropriate in size relative to Marathon that you need to make this a really core growth engine? Or should we expect you all could look at larger bolt-on opportunities? And if you could give some color for what the market's looking for M&A in there right now?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, yes. This is Lee. I think -- absolutely, we feel that Oklahoma is at a scale now where it can be a key growth engine for the future. We've talked about it in terms of 100,000 oil equivalent barrel per day producer for us in the future. Having said
componenttext: Right, yes. This is Lee. I think -- absolutely, we feel that Oklahoma is at a scale now where it can be a key growth engine for the future. We've talked about it in terms of 100,000 oil equivalent barrel per day producer for us in the future. Having said that, we continue to look for accretive opportunities to grow our core position there. Case in point, Scott, last year we added something around 12,000 acres in Blaine County, and we're going to continue to look for that type of opportunity to expand and more consolidate our position, particularly in the STACK area. We see it as -- as you look at not only our results as well as the industry results, what you can really say is that the vector is definitely up in the STACK in terms of the well performance, the cost reductions that are being achieved there. So all of that, for us, is really just validating our very early perspective on just the potential that the SCOOP and the STACK have.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Next question comes from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: From a big picture perspective, you talked in your last call about leverage versus liquidity, and as have been mentioned, you've done a few things here that have improved that leverage. But I wonder if you could speak to as maybe the thought has come abou
componenttext: From a big picture perspective, you talked in your last call about leverage versus liquidity, and as have been mentioned, you've done a few things here that have improved that leverage. But I wonder if you could speak to as maybe the thought has come about moving towards ramp-up mode at some point, $50 might be the number. What we should expect and how you would expect to target both leverage and spending within cash flow or outspending? And how that may change depending on the commodity environment or if it just doesn't change? Can you just talk about how we should see your strategy in potentially a higher oil price environment than the one that we're in right now?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. First, just maybe to reprise a bit, when we took the decision on the equity raise, that was a risk management decision that allowed us to derisk our business plans out through 2017. But probably more importantly, beyond strengthening our
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. First, just maybe to reprise a bit, when we took the decision on the equity raise, that was a risk management decision that allowed us to derisk our business plans out through 2017. But probably more importantly, beyond strengthening our balance sheet, it also provided us the optionality and the flexibility to be a bit more on the offense when we do see that constructive price signal. And we -- and we've kind of talked about the $50 or above number as being that signal. And it has to be a signal that also equally supported by the fundamentals of supply and demand. It needs to be something that we have confidence in. We know that we're going to be living with some near-term volatility. But we want to have confidence as we start deploying that first amount of incremental investment. So we are prepared. Everything we've been doing early this year, and actually toward the back end of last year, has been geared toward that ramp-up and activity that we can see a case for potentially in 2017. And to the extent that we do see that pricing signal, we're well prepared, and I think Lance said it well, that we've retained the internal competencies and capabilities that would allow us to get on a good, strong ramp-up in 2017 from an activity standpoint that would get us back very quickly into sequential growth mode.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the willingness to outspend cash flow to that is there, in part because of the proceeds that have come in?
componenttext: And the willingness to outspend cash flow to that is there, in part because of the proceeds that have come in?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, absolutely. I think that it's an independent decision early on, just how strongly we would want to go. I think right now, our 2016 objective is definitely living within cash flows, inclusive of noncore asset sales. I think as we look at 2017, the re
componenttext: Well, absolutely. I think that it's an independent decision early on, just how strongly we would want to go. I think right now, our 2016 objective is definitely living within cash flows, inclusive of noncore asset sales. I think as we look at 2017, the reason we've talked about that $50 number is we believe that growth can be achieved there while still living within our means, and that's been a controllable factor. Again, we have a desire to continue to maintain and strengthen our balance sheet over time. So 2017, again, we'd have very little appetite for outspending in that year. And we don't see that as a limiting factor.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up is with regards to the Eagle Ford and the well performance that you've seen in the high GOR area, the 20% outperformance. Can you talk to whether the production mix is the same as your expectations? And how when you layer in the combinati
componenttext: And my follow-up is with regards to the Eagle Ford and the well performance that you've seen in the high GOR area, the 20% outperformance. Can you talk to whether the production mix is the same as your expectations? And how when you layer in the combination of the high GOR area and condensate drilling, what we should expect for oiliness in the Eagle Ford going forward?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. I think if you look back over the last several quarters, our overall crude and condensate has drifted down a little bit. And I think that's been our focus of -- for the last several quarters we've been on, focused on value, and I think rightf
componenttext: Sure, Brian. I think if you look back over the last several quarters, our overall crude and condensate has drifted down a little bit. And I think that's been our focus of -- for the last several quarters we've been on, focused on value, and I think rightfully so in a challenged commodity market. And in many cases, that's been the very high pressure, high deliverability condensate wells. I think as we've lifted the returns and the performance of our oil wells set, which is the majority of our future inventory, we have an opportunity to shift that mix back toward the crude oil side a bit. I don't expect it to move very much either way in the future because we have such a large base. But I think as we've -- the first quarter's been more biased to the oil. We have some subsequent bias to that later in the year in general. We'll see it level out or perhaps trend a bit upward on the oil versus condensate side.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.
componenttext: The next question comes from Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a short-term question, and apologies if you've dealt with this as much as you want to. But could you talk a little bit more about the situation in Canada for us, Lee? And sorry, before you start, Chris, sorry, but congrats. And I'll be thinking of yo
componenttext: Just a short-term question, and apologies if you've dealt with this as much as you want to. But could you talk a little bit more about the situation in Canada for us, Lee? And sorry, before you start, Chris, sorry, but congrats. And I'll be thinking of you when the big soccer tournament happens this summer and we have England versus Wales. But more importantly, thank you for your help over the years. I'm sorry. Back to Canada, Lee.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul.
componenttext: Thank you, Paul.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Absolutely. Well, obviously, it's a very serious and dynamic situation right now, Paul. It's -- as we've gotten feedback, of course, from the operator, Shell, the current situation is that operations are suspended at both mines. And that's largely be
componenttext: Yes. Absolutely. Well, obviously, it's a very serious and dynamic situation right now, Paul. It's -- as we've gotten feedback, of course, from the operator, Shell, the current situation is that operations are suspended at both mines. And that's largely being done to allow folks to focus on rendering, a, to the community an emergency response, so very well justified. The mines themselves are not under any direct or immediate threat from the fires themselves. But precautions again are being taken, and it's being watched very closely. The upgrader is still operating on existing inventory, and we have a certain amount of -- a finite amount of inventory there that we can leverage during this outage. And really, we're just going to have to wait and see how the situation develops. But rightly so, all the focus right now is on the safety and well-being of the folks in the Fort McMurray community.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, totally understood. So the industry, obviously, is just turning its attention to the human crisis and -- got it. If I could ask you a strategic question, Lee, to totally change subject. You talked about -- and a lot of companies have talked about the
componenttext: Yes, totally understood. So the industry, obviously, is just turning its attention to the human crisis and -- got it. If I could ask you a strategic question, Lee, to totally change subject. You talked about -- and a lot of companies have talked about the flex in short cycle. You mentioned short cycle several times. Is there a scenario for long cycle here? At least if there is, what would it be for you? Would it be more Gulf of Mexico deep water, would it be toward something else? Would it be Canadian-heavy also?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. For us, Paul, it really starts with what are the risk-adjusted returns that we can generate? And we want our capital allocation, whether it be short cycle or long cycle, directed to those projects and opportunities that offer the highest
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. For us, Paul, it really starts with what are the risk-adjusted returns that we can generate? And we want our capital allocation, whether it be short cycle or long cycle, directed to those projects and opportunities that offer the highest risk-adjusted returns. We've been very clear, for instance, that we're transitioning out of the conventional exploration space, and that's being driven strictly by capital allocation. We simply did not see those opportunities competing in a relative sense within the very opportunity-rich portfolio that we have here in the U.S. resource plays. Now we still have accretive opportunities that are more mid-cycle and long cycle, for instance, the compression project that's ramping up in Equatorial Guinea. But I think as we continue to transition our portfolio, you should expect to see more and more of our capital allocation going toward our very kind of deep end, very economic U.S. resource play inventory.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's the impression I had. What do you think the risk is of that, if there is one? I mean, it seems, frankly, just simply to be the right thing to do.
componenttext: Yes, that's the impression I had. What do you think the risk is of that, if there is one? I mean, it seems, frankly, just simply to be the right thing to do.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think -- again, going back to that kind of -- the risk-adjusted return kind of question for me really kind of sets it. And when we look within our current portfolio and we see the deep inventory, the $3.6 billion of 2P resources that we have
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think -- again, going back to that kind of -- the risk-adjusted return kind of question for me really kind of sets it. And when we look within our current portfolio and we see the deep inventory, the $3.6 billion of 2P resources that we have access to, we feel very good about that. And to bring other opportunities in that portfolio, they have to compete within that space in a relative sense. So we feel very strongly that we're headed in the right direction. It's been a true transformational shift in our company since becoming an independent back in 2011. And we're very encouraged and excited about the progress that we've made.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If I could just round out. I guess, the risk is that everybody tries to grow at the same time. What can you do to mitigate costs? And I know I've asked 6 questions, so I'll leave it there.
componenttext: Yes. If I could just round out. I guess, the risk is that everybody tries to grow at the same time. What can you do to mitigate costs? And I know I've asked 6 questions, so I'll leave it there.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's okay. We'll give you an out today, Paul. It is a question -- when I think about the capacity and execution capacity question, I think of it really in 2 buckets, Paul. One is the internal capacity and competencies. And I think Lance and I have both
componenttext: That's okay. We'll give you an out today, Paul. It is a question -- when I think about the capacity and execution capacity question, I think of it really in 2 buckets, Paul. One is the internal capacity and competencies. And I think Lance and I have both addressed that. That we've been very thoughtful in our approach there to ensure that we preserve the internal capabilities and capacities needed to get back into growth mode when we do get that constructive pricing. And we've done that through redeployment to everything, from special projects to field leadership roles to displacement of contractors, so that we do retain those essential skill sets that will be required when we get back into a growth mode. Externally, it's a little bit more complicated, in that the service sector has been a bit decimated, at least on the labor side from this correction. I do think what will modulate some of that is just many companies will still be in either balance sheet repair or will just simply not have the cash flows or the wherewithal to get back on a very fast ramp. So I do think the ramp will be self-moderated in some ways once we get on it. But I think maintaining those strong relationships with our key service providers, which we have been able to do during the downturn, that's very important. And we're going to leverage those relationships when the kind of -- the bell rings again to get back into growth mode.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The following question comes from Guy Baber from Simmons.
componenttext: The following question comes from Guy Baber from Simmons.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congrats, Chris. Lee, you mentioned the objective to flatten declines at $50 and then eventually grow at that price. Can you give us some indications of the latest view with the productivity improvements you're realizing, the cost reductions you're seeing
componenttext: Congrats, Chris. Lee, you mentioned the objective to flatten declines at $50 and then eventually grow at that price. Can you give us some indications of the latest view with the productivity improvements you're realizing, the cost reductions you're seeing? How many rigs it would take or how much capital relative to current activity levels and CapEx to stabilize that unconventional production portfolio?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Guy. Let me maybe address it this way. When we talk about kind of getting to the maintenance capital and getting back on a growth mode, you really have to talk about it from a common starting point. Where are you starting that discussion? So if
componenttext: Yes, sure, Guy. Let me maybe address it this way. When we talk about kind of getting to the maintenance capital and getting back on a growth mode, you really have to talk about it from a common starting point. Where are you starting that discussion? So if I kind of fast-forward to the end of this year based on our current plan, and I look at where my resource plays will be exiting at the end of this year, and I think about what type of capital program will not only flatten, but will actually start growing sequentially in 2017. Based on what we know today, and again, this is not a budget outlook, we would probably place that capital program in the resource plays in the $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion. And again, that's not just getting us back to flat. That's actually starting sequential growth again in 2017. So that's kind of a ballpark number. It's one that I think will continue to improve as we -- I mean, Lance did a great job describing some of the secular efficiencies that we're already creating in the business. The Eagle Ford is a great example of that because we're operating at scale there. And as we take those efficiencies forward, we expect that, that number will even have some downward and constructive pressure on it.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great detail. And then I wanted to discuss -- we haven't talked about the Bakken much today. But I wanted to discuss the resilience of your production there. I'm struck by the fact that production is effectively flat year-over-year and quarter-over
componenttext: That's great detail. And then I wanted to discuss -- we haven't talked about the Bakken much today. But I wanted to discuss the resilience of your production there. I'm struck by the fact that production is effectively flat year-over-year and quarter-over-quarter despite the meaningful activity reductions. So can you update us on the strength you're seeing in your production rates there? What's your learning in terms of decline rates? And really just update us on the outlook and kind of on what's driven some of that unforeseen strength, at least on our part.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Guy. This is Lance, I'm happy to address that. I'm pleased that you've noticed that actually. The Bakken seems to have done a really effective job of managing that production base over the last year at lower and lower activity. One of the key things
componenttext: Sure, Guy. This is Lance, I'm happy to address that. I'm pleased that you've noticed that actually. The Bakken seems to have done a really effective job of managing that production base over the last year at lower and lower activity. One of the key things is, is we had lower activity and they've been very focused on the base business. The production efficiency or uptime is really rising. And that's been a focus of theirs, and not just the last year, but the last couple of years, and they've really improved there. And I think probably more important than that in driving that flattening decline profile you see is that we've made a material shift in our completion practices over the last 1.5 years. And the wells from 2015 are among the best we've ever developed and put online. And the declines from those continue to flattened, and so that group is a big part of driving that flatter profile. So those completion practices with more fluid volume, higher density proppant loading, more stages, have all been beneficial, and we continue that. I think we're -- I've certainly said today, at lower activity, we have less opportunity to demonstrate that. But we look forward to the future. There's enormous commodity price leverage in the Bakken, and when we get back to activity there, we expect to be able to deliver even better wells in the future than we have in the past, just building on that. And I think we even look forward to say in the second quarter earnings and being able to talk about the results from the Clark's Creek pad in West Myrmidon, where we'll have pumped our -- what we view is our most sophisticated, most aggressive stimulations to date in the Bakken, and we expect those results to be compelling.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pavel from Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pavel from Raymond James.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one for me, and this goes back to the labor issue that was discussed a little bit earlier. Given the headcount reductions that you've had internally, and of course, your contractors as well, is there a rig count number, or analogously, a CapEx number
componenttext: Just one for me, and this goes back to the labor issue that was discussed a little bit earlier. Given the headcount reductions that you've had internally, and of course, your contractors as well, is there a rig count number, or analogously, a CapEx number of that you can say is kind of the peak that you guys could achieve before running into labor availability issues?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The way, I guess, I would address that is going back to my earlier comments about what 2017 might look like in a more constructive environment as we get back on a flat and even a sequential increase or growth in the U.S. resource plays. We're sitting
componenttext: Yes. The way, I guess, I would address that is going back to my earlier comments about what 2017 might look like in a more constructive environment as we get back on a flat and even a sequential increase or growth in the U.S. resource plays. We're sitting today at right around 7 rigs across all the resource plays. We've got 5 rigs running in the Eagle Ford, 2 rigs running in Oklahoma. As we think about that kind of notional budget out in 2017 in the resource plays, that $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion we talked about, that's -- that type of spend in 2017 would likely see us ramping into a rig activity that would probably be close to double of where we are today. And so we absolutely have the capacity internally, and we feel that the vendor and service community could support it as well. That if that scenario did in fact play out, and again, this is not a 2017 budget discussion, but if that scenario did play out, we would comfortably be able to ramp into that level of activity.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So just to clarify, twice your current rig count is the -- what can be realistically achieved, right, without labor pressures?
componenttext: Okay. So just to clarify, twice your current rig count is the -- what can be realistically achieved, right, without labor pressures?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think what we're saying is as we look at a reasonable plan under a constructive pricing scenario, that's a type of ramp-up that we think would be supportable with all the other constraints that we may have around cash flows, et cetera. And so yes,
componenttext: Yes. I think what we're saying is as we look at a reasonable plan under a constructive pricing scenario, that's a type of ramp-up that we think would be supportable with all the other constraints that we may have around cash flows, et cetera. And so yes, we would be very comfortable. I wouldn't want to portray that as a peak that we think we would get to. We just think that's just a realistic scenario to think about.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: And our final question comes from Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just an update on hedging, if you could.
componenttext: Just an update on hedging, if you could.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is J.R. You've probably seen from the materials that we put out last night that we have increased our hedge book. I think we've done that, really for the purpose of protecting at least some level of our cash flows that in turn supports the bala
componenttext: Paul, this is J.R. You've probably seen from the materials that we put out last night that we have increased our hedge book. I think we've done that, really for the purpose of protecting at least some level of our cash flows that in turn supports the balance sheet. When I look at the second half of 2016, we've got now positions in the aggregate of about -- a little bit less than 60,000 barrels a day of crude production. Those are done through either straight two-way collars or through three-ways. And when I look at kind of an average floor price, it's around, call it, $49 to $50 average floor price with a sold put on the bottom of that, of right around $40. So it gives us -- it does put, again, I think a floor underneath, at least a portion of our production, just to give us insurance with regard from a cash flow standpoint. Really nothing at this point in time beyond the 2016 time frame, Paul.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: What -- has the strategy changed? And what -- just remind us what the strategy is. I mean, how much do you want to be hedged? And where are we in that?
componenttext: What -- has the strategy changed? And what -- just remind us what the strategy is. I mean, how much do you want to be hedged? And where are we in that?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't have anything hard and fast, Paul. But I would tell you anything north of, say, half of our crude production we would likely not do at least at this point in time. And so again, what we're trying to is at least put some level of support under the
componenttext: We don't have anything hard and fast, Paul. But I would tell you anything north of, say, half of our crude production we would likely not do at least at this point in time. And so again, what we're trying to is at least put some level of support under the cash flows but still allow our shareholders an opportunity to participate in as much of that upside as possible, hence the use of the collars in the throughput.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Guy Baber from Simmons.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry to reprompt here, guys. But J.R., I wanted to get a comment on the cash flow during the quarter. It was a little bit light versus what we had modeled, granted the environment, obviously, exceptionally challenging. But was there anything nonratable t
componenttext: Sorry to reprompt here, guys. But J.R., I wanted to get a comment on the cash flow during the quarter. It was a little bit light versus what we had modeled, granted the environment, obviously, exceptionally challenging. But was there anything nonratable that you might highlight as we think about the outlook for cash flow generation this year?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, Guy. I'm actually kind of glad you asked. I've seen the brief write-ups earlier this morning. And needless to say, Chris and Zach had been responding to a lot of questions from folks. And to be honest, first and foremost, I think you were somewh
componenttext: Yes. Yes, Guy. I'm actually kind of glad you asked. I've seen the brief write-ups earlier this morning. And needless to say, Chris and Zach had been responding to a lot of questions from folks. And to be honest, first and foremost, I think you were somewhat alluding to, it's really predominantly driven by the macro conditions in the first quarter being the substantial reduction and realized prices on a fee-and-fee basis, about 25%, and of course, the volumetric implications as well. But when I then kind of just look at the -- more of the micro granular level, there is an item to use the vernacular of some of the reports this morning, the amount of the deferred taxes in the first quarter, or the deferred tax benefit in the first quarter, might have been lower as compared to what many people were assuming it to be. And it's really -- unfortunately, it's really just the methodology we are using for interperiod tax allocation. So how we allocate taxes we anticipate for the full year, how we allocate them on a quarterly basis. And honestly, that, coupled with a couple other nonrecurring items, likely accounts for close to $0.07 or $0.08 per share on a cash flow basis. And so I think -- unfortunately, when you're always looking at working cash flow before working capital, you're going to get some anomalies there. We always try, of course. We're managing total cash flow, and look at it on an after-working capital basis. And when I do that, we did have an additional anomaly in there. We had some nonqualified pension payments that we paid in the first quarter that relates to our late 2015 workforce reduction. And as every company has in the first quarter, we also had the prior years' incentive compensation payment. And so all of those items actually add together to get us back another, as I said, $0.07 to $0.08 in the aggregate to cash flow per share.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sylvia. Thank you for the kind words at the end of your opening remarks, Lee. I have very much enjoyed interacting with the Street analysts and investors over the last 8 years, and of course, all of my work colleagues over the last 30-plus year
componenttext:
Thank you, Sylvia. Thank you for the kind words at the end of your opening remarks, Lee. I have very much enjoyed interacting with the Street analysts and investors over the last 8 years, and of course, all of my work colleagues over the last 30-plus years at Marathon Oil. I look forward to following the progress of the company as an investor in my retirement. 
With that said, I'd like to thank everyone again for their participation this morning. This final statement, I will particularly enjoy. Please contact Zach Dailey if you have any follow-up questions. 
Sylvia, thank you. This concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.

componenttext:
Welcome to the Marathon Oil Corporation 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Hilda, and I will be the operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.
I will now like to turn the call over to Mr. Zach Dailey. Mr. Dailey, you may begin.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Hilda, and good morning to everyone. Welcome to Marathon Oil second quarter earnings call. Joining me on the call this morning are Lee Tillman, President and CEO; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO; Lance Robertson, Vice President, Resour
componenttext:
Thanks, Hilda, and good morning to everyone. Welcome to Marathon Oil second quarter earnings call. Joining me on the call this morning are Lee Tillman, President and CEO; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO; Lance Robertson, Vice President, Resource Plays; Mitch Little, Vice President, Conventional. As a reminder, today's call may contain forward-looking statements subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. Please read our disclosures in our earnings release and in our SEC filings for a discussion of these items. Reconciliations of any non-GAAP financial measures we discuss can be found in the quarterly information package on our website.
with that, I'll turn the call over to Lee.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Zack, and good morning to everyone. I'll make a few brief comments and open the call for questions. Our second quarter headlines. Strong well results, continued cost reduction, successful portfolio management.Our Oklahoma Asset team delivered
componenttext:
Thank you, Zack, and good morning to everyone. I'll make a few brief comments and open the call for questions. Our second quarter headlines. Strong well results, continued cost reduction, successful portfolio management.
Our Oklahoma Asset team delivered 2 outstanding STACK Merrimac wells with oil cuts above 70%, while continuing to balance leased whole demands with acreage delineation. This same team also closed our Payrock acquisition on Monday, just 6 weeks after announcing the deal, and are rapidly integrating that asset into our Oklahoma business. The team actually had a countdown calendar in the office as they marched towards the accelerated close date. Needless to say, they're excited and they're focused efforts will ensure no loss of momentum.
We had an exceptional quarter in the Bakken, delivering a record well on our West Myrmidon acreage through a combination of great reservoir quality and enhanced completion design. The Bakken as a team is really embraced this time of lower activity to prepare for what's next. They dropped their production cost materially and upped their game on well returns to place West Myrmidon in the mix for 2017 capital allocation.
The Eagle Ford continued seeing uplift from tighter state spacing, while feeling the effects of a planned step down in activity and challenging base production declines. And despite their move to higher intensity completions, their completed well costs are down significantly year-over-year.
Winning the production cost battle is hard work and typically measured in numerous but smaller victories. Rest assure that cost management remains front and center with all of our asset teams.
North America E&P production costs are down almost 30% from a year ago, and we dropped their full year guidance by $1 per oil equivalent barrel. We've also reduced 2016 unit production expense guidance for international by $0.50 per oil the equivalent barrel.
Through a combination of capital discipline and efficiency gains across all of our businesses, we'll deliver a 2016 capital program that's $100 million below our original budget. All while funding the incremental 2016 activity associated with our STACK acquisition, including the additional rig we'll add there this quarter.
Oklahoma is getting busy, with the acquisition, we will be doubling our activity in the STACK to 4 rigs in total.
Not to be outdone by a North America success in our international business, we achieved first gas from the B3 compression project in EG in July, on schedule and within budget. The project is fulfilling its mission to extend the Alba Field's production plateau by 2 years and the assets life out 2013. As our capital investment and compression project walls of the EG will contribute significant free cash flow that we can reinvest in our deep inventory of a high return opportunities here in the U.S. resource plays.
On the portfolio management side. Our noncore asset sales program has now achieved over $1 billion year-to-date. And though exceeded our additional target, we aren't done. Expect noncore asset sales to be ongoing as we continue optimizing our capital allocation to the lowest cost, highest margin opportunities.
On the other side of portfolio management, the 61,000 net acres we acquired in the STACK Merrimac oil window ticks all the boxes, quality, scale, value and with further upside not assumed in the purchase price. Through this volatile and commodity price environment, we've been resolute in executing against our playbook. Strengthening our balance sheet, resetting our cost structure, simplifying our portfolio. All with the goal of profitable growth within cash flows when sustainably higher prices give us the confidence to ramp activity. With that, I'll hand it back to Zach to begin the Q&A.

componenttextpreview: Yes, Ed, we're still committed to that, Ed. As we look out at the macro today, though, we're sitting at 40 today, but as we look out the 2017 and see that more constructive pricing, we feel very confident in our ability to begin that growth sequentially a
componenttext: Yes, Ed, we're still committed to that, Ed. As we look out at the macro today, though, we're sitting at 40 today, but as we look out the 2017 and see that more constructive pricing, we feel very confident in our ability to begin that growth sequentially again, and do it within cash flows in that low to mid-50s kind of price range. A lot of that will also hinge on our ability to ensure that we have operational momentum coming out of 2016 as well.

componenttext: We talked about, nominally, kind of a $1.4 billion program in 2017 that would get us back on that sequential growth track within the resource play. And within that is the way I would ask you to think about it, Ed, is embedded basically almost doubling of the rig count from where we are today to when we with exit in 2017. And that would support both that capital program as well as that volumes profile.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ed. This is JR. As we talked on previous calls, even though we're focused here on ultimately being able to get that capital program up to a level to where we can resume the growth path, the balance sheet is still going to be important. I think we've got s
componenttext: Ed. This is JR. As we talked on previous calls, even though we're focused here on ultimately being able to get that capital program up to a level to where we can resume the growth path, the balance sheet is still going to be important. I think we've got so maturities coming up year in October of '17 and again in March of '18. Sitting here today, it would appear to be the right allocation of capital might just be to wait to be able to pay off those maturities when their due. And that's one reason why we're maintaining the cash balance that we are today to give us that option, but we'll continue to look at other opportunities to be able to reduce [indiscernible] right now, we're leaning towards just repaying those maturities when they're due.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So guys, as things post your acquisition in the STACK, obviously, there's a lot of tension going on there. Can you please give us some ideas on how you would prioritize incremental rig additions in the event the commodity does continue to recover next yea
componenttext: So guys, as things post your acquisition in the STACK, obviously, there's a lot of tension going on there. Can you please give us some ideas on how you would prioritize incremental rig additions in the event the commodity does continue to recover next year?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug. Oklahoma STACK is going to be our absolute first priority, Doug. Once we've met our leasehold requirements and our strategic objectives in the STACK, then we're going to look at optimizing across the remaining basins to maximize economic return
componenttext: Yes, Doug. Oklahoma STACK is going to be our absolute first priority, Doug. Once we've met our leasehold requirements and our strategic objectives in the STACK, then we're going to look at optimizing across the remaining basins to maximize economic return. I think the good news there for us is that when we look at that multi-base and optimization, we've got a very competitive and diverse Tier 1 inventory that really now features everything from Eagle Ford oil and condensate to Bakken West Myrmidon to SCOOP. So it's a great portfolio, but that first incremental capital is absolutely going to Oklahoma STACK. In fact, as we stated in our released material last evening, we'll be looking to add that second rig into the STACK acquisition acreage later in the third quarter, bringing us to a total of 4 rigs in Oklahoma.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up, obviously, the STACK's are filling meaningful change in your inventory, Lee. But what -- what would you characterize your comfort level are your satisfaction, I guess a better way of putting it with your acreage position up there? But you,
componenttext: As a follow-up, obviously, the STACK's are filling meaningful change in your inventory, Lee. But what -- what would you characterize your comfort level are your satisfaction, I guess a better way of putting it with your acreage position up there? But you, obviously, relative to some of your other peers, relatively small footprint. Do you see other additions in the future? Or we'll see characterization of the available acreage as we do there?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, though, I certainly wouldn't -- I'm very happy with our footprint and the STACK as well as SCOOP certainly, with a bolt-on of the STACK acquisition, the pay rock acquisition, it enhance our position materially in the STACK. But as I look across it fr
componenttext: Yes, though, I certainly wouldn't -- I'm very happy with our footprint and the STACK as well as SCOOP certainly, with a bolt-on of the STACK acquisition, the pay rock acquisition, it enhance our position materially in the STACK. But as I look across it from a overall lease or standpoint and you think about the fact that we now have in excess of about $1 billion 2P resources in the STACK as well as another $1 billion or so in the SCOOP, that is a very material position going forward in Oklahoma. And just over a couple hundred thousand surface acres, net surface acres in the STACK, we feel very good about our position. We've never -- we would never forgo accretive small bolt-on positions or greenfield leasing, but we're quite pleased with where we stand right now in Oklahoma.

componenttext: Let me maybe tick that one off and out there and over to plans to provide a little bit more collar. But we just closed on STACK, on the STACK acquisition, on Monday and took over operations on Monday. Integration is a work in king progress as a team as well at last. As we mentioned, we're going to be putting a second rig to their work there. The 2 rigs are going to be initially focused on protecting that valuable leasehold, but also looking forward continuing strategic, I'll say, divination and around the play as well. But in terms of economics and where of those wells fall in our set of opportunities, there's no doubt that the STACK o  opportunity compete at the very top of our Tier 1 inventory. And that's even been confirmed yet again with a 3 additional wells that have been brought to sales by -- within the acquisition between up to close. And so maybe I'll just let Lance fill in a few more details on just how the integration is going.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Lee. We took over operations on Monday, it's been very seamless today. Obviously, we looked at the acquired acres, they're on the oil [indiscernible] side. We think it balances the portfolio across the breadth of the STACK basin very nicely
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Lee. We took over operations on Monday, it's been very seamless today. Obviously, we looked at the acquired acres, they're on the oil [indiscernible] side. We think it balances the portfolio across the breadth of the STACK basin very nicely for us. We're going to have the ongoing obligations there to defend position in our heritage marathon acreage in STACK as well is ongoing in the acquired acres. We do have a bit of excess capacity there. I think one of the things that you would recognize in our activities to date. So for example in the reports we reported this quarter, we've been transitioning to XL wells in our overpressured area to look at the value there, those we'll results have been very compelling and we're very excited about those. We also purchased this acquisition on the oil buy-side based on the fact that they among the very best productivity on a lateral adjusted foot basis with a very low capital costs, which together, create a great value opportunity for us, and so we're going to continue on that basis. I think we also recognize the opportunity with about half acreage in the acquired package suitable for XL that we're going to moved also test the XL in that area to see what the best long-term results for Marathon is.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: And how much of your acreage across the entire acquired acreage [indiscernible] entire STACK portfolio, can you see the long laterals?
