headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Simmons.
componenttext: We have a question from Simmons.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just trying to understand the financial and operational framework you set out here for '17. And so a follow up there. But I believe you mentioned the early view, is it about $1.4 billion in spending or so next year would be sufficient to return the co
componenttext: I'm just trying to understand the financial and operational framework you set out here for '17. And so a follow up there. But I believe you mentioned the early view, is it about $1.4 billion in spending or so next year would be sufficient to return the company to sequential growth assuming oil in the mid- to low 50s? I believe you also mentioned the desire to live within cash flow. So is $1.4 billion plus your dividend about the type of cash flow you expect to generate next year, low to mid-50 world? Or are you incorporating some asset sales proceeds into your forecast to support that as well?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, guy, thanks for the follow-up question. First of all, I want to be very clear. The $1.4 billion I'm talking about, Guy, is for the resource play element only, that would not include other capital requirements and the conventional elements of our busi
componenttext: Yes, guy, thanks for the follow-up question. First of all, I want to be very clear. The $1.4 billion I'm talking about, Guy, is for the resource play element only, that would not include other capital requirements and the conventional elements of our business. Although we would expect similar to what we did this year that the bulk of our capital investment in 2017 will in fact be allocated to the resource play. But in that low 50 to mid-50 window, we would absolutely expect to cover that capital demand within operating cash flows. Does not mean we're not still pursuing noncore asset divestitures, but we're certainly not saying we're going to be reliant upon those. They give us optionality, but we don't feel that we need to rely on those if we're in that price band.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's very helpful. And then my follow-up is, understanding 2017 is something of a transitional year for you during what you tend to return to the company back to sequential growth. But once you get a better commodity price environment, you've imp
componenttext: Great. That's very helpful. And then my follow-up is, understanding 2017 is something of a transitional year for you during what you tend to return to the company back to sequential growth. But once you get a better commodity price environment, you've improved the well results, the operational performance I think, significantly. You also made meaningful improvements of the portfolio and your opportunity set. When the time comes, what type of growth rate do you think Marathon is poised to fundamentally deliver longer-term? I'm just trying to understand kind of that framework for longer-term growth.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, absolutely. Yes, I think first and foremost, you said it well. We've got this great opportunity set that very much competes for capital in the price band. A lot of that, I would say, growth aspiration, though, will be highly dependent upon the pr
componenttext: Yes. No, absolutely. Yes, I think first and foremost, you said it well. We've got this great opportunity set that very much competes for capital in the price band. A lot of that, I would say, growth aspiration, though, will be highly dependent upon the pricing that we see. Being a very oil levered company, of course, we have a very strong response in operating cash flows as we see improvements to the oil price. So to the extent that we need to modulate between growth as well as generating free cash flows, we're prepared to do that. But the potential that we've got in the 3 resource play definitely provides as an avenue for moving to a very competitive growth metric in the future. Without getting into specifics there, we have that potential.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We have a question from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question. Your Merrimack, your legacy were also performing better than your tight curve. How large of a well sample production is you need to raise your resource estimate? I guess, the same question applies to Eagle Ford with the 200 [indiscernib
componenttext: My first question. Your Merrimack, your legacy were also performing better than your tight curve. How large of a well sample production is you need to raise your resource estimate? I guess, the same question applies to Eagle Ford with the 200 [indiscernible] spacing and Bakken wells with larger completion. Another -- the last time you looked at your resource estimate was September. How are you guys thinking about that?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Evan. This is Lance. So I'll start kind of in the order you asked them, perhaps. But overall, it's clearly early in the STACK still. We're delineating the whole acreage, us and peers. Those wells were reported this quarter, the [indiscernible] in al
componenttext: Sure, Evan. This is Lance. So I'll start kind of in the order you asked them, perhaps. But overall, it's clearly early in the STACK still. We're delineating the whole acreage, us and peers. Those wells were reported this quarter, the [indiscernible] in all of June are excellent well results Their excellent wells are performing about tight curve. They're also only about 40 or 50 days into their total production, so I think we're going to let those run a while. I think we're excited there above that curb and so there's certainly an opportunity for resource upward. We also have, as you might recall, a number of other XL wells in the third quarter and fourth quarter in that same Blaine County area from that heritage we're here to talk about. So when get the breadth of those and they've matured a bit, it'd be a more appropriate time for that. And turning to the Bakken, I think the well results we reported there are really remarkable this quarter. All off in the same pad. That 3 best -- among the 3 best wells put in the basin in the last 3 years, that really demonstrates what technology application, the right landings on the right combination is -- we have inventory like that. Similarly, we like to see those material, but there other wells in that areas, they also perform well, which is why we were aggressive in that area, I think we need to let those mature, but I just eco-sourced upgrade there driven by that. Lastly, Eagle Ford, we continue to be really pleased with the results of tighter staged basin, particularly in the oil areas in the upper and lower Eagle Ford, responding very well. We've got the breath of wells there now. Almost 75 wells in that group, so it's maturing, which gives us more confidence. And I think we recognize there will be a need to do a resource update in the not-too-distant future.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. If I could follow-up in the Eagle Ford. I know you got spaced. And you also assumptions and say or acre spacing. I mean, could you walk us through what drove that change? And is because you're getting well interference in the 40-acre spaci
componenttext: That's helpful. If I could follow-up in the Eagle Ford. I know you got spaced. And you also assumptions and say or acre spacing. I mean, could you walk us through what drove that change? And is because you're getting well interference in the 40-acre spacing? I guess you're planning on draining the Austin Chalk with your Upper Eagle Ford laterals?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan. So I think we went last year from sort of unconstrained Austin Chalk, very quickly to 40-acre spacing in the Austin Chalk, to try to find a vase of productivity of that Reservoir. And what you we over the last few quarters is that 40-acre spaci
componenttext: Yes, Evan. So I think we went last year from sort of unconstrained Austin Chalk, very quickly to 40-acre spacing in the Austin Chalk, to try to find a vase of productivity of that Reservoir. And what you we over the last few quarters is that 40-acre spacing when we had groups, our first groups of Austin Chalk wells that are constrained. The reservoir quality very high, it's got natural fracturing, which we suspected but once certain of and those wells are communicating laterally a bit. And then overall, we're going to get the best capital efficiency in the Austin Chalk at wider spacing. In that same time frame, we've also been testing the Upper Eagle Ford, really double the amount of our delineated acreage over that time in the Upper Eagle Ford. And recognize that it can -- we can backfill some of those Austin Chalk locations with Upper Eagle Ford but both at wider space and they just interact better. Ultimately, we're looking provides recovery of hydrocarbon out of that unit at the lowest capital input so we try to optimize the returns at the drilling unit level.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is the reasonable oil price, we should go back to grow 40-acre downspacing, or how does the interplay work?
componenttext: Is the reasonable oil price, we should go back to grow 40-acre downspacing, or how does the interplay work?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: I think yet to take of the on price. [indiscernible] reflected. We started this density testing north of $28 a barrel, it probably looks different at $40. So the higher commodity price, I think the more you'd want to look at that ultimate density, because that just drives the returns from that unit. We think where we are today, while e're making these adjustments as appropriate for today's commodity market.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We have a question from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up on CapEx, $1.4 billion. You clarified on the earlier question that this is for the key resource areas. And I just wanted to put that into context to make sure the base is right. Is this essentially about a $375 million spent for thos
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up on CapEx, $1.4 billion. You clarified on the earlier question that this is for the key resource areas. And I just wanted to put that into context to make sure the base is right. Is this essentially about a $375 million spent for those resource plays in the first half of the year? And then can you talk about that trajectory for how your thinking about the rest of the company? I think, if we look at these on a cash flow statement that perspective, you spent about $800 million overall for the company in the first half.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Certainly, in the first half of the year, Brian, there was a bit of a bias because we had a couple of long cycle projects running their course that are now, of course, both started up, which are the EG compression project as well as the nonoperated G
componenttext: Yes. Certainly, in the first half of the year, Brian, there was a bit of a bias because we had a couple of long cycle projects running their course that are now, of course, both started up, which are the EG compression project as well as the nonoperated Gun Flint project. So there was probably bit more biased to the conventional portfolio in the first half of the year. As we look forward to the second half of the year, that's going to largely be faced by the resource plays themselves. And that would really set that, I'll say, kind of that exit velocity that we achieved from a capital program standpoint as we move out of the year. We do anticipate based on the activity we described, including  an additional rake in Oklahoma as well as some additional completion work in the Eagle Ford, that to be will exit the fourth quarter with some pretty strong momentum going into 2017. To your point, I guess, on the rest of the portfolio, looking forward to 2017, you should expect us to continue to minimize the capital allocation to the conventional program, very similar to what we endeavored to do this cycle in 2016.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that is a little bit of a follow-up for more of a strategic perspective which is given your interest in the returns you're seeing from the resource play portfolio, how typically are you thinking about the assets elsewhere? Do anticipate additional ass
componenttext: And that is a little bit of a follow-up for more of a strategic perspective which is given your interest in the returns you're seeing from the resource play portfolio, how typically are you thinking about the assets elsewhere? Do anticipate additional asset sales? Or as you perhaps just described, minimum levels of capital investment to try to use these assets for the free cash flow to offset spending going off the resource plays.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, our conventional business is absolutely geared toward generating free cash flow that can then be redeployed. That's the model, that's what drives the team forward. I will look at some selective investments there. A great example is the EG compressi
componenttext: Brian, our conventional business is absolutely geared toward generating free cash flow that can then be redeployed. That's the model, that's what drives the team forward. I will look at some selective investments there. A great example is the EG compression project. I'll be at a long cycle projects it's very exceeded, it's delivering very strong economics and performance in the portfolio. And it's simply going to add to the ability of equatorial grenade to add to our cash flows. I think a separate question, though, is more of the noncore assets question. We continue to scrutinize our portfolio and ensure that it is fully optimized. As I said in my opening remarks, we've achieved $1 billion year-to-date of noncore asset divestitures, but we believe there is more work to be done there. We don't think very will be through the scale of, say, Wyoming, but we still believe there's some good solid portfolio. We're particularly here in North America that we continue to drive. And again, it's all focused on the simplification and concentration of the portfolio toward the highest risk-adjusted returns.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Paul Sankey of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: We have a question from Paul Sankey of Wolfe Research.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A high level question, if I could. I see that you're basically turning the company at about a $50 outlook. How would things change if we start assuming $40 or $60 in your mind. And I know you're a little bit reluctant, probably to commit to this levels of
componenttext: A high level question, if I could. I see that you're basically turning the company at about a $50 outlook. How would things change if we start assuming $40 or $60 in your mind. And I know you're a little bit reluctant, probably to commit to this levels of prices, which you start to think about past growth and stuff, but I'm trying to pin you down on it.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, I appreciate your transparency. I'll maybe take those 2 bookends that you just talked about, the 40 and the 60. Obviously, I think it's 40, similar to what we've experienced this year, would be looking to protect our balance sheet to ensure that the
componenttext: Paul, I appreciate your transparency. I'll maybe take those 2 bookends that you just talked about, the 40 and the 60. Obviously, I think it's 40, similar to what we've experienced this year, would be looking to protect our balance sheet to ensure that the we continue to drive lease hold and strategic objectives in the portfolio. And then look with great discipline at some of those discretionary economic opportunities within the portfolio. We'd still be bearing down on cost. We'd still be bearing down on noncore asset sales. So those, with the behaviors and the objectives, if we saw an environment moving into '17, that is more in the 4 handle range. I think conversely, if we see more constructive pricing moving into '17, that $60 as we talked about, a $10 move in pricing for us is a big impact on our operating cash flows, and we'd be looking to redeploy those pretty strongly back here into the U.S. resource plays to not only get back on sequential growth, but get back on that growth quite strongly if we saw that level of price support. We protected the organization in such a way that we have the capacity to move to much higher activity levels. And if we saw that $60, we'd move toward that as quickly as we could.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's interesting. So on the dividend, is that still something that you aspire to return to be relatively be a high dividend payer? Or do you see shifting as to more of a commercial growth story?
componenttext: That's interesting. So on the dividend, is that still something that you aspire to return to be relatively be a high dividend payer? Or do you see shifting as to more of a commercial growth story?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think as you look at our portfolio, Paul, you look at our business model, we have made the shift. We may the shift in the dividend last year. Of course, it was helpful from an operating cash flow standpoint. But it was also much more consistent with whe
componenttext: I think as you look at our portfolio, Paul, you look at our business model, we have made the shift. We may the shift in the dividend last year. Of course, it was helpful from an operating cash flow standpoint. But it was also much more consistent with where we were headed in this very short cycle investment resource play intensive business that we're in. And We think from a competitive standpoint, given our opportunity outlook for growth and reinvestment, that's the right place for us to place our shareholder money.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. If I could just try 1 to Lance. Lance, you've seen something very interesting here which is the -- obviously, we've seen a significant improvement in cost performance, really across the industry at lower prices. But what's also interesting is, I gu
componenttext: Great. If I could just try 1 to Lance. Lance, you've seen something very interesting here which is the -- obviously, we've seen a significant improvement in cost performance, really across the industry at lower prices. But what's also interesting is, I guess, the technical improvements are still being achieved even though activity is so much lower. If we go back to higher prices, do you think technical improvements would accelerate? Or would they actually deteriorate because we'd be going into presumably less high-quality acreage.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul. I think that's an insightful question. I think what we would focus on at today's activity, which we or higher activity in the future would be in our Tier 1 inventory. As we've taken those technical advances and lifted up the returns of some of
componenttext: Yes, Paul. I think that's an insightful question. I think what we would focus on at today's activity, which we or higher activity in the future would be in our Tier 1 inventory. As we've taken those technical advances and lifted up the returns of some of our portfolio, we have such a breath of it now that we're going to focus within that Tier 1 first but we'll take a portion of our activity to try to test some Tier 2 and lift it up to meet that thing. We need to stay disciplined in any price environment to make sure we're bringing our best opportunities forward, but also take into view that we're going to bet on technology, we're going to bet on the innovation and the creativity of our people to bring our portfolio of the accretive the over that time.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I ask a follow-up? You've said you've retained -- you haven't the structured people? Or have you retained your ability that both of you mentioned?
componenttext: Can I ask a follow-up? You've said you've retained -- you haven't the structured people? Or have you retained your ability that both of you mentioned?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. As we spun the activity, we recognize that we have a of early career talented people, and we don't necessarily have the direct activity department. So we've taken them at to special projects across the company, they're out doing site supervisio
componenttext: Yes, sure. As we spun the activity, we recognize that we have a of early career talented people, and we don't necessarily have the direct activity department. So we've taken them at to special projects across the company, they're out doing site supervision work on rigs and frac crews, productions supervisors. So we are retaining them in very variable functions, maturing their leadership and their technical skills and their business acumen. And then as we go activity, we can recall them into other kind of a petrol technical focus roles, and they're going to be even better to take those on. So the early activity ramp, those people are here for us.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: We have a question from Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I can ask you to kind of force rank your Bakken and Eagle Ford opportunity. So you've been very clear, SCOOP and STACK will be the first call in capital, which one goes in second?
componenttext: Maybe I can ask you to kind of force rank your Bakken and Eagle Ford opportunity. So you've been very clear, SCOOP and STACK will be the first call in capital, which one goes in second?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Lee. Just for clarity, at the top of our kind of batting order is STACK oil, that clearly has the superior returns whether we look at a $40 environment or even a $50 environment. I think then, the league table gets pretty interesting because
componenttext: Yes, this is Lee. Just for clarity, at the top of our kind of batting order is STACK oil, that clearly has the superior returns whether we look at a $40 environment or even a $50 environment. I think then, the league table gets pretty interesting because of all the good work the asset teams have been doing. We actually have more diversity within our Tier 1 kind of inventory that will compete for capital. But the ones that we would see really rising to the top are we're going to continue to see Eagle Ford, [indiscernible] oil, we're going to continue to see Bakken, West Myrmidon specifically come into the mix. And then also the SCOOP condensate area is going to be a strong performer, which will also maybe amplified in the event that we see stronger gas support as well. So that's really kind of the league table as we see it today.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And just a point of clarification on the small drop in your full year production guidance. Is that purely the net effect of taking out Wyoming and putting in the new STACK acreage?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from Arun Jayaram of JPMorgan.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give us your outlook or expectations for how the U.S. resource play production could trend in the back half of the year? And secondly, is there going to be some more knock-on effect from the Eagle Ford completions, high densit
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give us your outlook or expectations for how the U.S. resource play production could trend in the back half of the year? And secondly, is there going to be some more knock-on effect from the Eagle Ford completions, high density completions you highlighted in 2015 in the update?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take maybe the question around the back half of the year on resource plays. And then maybe pitch it over to Lance to take on, if there's any knock on affect of completion discussion. I think you've seen the releases that come out over the last few da
componenttext: I'll take maybe the question around the back half of the year on resource plays. And then maybe pitch it over to Lance to take on, if there's any knock on affect of completion discussion. I think you've seen the releases that come out over the last few days. There's clearly more optimism in the market, particularly, I think as you stretch end of 2017. I think the sector, in general, was struggling with striking the correct balance between wanting to be prepared if they get a strong and sustainable price signal versus getting too far ahead of their headlights and losing, I think, the discipline that had been required during this downturn. So speaking from a Marathon Oil perspective, we do expect to build some momentum going into the fourth quarter, which we think would position us quite favorably in the event we do see more constructive pricing, and I would say that there's probably many others within our space that are looking to do the same. There of course, will always be an element that may have to be more in a balance sheet repair mode as opposed to kind of being on their front foot and looking to drive toward incremental activity. But I don't see a dramatic adjustment just because of the declines have been pretty challenging this year and it's going to be hard, of course, to offset that completely with late-year activity. And maybe, Lance, you want to chime in on just the question on the knock-on and the completion effects.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So specifically talking on the Eagle Ford, I think as Lee referenced, our guidance takes into account our view on all that, so it's there in it. We have made some adjustments to the development plan, you'll see those reflected in the Eagle Ford seco
componenttext: Sure. So specifically talking on the Eagle Ford, I think as Lee referenced, our guidance takes into account our view on all that, so it's there in it. We have made some adjustments to the development plan, you'll see those reflected in the Eagle Ford second half of the year. Shift to focus on more 2/3 of that activities in the high GOR oil areas, which are our highest value type curves with pricing and we have widen out that Austin Chalk from 40-acre to 80-acre spacing to mitigate those influences. And the 3 and 4 zone high density pads are really -- we're for going those for the rest of this year, and so that will help mitigate those concerns. I think otherwise, we put into our guidance what we think the base decline from '15 is going to look like.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And my follow-up. Just Lee, in terms of your comments of earlier in the call about doubling, maybe the rig count between now and year-end '17 in order to get to that call it flattish with some growth in the U.S. resource play. Would you anticipate
componenttext: Great. And my follow-up. Just Lee, in terms of your comments of earlier in the call about doubling, maybe the rig count between now and year-end '17 in order to get to that call it flattish with some growth in the U.S. resource play. Would you anticipate kind of a stair-step linear kind of move inactivity over that time period?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. There will certainly be a ramp associated with that. I mean, that would not be a step change, if you will, there will be at a ramp across the year. So I was trying to project at where we thought we might exit out of 2017 based on that kind of nominal
componenttext: Yes. There will certainly be a ramp associated with that. I mean, that would not be a step change, if you will, there will be at a ramp across the year. So I was trying to project at where we thought we might exit out of 2017 based on that kind of nominal $1.4 billion type investment. But there will absolutely be a ramp. And I think, too, you have to bear in mind that the rigs today are doing a lot more than the rigs did a year ago. And so we're absolutely are take advantage of that deficiency. In fact, in the Eagle Ford, we've actually gone down our rigs in second quarter from 5 to 4 rigs, recognizing just the sheer efficiency of our drilling operations and the ability of our teams to continue to set a very strong pace on the drilling side of the business.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have no further questions at this time. I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Lee Tillman for closing remarks.
componenttext: We have no further questions at this time. I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Lee Tillman for closing remarks.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would like to thank everyone on the call for the questions and certainly, their interest in Marathon Oil. It's a busy and productive quarter for the company. I think the headline speaks for themselves, I won't go back through those. But we are pre
componenttext: Well, I would like to thank everyone on the call for the questions and certainly, their interest in Marathon Oil. It's a busy and productive quarter for the company. I think the headline speaks for themselves, I won't go back through those. But we are preparing for that sustainable price environment where we can profitably grow our business within cash flows. In 2017, we can get our business back to sequential growth and live within our means with WTI in the low to mid-50s. And as I've stated during the call, we have the potential for even higher growth at higher pricing with an industry-leading leveraged oil. So thank you again for their time on the call. I, appreciate it, and have a great day.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Marathon Oil Corporation 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Hilda, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.I would now like to turn the
componenttext:
Welcome to the Marathon Oil Corporation 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Hilda, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Zach Dailey. Mr. Dailey, you may begin.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Hilda, and good morning to everyone. Welcome to Marathon Oil's second quarter earnings call. Joining me this morning are Lee Tillman, President and CEO; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO; Lance Robertson, Vice President, Resource Plays;
componenttext:
Thanks, Hilda, and good morning to everyone. Welcome to Marathon Oil's second quarter earnings call. Joining me this morning are Lee Tillman, President and CEO; J.R. Sult, Executive Vice President and CFO; Lance Robertson, Vice President, Resource Plays; and Mitch Little, Vice President, Conventional. 
As a reminder, today's call may contain forward-looking statements subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. Please read our disclosures in our earnings release and in our SEC filings for a discussion of these items. Reconciliations of any non-GAAP financial measures we discuss can be found in the quarterly information package on our website.
with that, I'll turn the call over to Lee.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Zach, and good morning to everyone. I'll make a few brief comments and I'll open the call for questions. Our second quarter headlines. Strong well results, continued cost reduction, successful portfolio management. Our Oklahoma asset team del
componenttext:
Thank you, Zach, and good morning to everyone. I'll make a few brief comments and I'll open the call for questions. 
Our second quarter headlines. Strong well results, continued cost reduction, successful portfolio management. Our Oklahoma asset team delivered 2 outstanding STACK Meramec wells, with oil cuts above 70%, while continuing to balance leased whole demands with acreage delineation. 
This same team also closed our PayRock acquisition on Monday, just 6 weeks after announcing the deal, and are rapidly integrating that asset into our Oklahoma business. The team actually had a countdown calendar in the office as they marched towards the accelerated close date. Needless to say, they are excited and their focused efforts will ensure no loss of momentum.
We had an exceptional quarter in the Bakken, delivering a record well on our West Myrmidon acreage through a combination of great reservoir quality and enhanced completion designs. The Bakken asset team has truly embraced this time of lower activity to prepare for what's next. They dropped their production costs materially and upped their game on well returns to place West Myrmidon in the mix for 2017 capital allocation.
The Eagle Ford continued seeing uplift from tighter stage spacing, while feeling the effects of a planned step down in activity and challenging base production declines. And despite their move to higher intensity completions, their completed well costs are down significantly year-over-year.
Winning the production cost battle is hard work and typically measured in numerous but smaller victories. Rest assured that cost management remains front and center with all of our asset teams.
North America E&P production costs are down almost 30% from a year ago, and we dropped their full year guidance by $1 per oil equivalent barrel. We've also reduced 2016 unit production expense guidance for international by $0.50 per oil equivalent barrel.
Through a combination of capital discipline and efficiency gains across all of our businesses, we'll deliver a 2016 capital program that's $100 million below our original budget, all while funding the incremental 2016 activity associated with our STACK acquisition, including the additional rig we'll add there this quarter.
Oklahoma is getting busy, with the acquisition, we will be doubling our activity in the STACK to 4 rigs in total.
Not to be outdone by North America's success in our international business, we achieved first gas from the B3 compression project in EG in July, on schedule and within budget. The project is fulfilling its mission to extend the Alba Field's production plateau by 2 years and the asset's life out beyond 2030. 
As our capital investment in the compression project falls away, EG will contribute significant free cash flow that we can reinvest in our deep inventory of high-return opportunities here in the U.S. resource plays.
On the portfolio management side. Our noncore asset sales program has now achieved over $1 billion year-to-date. And though we exceeded our initial target, we aren't done. Expect noncore asset sales to be ongoing as we continue optimizing our capital allocation to the lowest cost, highest margin opportunities.
On the other side of portfolio management, the 61,000 net acres we acquired in the STACK Meramec oil window ticks all the boxes: quality, scale, value and with further upside not assumed in the purchase price. Through this volatile and uncertain commodity price environment, we've been resolute in executing against our playbook, strengthening our balance sheet, resetting our cost structure, simplifying our portfolio, all with the goal of profitable growth within cash flows when sustainably higher prices give us the confidence to ramp activity. 
With that, I'll hand it back to Zach to begin the Q&A.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of excitement on the STACK. You spoke in the prepared remarks about resuming sequential growth at low to mid-50s. Maybe just some opening remarks about that statement.
componenttext: A lot of excitement on the STACK. You spoke in the prepared remarks about resuming sequential growth at low to mid-50s. Maybe just some opening remarks about that statement.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good morning, Ed. We're still committed to that, Ed. We -- as we look out at the macro today, though, it's -- we're sitting at $40 today. But as we look out to 2017 and see that more constructive pricing, we feel very confident in our ability to begi
componenttext: Yes, good morning, Ed. We're still committed to that, Ed. We -- as we look out at the macro today, though, it's -- we're sitting at $40 today. But as we look out to 2017 and see that more constructive pricing, we feel very confident in our ability to begin that growth sequentially again, and do it within cash flows in that low to mid-50s kind of price range. A lot of that will also hinge on our ability to ensure that we have operational momentum coming out of 2016 as well.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so on the -- maybe some color on the rig activity that would be simply embedded in that. I mean, obviously, we can do our own forecast. We're just interested in your color on rig ramps and by an Eagle Ford STACK, Bakken.
componenttext: And so on the -- maybe some color on the rig activity that would be simply embedded in that. I mean, obviously, we can do our own forecast. We're just interested in your color on rig ramps and by an Eagle Ford STACK, Bakken.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely, Ed. Well, we've talked about, nominally, kind of a $1.4 billion program in 2017 that would get us back on that sequential growth track in -- within the resource plays. And within that is -- the way I would ask you to think about it, Ed, i
componenttext: Yes, absolutely, Ed. Well, we've talked about, nominally, kind of a $1.4 billion program in 2017 that would get us back on that sequential growth track in -- within the resource plays. And within that is -- the way I would ask you to think about it, Ed, is it's embedded basically almost doubling of the rig count from where we are today to when we would exit in 2017. And that would support both that capital program as well as that volumes profile.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: All right. Okay. If I can sneak one final one, debt repurchases or blending and extending maturities, any thoughts there? Other companies are doing the same thing.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: 9Hey, Ed, this is J.R. As we've talked, I think, on previous calls, even though we're focused here on ultimately being able to get that capital program up to a level to where we can resume the growth path, the balance sheet is still going to be importan
componenttext:
9
Hey, Ed, this is J.R. As we've talked, I think, on previous calls, even though we're focused here on ultimately being able to get that capital program up to a level to where we can resume the growth path, the balance sheet is still going to be important. I think we've got some maturities coming up here in October of '17 and again in March of '18. Sitting here today, it would appear to be the right allocation of capital might be just to wait to be able to pay off those maturities when they're due. And that's one reason why I think we're maintaining the cash balance that we are today to give us that option. But we'll continue to look at other opportunities to be able to reduce overall gross debt. But right now, I think we're leaning toward just repaying those maturities when they're due.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We have a question from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So guys, as things post your acquisition in the STACK, obviously, there's a lot of tension going on there. Can you just give us some ideas to how you would prioritize incremental rig additions in the event that the commodity does continue to recover next
componenttext: So guys, as things post your acquisition in the STACK, obviously, there's a lot of tension going on there. Can you just give us some ideas to how you would prioritize incremental rig additions in the event that the commodity does continue to recover next year?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, Doug, good morning. Oklahoma STACK is going to be our absolute first priority, Doug. Once we've met our leasehold requirements and our strategic objectives in the STACK, then we're going to look at optimizing across the remaining basins to maxim
componenttext: Yes. Yes, Doug, good morning. Oklahoma STACK is going to be our absolute first priority, Doug. Once we've met our leasehold requirements and our strategic objectives in the STACK, then we're going to look at optimizing across the remaining basins to maximize economic return. I think the good there -- the good news there for us is that when we look at that multi-basin optimization, we've got a very competitive and diverse Tier 1 inventory that really now features everything from Eagle Ford oil and condensate to Bakken West Myrmidon to SCOOP. So it's a great portfolio, but that first incremental capital is absolutely going to Oklahoma STACK. In fact, as we stated in our released material last evening, we'll be looking to add that second rig into the STACK acquisition acreage later in the third quarter, bringing us to a total of 4 rigs in Oklahoma.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up, obviously, the STACK is a very filling meaningful change in your inventory, Lee. But what would you -- how would you characterize your comfort level or your satisfaction, I guess a better way of putting it, with your current acreage positi
componenttext: As a follow-up, obviously, the STACK is a very filling meaningful change in your inventory, Lee. But what would you -- how would you characterize your comfort level or your satisfaction, I guess a better way of putting it, with your current acreage position up there? Because obviously, relative to some of your other peers, there's still a relatively small footprint. Do you see other additions in the future? Or we'll see overall characterization of availability of acreage? And I'll leave you there.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, thank you. Yes, Doug, I certainly wouldn't -- I'm very happy with our footprint in the STACK as well as the SCOOP as certainly with the bolt-on of the STACK acquisition, the PayRock acquisition that enhanced our position materially in the STACK
componenttext: Yes. Well, thank you. Yes, Doug, I certainly wouldn't -- I'm very happy with our footprint in the STACK as well as the SCOOP as certainly with the bolt-on of the STACK acquisition, the PayRock acquisition that enhanced our position materially in the STACK. But as I look across it from a overall resource standpoint, and you think about the fact that we now have in excess of about $1 billion 2P resource in the STACK as well as another $1 billion or so in the SCOOP, that is a very, very material position going forward in Oklahoma. And at just over a couple hundred thousand surface acres -- net surface acres in the STACK, we feel very good about our position. We've never -- we would never forgo accretive small bolt-on positions or greenfield leasing, but we're quite pleased with where we stand right now in Oklahoma.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Ryan Todd from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We have a question from Ryan Todd from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe with the PayRock deal closed, can you talk a little bit about plans to integrate these assets? I mean you -- I guess you've talked about rig addition there. But generally, how do you characterize that acreage relative to your legacy acreage and pote
componenttext: Maybe with the PayRock deal closed, can you talk a little bit about plans to integrate these assets? I mean you -- I guess you've talked about rig addition there. But generally, how do you characterize that acreage relative to your legacy acreage and potential improvements or any inches operationally maybe you might make to look -- or look to make on things like lateral length or completion there or such versus what you've done on your acreage?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me maybe tick that one off and then I'll turn it over to Lance to maybe provide a bit more color. But we just closed on STACK -- on the STACK acquisition on Monday and took over operations after lunch on Monday. So integration is still a work in
componenttext: Yes, let me maybe tick that one off and then I'll turn it over to Lance to maybe provide a bit more color. But we just closed on STACK -- on the STACK acquisition on Monday and took over operations after lunch on Monday. So integration is still a work in progress so the team is well advanced. And as you've mentioned, we're going to be putting a second rig to work there. The 2 rigs are going to be initially focused on protecting that valuable leasehold, but also looking towards continuing strategic, I'll say, delineation around the play as well. But in terms of economics and where those wells fall in our set of opportunities, there's no doubt that the STACK oil opportunities compete at the very top of our Tier 1 inventory. And that's even been confirmed yet again with the 3 additional wells that have been brought to sales by -- within the acquisition between -- up to close. And so maybe I'll just let Lance fill in a few more details on just how the integration is going.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Lee. We took over the operations on Monday. It's been very seamless today. Obviously, we look at the acquired acres. They're on the oil buy-side. We think it balances the portfolio across the breadth of the STACK basin very nicely for us. We
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Lee. We took over the operations on Monday. It's been very seamless today. Obviously, we look at the acquired acres. They're on the oil buy-side. We think it balances the portfolio across the breadth of the STACK basin very nicely for us. We're going to have the ongoing obligations there to defend the lease position. In our heritage Marathon acreage in STACK as well is ongoing in the acquired acres. We do have a bit of excess capacity there. I think one of the things that you would recognize in our activities to date. So for example, in the results we have reported this quarter, we've been transitioning to XL wells in our overpressured area to look at the value there. Those well results have been very compelling and we're very excited about those. We also purchased this acquisition on the oil buy-side based on the fact that they had among the very best productivity on a lateral-adjusted foot basis with very low capital costs, which together, create a great value opportunity for us. And so we're going to continue on that basis. And I think we also recognize the opportunity with about half the acreage in the acquired package suitable for XL that we're going to move to also test the XL in that area to see what the best long-term result for Marathon is.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how much of your acreage across the entire -- not just the acquired acreage but across your entire STACK portfolio is conducive to long laterals?
componenttext: And how much of your acreage across the entire -- not just the acquired acreage but across your entire STACK portfolio is conducive to long laterals?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, in general, about half of that is conducive to long laterals, perhaps a bit more as we continue to consolidate and unitize in there. But that's where we stand today.
componenttext: I think, in general, about half of that is conducive to long laterals, perhaps a bit more as we continue to consolidate and unitize in there. But that's where we stand today.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question Guy Baber from Simmons.
componenttext: We have a question Guy Baber from Simmons.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just trying to understand the financial and operational framework you've set out here for 2017. So I had a follow-up there. But I believe you mentioned the early view is at about $1.4 billion in spending or so next year would be sufficient to return t
componenttext: I'm just trying to understand the financial and operational framework you've set out here for 2017. So I had a follow-up there. But I believe you mentioned the early view is at about $1.4 billion in spending or so next year would be sufficient to return the company to sequential growth assuming oil in the mid- to low 50s. I believe you also mentioned the desire to live within cash flow. So is $1.4 billion plus your dividend about the type of cash flow you expect to generate next year in a low to mid-50 world? Or are you incorporating some asset sales proceeds into your forecast to support that as well?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, guy -- yes, thanks for the follow-up question. First of all, I want to be very clear. The $1.4 billion I'm talking about, Guy, is for the resource play element only. That would not include other capital requirements and the conventional elements of o
componenttext: Yes, guy -- yes, thanks for the follow-up question. First of all, I want to be very clear. The $1.4 billion I'm talking about, Guy, is for the resource play element only. That would not include other capital requirements and the conventional elements of our business. Although we would expect similar to what we did this year that the bulk of our capital investment in 2017 will in fact be allocated to the resource plays. But in that low 50 to mid-50 window, we would absolutely expect to cover that capital demand within operating cash flows. Does not mean we're not still pursuing noncore asset divestitures, but we're certainly not saying we're going to be reliant upon those. They give us optionality, but we don't feel that we need to rely on those if we're in that price band.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's very helpful. And then my follow-up is, understanding 2017 is something of a transitional year for you during what you attempt to return the company back to sequential growth. But once you get a better commodity price environment, you've imp
componenttext: Great. That's very helpful. And then my follow-up is, understanding 2017 is something of a transitional year for you during what you attempt to return the company back to sequential growth. But once you get a better commodity price environment, you've improved the well results, the operational performance, I think, significantly. You've also made meaningful improvements to the portfolio and your opportunity set. When the time comes, what type of growth rate do you think Marathon is poised to fundamentally deliver longer term? I'm just trying to understand kind of that framework for longer-term growth.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, absolutely. Yes, I think first and foremost, you said it well. We've got this great opportunity set that very much competes for capital in the price band. A lot of that, I would say, growth aspiration, though, will be highly dependent upon the pr
componenttext: Yes. No, absolutely. Yes, I think first and foremost, you said it well. We've got this great opportunity set that very much competes for capital in the price band. A lot of that, I would say, growth aspiration, though, will be highly dependent upon the pricing that we see. Being a very oil-levered company, of course, we have a very strong response in operating cash flows as we see improvements to the oil price. So to the extent that we need to modulate between growth as well as generating free cash flows, we're prepared to do that. But the potential that we've got in the 3 resource plays definitely provides us an avenue for moving to a very competitive growth metric in the future. Without getting into specifics there, we have that potential.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We have a question from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question. Your Meramec, your legacy wells are performing better than your type curve. How large of a well sample production history do you need to raise your resource estimate? And I guess the same question applies to Eagle Ford with the 200-stag
componenttext: My first question. Your Meramec, your legacy wells are performing better than your type curve. How large of a well sample production history do you need to raise your resource estimate? And I guess the same question applies to Eagle Ford with the 200-stage spacing and Bakken wells with larger completion. I know the last time you lifted your resource estimate was September. How are you guys thinking about that?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Evan. This is Lance. So I'll start kind of in the order you asked them perhaps. But overall, it's clearly early in the STACK still. I mean, we're delineating the whole acreage, us and peers. Those well results were reported this quarter, the Irven J
componenttext: Sure, Evan. This is Lance. So I'll start kind of in the order you asked them perhaps. But overall, it's clearly early in the STACK still. I mean, we're delineating the whole acreage, us and peers. Those well results were reported this quarter, the Irven John and Olive June are excellent well results. Other XL wells are performing above that type curve. They're also only about 40 or 50 days into their total production, so I think we're going need to let those run a while. I think we're excited that they're above that curve and so there will be certainly an opportunity for a resource upgrade. We also have, as you might recall, a number of other XL wells in the third quarter and fourth quarter in that same Blaine County area from our heritage acreage we'll get to talk about. So when we get the breadth of those and they've matured a bit, it would be a more appropriate time for that. Turning to the Bakken, I think the well results we reported there are really remarkable this quarter. All off of the same pad, the 3 best -- among the 3 best wells put in the basin in the last 3 years, that really demonstrates what technology application, the right landings on the right combination is and we have inventory like that. Similarly, we like to see those mature, but there other wells in that area that also perform well, which is why we were aggressive in that area. So I think we need to let those mature, but there -- I'd just echo, source upgrade there driven by that. Lastly, Eagle Ford, we continue to be really pleased with the results of tighter stage basin, particularly in the oil areas in the upper and lower Eagle Ford, responding very well. We've got a breath of wells there now, almost 75 wells in that group. So it's maturing, which gives us more confidence. And I think we recognize there will be a need to do a resource update in the not-too-distant future.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. If I could follow-up in the Eagle Ford. I know you up-spaced. Your Austin Chalk assumptions to 80-acre spacing. I mean, could you walk us through what drove that change? And is that because you were getting well interference with the
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. If I could follow-up in the Eagle Ford. I know you up-spaced. Your Austin Chalk assumptions to 80-acre spacing. I mean, could you walk us through what drove that change? And is that because you were getting well interference with the 40-acre spacing? And I guess you're planning on draining the Austin Chalk with your Upper Eagle Ford laterals?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan. So I think we went last year from sort of unconstrained Austin Chalk, very quickly to 40-acre spacing in the Austin Chalk to try to find the balance of productivity of that reservoir. I think what we've discovered over the last few quarters is
componenttext: Yes, Evan. So I think we went last year from sort of unconstrained Austin Chalk, very quickly to 40-acre spacing in the Austin Chalk to try to find the balance of productivity of that reservoir. I think what we've discovered over the last few quarters is that at 40-acre spacing, when we've had groups, really, our first groups of Austin Chalk wells together that are constrained, that the reservoir quality is very high. It's got a lot of natural fracturing, which we suspected but weren't certain of. And those wells are communicating laterally a bit. And that overall, we're going to get the best capital efficiency in the Austin Chalk at wider spacing. In that same time frame, we've also been testing the Upper Eagle Ford, really doubled the amount of our delineated acreage over that time in the Upper Eagle Ford. And recognize that it can -- we could backfill some of those Austin Chalk locations with Upper Eagle Ford, but both at wider spacing. They just interact better. But ultimately, we're looking for the highest recovery of hydrocarbon out of that unit at the lowest capital input. So we're trying to optimize the returns at the drilling unit level.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is it a reasonable oil price and we should go back to the 40-acre downspacing? Or how does that interplay work?
componenttext: Is it a reasonable oil price and we should go back to the 40-acre downspacing? Or how does that interplay work?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think you have take a view on price in any of this. And I would reflect that we started this density testing at north of $90 a barrel. It probably looks different at $40. So the higher commodity price, I think, the more you'd want to look at that
componenttext: Sure. I think you have take a view on price in any of this. And I would reflect that we started this density testing at north of $90 a barrel. It probably looks different at $40. So the higher commodity price, I think, the more you'd want to look at that ultimate density, because that just drives the returns from that unit. We think where we are today evolving, making these adjustments is appropriate for today's commodity market.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We have a question from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up on the CapEx, $1.4 billion. I think you clarified on the earlier question that this is for the key resource areas. And I just wanted to kind of put that into context to make sure the base is right. Is this essentially off of about a
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up on the CapEx, $1.4 billion. I think you clarified on the earlier question that this is for the key resource areas. And I just wanted to kind of put that into context to make sure the base is right. Is this essentially off of about a $375 million spent for those resource plays in the first half of the year? And then can you talk about the trajectory for how you're thinking about the rest of the company? I think, if we look at least on a cash flow statement type perspective, you spent about $800 million overall for the company in the first half.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Certainly, in the first half of the year, Brian, there was a bit of a bias because we had a couple of long cycle projects that were running their course that are now, of course, both started up, which are the EG compression project as well as the non
componenttext: Yes. Certainly, in the first half of the year, Brian, there was a bit of a bias because we had a couple of long cycle projects that were running their course that are now, of course, both started up, which are the EG compression project as well as the non-operated Gunflint project. So there was probably a bit more bias to the conventional portfolio in the first half of the year. As we look forward to the second half of the year, that's going to largely be paced by the resource plays themselves. And that will really set the, I'll say, kind of that exit velocity that we achieved from a capital program standpoint as we move out of the year. We do anticipate, based on the activity we've described, including the additional rig in Oklahoma as well as some additional completion work in the Eagle Ford, that to be will exit the fourth quarter with some pretty strong momentum going into 2017. To your point, I guess, on the rest of the portfolio, looking forward to 2017, you should expect us to continue to minimize the capital allocation to the conventional program, very similar to what we endeavored to do this cycle in 2016.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And that is a little bit of a follow-up to more of a strategic perspective, which is given your, I think, interest in the returns that you're seeing from the resource play portfolio, how strategically are you thinking about the assets elsewhere? Do
componenttext: Great. And that is a little bit of a follow-up to more of a strategic perspective, which is given your, I think, interest in the returns that you're seeing from the resource play portfolio, how strategically are you thinking about the assets elsewhere? Do you anticipate additional asset sales? Or as you perhaps just described, minimal levels of capital investment to try to use these assets for the free cash flow to offset potential outspending going on at the resource plays?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Brian, our conventional business is absolutely geared toward generating free cash flows that can then be redeployed. That's the model. That's what Mitch drives the team toward. I will look at some selective investments there. A great example is the E
componenttext: Yes. Brian, our conventional business is absolutely geared toward generating free cash flows that can then be redeployed. That's the model. That's what Mitch drives the team toward. I will look at some selective investments there. A great example is the EG compression project, albeit a long-cycle project. It's very accretive. It's delivering very strong economics and performance in the portfolio. And it's simply going to add to the ability of Equatorial Guinea to add to our cash flows. I think a separate question, though, is more of the noncore asset question. We continue to scrutinize our portfolio and ensure that it is fully optimized. As I said in my opening remarks, we've achieved $1 billion year-to-date of noncore asset divestitures, but we believe there is more work to be done there. We don't think that will be to the scale of, say, Wyoming, but we still believe there's some good solid portfolio work, particularly here in North America that we continue to drive. And again, it's all focused on that simplification and concentration of the portfolio toward the highest risk-adjusted returns.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.
componenttext: We have a question from Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A high-level question, if I could. I assume that you are basically turning the company at about a $50 outlook. How would things change if we would start assuming $40 or $60 in your mind? And I know you've been a little bit reluctant, probably quite rightl
componenttext: A high-level question, if I could. I assume that you are basically turning the company at about a $50 outlook. How would things change if we would start assuming $40 or $60 in your mind? And I know you've been a little bit reluctant, probably quite rightly to commit to sort of levels of prices at which you'd start to think about faster growth and stuff, but I'm trying to pin you down on it.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, I appreciate your transparency. I'll maybe take those 2 bookends that you just talked about, the $40 and the $60. Obviously, I think it's $40, similar to what we've experienced this year. We'd be looking to protect our balance sheet to ensure that t
componenttext: Paul, I appreciate your transparency. I'll maybe take those 2 bookends that you just talked about, the $40 and the $60. Obviously, I think it's $40, similar to what we've experienced this year. We'd be looking to protect our balance sheet to ensure that though we continue to drive those leasehold and strategic objectives in the portfolio and then look with great discipline at some of those discretionary economic opportunities within the portfolio, we'd still be bearing down on cost. We'd still be bearing down on noncore asset sales. So those with the behaviors and the objectives as we -- if we saw an environment moving into '17, that is more in the 4-handle range. I think conversely, if we see more constructive pricing moving in to '17, at that $60 as we've talked about, a $10 move in pricing for us is a big impact on our operating cash flows. And we'd be looking to redeploy those pretty strongly back here into the U.S. resource plays to not only get back on sequential growth, but get back on that growth quite strongly if we saw that level of price support. We've protected the organization in such a way that we have the capacity to move to much higher activity levels. And if we saw that $60, we'd move toward that as quickly as we could.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's interesting. So on the dividend, is that still something that you aspire to return to be relatively a high-dividend payer? Or do you see us all shifting as to more of an unconventional growth story?
componenttext: That's interesting. So on the dividend, is that still something that you aspire to return to be relatively a high-dividend payer? Or do you see us all shifting as to more of an unconventional growth story?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think as you look at our portfolio, Paul, you look at our business model, we have made the shift. We made the shift in the dividend last year. Of course, it was helpful from an operating cash flow standpoint. But it was also much more consistent with wh
componenttext: I think as you look at our portfolio, Paul, you look at our business model, we have made the shift. We made the shift in the dividend last year. Of course, it was helpful from an operating cash flow standpoint. But it was also much more consistent with where we were headed in this very short-cycle investment resource play-intensive business that we're in. And we think from a competitive standpoint, given our opportunity outlook for growth and reinvestment, that's the right place for us to place our shareholder money.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And if I could just try one to Lance. Lance, you've seen something very interesting here which is the -- obviously this being a significant improvement in cost performance, really across the industry at lower prices. But what's also interesting is,
componenttext: Great. And if I could just try one to Lance. Lance, you've seen something very interesting here which is the -- obviously this being a significant improvement in cost performance, really across the industry at lower prices. But what's also interesting is, I guess, the technical improvements are still being achieved even though activity is so much lower. If we did go back to higher prices, do you think technical improvements would accelerate? Or would they actually deteriorate because we'd be going into presumably into less high-quality acreage?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul. I think that's an insightful question. And I think what we would focus on at today's activity, which we are or at higher activity in the future would be in our Tier 1 inventory. And as we've taken those technical advances and then we've lifted
componenttext: Yes, Paul. I think that's an insightful question. And I think what we would focus on at today's activity, which we are or at higher activity in the future would be in our Tier 1 inventory. And as we've taken those technical advances and then we've lifted up the returns of some of our portfolio, we have such a breadth of it now that we're going to focus within that Tier 1 first, but we'll take a portion of our activity to try to test some Tier 2 and lift it up to meet that thing. I think we need to stay disciplined in any price environment to make sure we're bringing our best opportunities forward, but also take into view that we're going to bet on technology. We're going to bet on the innovation and the creativity of our people to keep bringing our portfolio up accretively over that time.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Can I just ask a follow-up? You said that you've retained -- is it that you haven't structured people? Or have you retained your ability that both of you mentioned?
componenttext: Yes. Can I just ask a follow-up? You said that you've retained -- is it that you haven't structured people? Or have you retained your ability that both of you mentioned?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. As we spun down our activity, we recognize that we have cadre of early career talented people, and we don't necessarily have the direct activity to put them into. So we've taken them out to special projects across the company. They're out doing
componenttext: Yes, sure. As we spun down our activity, we recognize that we have cadre of early career talented people, and we don't necessarily have the direct activity to put them into. So we've taken them out to special projects across the company. They're out doing site supervision work on rigs and frac crews, production supervisors. So we are retaining them in very variable functions, maturing their leadership and their technical skills and their business acumen. And then as we grow activity, we can recall them into other kind of petrotechnical focused roles, and they're going to be even better prepared to take those on. So the early activity ramp, those people are here for us.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: We have a question from Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I can ask you to kind of force rank your Bakken and Eagle Ford opportunities. So you've been very clear, SCOOP and STACK will be the first call on capital. Which one goes second?
componenttext: Maybe I can ask you to kind of force rank your Bakken and Eagle Ford opportunities. So you've been very clear, SCOOP and STACK will be the first call on capital. Which one goes second?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Lee. Just for clarity, at the top of our kind of batting order is going to STACK oil. That clearly has the superior returns whether we look at a $40 environment or even a $50 environment. I think then, the league table gets pretty interesting
componenttext: Yes, this is Lee. Just for clarity, at the top of our kind of batting order is going to STACK oil. That clearly has the superior returns whether we look at a $40 environment or even a $50 environment. I think then, the league table gets pretty interesting because of all the good work the asset teams have been doing. We actually have more diversity within our Tier 1 kind of inventory that will compete for capital. But the ones that we would see really rising to the top are -- we're going to continue to see Eagle Ford, high GOR oil. We're going to continue to see Bakken, West Myrmidon, specifically come into the mix. And then also the SCOOP condensate area is going to be a strong performer, which will also may be amplified in the event that we see stronger gas support as well. So that's really kind of the league table as we see it today.
