headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: 9Hey, Ed, this is J.R. As we've talked, I think, on previous calls, even though we're focused here on ultimately being able to get that capital program up to a level to where we can resume the growth path, the balance sheet is still going to be importan
componenttext:
9
Hey, Ed, this is J.R. As we've talked, I think, on previous calls, even though we're focused here on ultimately being able to get that capital program up to a level to where we can resume the growth path, the balance sheet is still going to be important. I think we've got some maturities coming up here in October of '17 and again in March of '18. Sitting here today, it would appear to be the right allocation of capital might be just to wait, to be able to pay off those maturities when they're due. And that's one reason why I think we're maintaining the cash balance that we are today to give us that option. But we'll continue to look at other opportunities to be able to reduce overall gross debt. But right now, I think we're leaning toward just repaying those maturities when they're due.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We have a question from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So guys, as things post your acquisition in the STACK, obviously, there's a lot of tension going on there. Can you just give us some ideas to how you would prioritize incremental rig additions in the event that the commodity does continue to recover next
componenttext: So guys, as things post your acquisition in the STACK, obviously, there's a lot of tension going on there. Can you just give us some ideas to how you would prioritize incremental rig additions in the event that the commodity does continue to recover next year?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, Doug. Oklahoma STACK is going to be our absolute first priority, Doug. Once we've met our leasehold requirements and our strategic objectives in the STACK, then we're going to look at optimizing across the remaining basins to maximize economic r
componenttext: Yes. Yes, Doug. Oklahoma STACK is going to be our absolute first priority, Doug. Once we've met our leasehold requirements and our strategic objectives in the STACK, then we're going to look at optimizing across the remaining basins to maximize economic return. I think the good there -- the good news there for us is that when we look at that multi-basin optimization, we've got a very competitive and diverse Tier 1 inventory that really now features everything from Eagle Ford oil and condensate to Bakken West Myrmidon to SCOOP. So it's a great portfolio, but that first incremental capital is absolutely going to Oklahoma STACK. In fact, as we stated in our released material last evening, we'll be looking to add that second rig into the STACK acquisition acreage later in the third quarter, bringing us to a total of 4 rigs in Oklahoma.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up, obviously, the STACK's a fairly meaningful change in your inventory, Lee. But what would you -- how would you characterize your comfort level or your satisfaction, I guess a better way of putting it, with your current acreage position up t
componenttext: As a follow-up, obviously, the STACK's a fairly meaningful change in your inventory, Lee. But what would you -- how would you characterize your comfort level or your satisfaction, I guess a better way of putting it, with your current acreage position up there? Because obviously, relative to some of your other peers, you still have relatively small footprint. Do you see other additions in the future? Or what's the overall characterization of availability of acreage? And I'll leave it there.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, thank you. Yes, Doug, I certainly wouldn't -- I'm very happy with our footprint in the STACK as well as the SCOOP as certainly with the bolt-on of the STACK acquisition, the PayRock acquisition that enhanced our position materially in the STACK
componenttext: Yes. Well, thank you. Yes, Doug, I certainly wouldn't -- I'm very happy with our footprint in the STACK as well as the SCOOP as certainly with the bolt-on of the STACK acquisition, the PayRock acquisition that enhanced our position materially in the STACK. But as I look across it from a overall resource standpoint, and you think about the fact that we now have in excess of about $1 billion 2P resource in the STACK as well as another $1 billion or so in the SCOOP, that is a very, very material position going forward in Oklahoma. And at just over a couple hundred thousand surface acres -- net surface acres in the STACK, we feel very good about our position. We'd never -- we would never forgo accretive small bolt-on positions or greenfield leasing, but we're quite pleased with where we stand right now in Oklahoma.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Ryan Todd from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We have a question from Ryan Todd from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe with the PayRock deal closed, can you talk a little bit about plans to integrate these assets? I mean you -- I guess you've talked about rig addition there. But generally, how do you characterize that acreage relative to your legacy acreage and pote
componenttext: Maybe with the PayRock deal closed, can you talk a little bit about plans to integrate these assets? I mean you -- I guess you've talked about rig addition there. But generally, how do you characterize that acreage relative to your legacy acreage and potential improvements or any inches [ph] operationally maybe you might make to look -- or look to make on things like lateral length or completion there or such versus what you've done on your acreage?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me maybe kick that one off and then I'll turn it over to Lance to maybe provide a bit more color. But we just closed on STACK -- on the STACK acquisition on Monday and took over operations after lunch on Monday. So integration is still a work in
componenttext: Yes, let me maybe kick that one off and then I'll turn it over to Lance to maybe provide a bit more color. But we just closed on STACK -- on the STACK acquisition on Monday and took over operations after lunch on Monday. So integration is still a work in progress though the team is well advanced. And as you've mentioned, we're going to be putting a second rig to work there. The 2 rigs are going to be initially focused on protecting that valuable leasehold, but also looking toward continuing strategic, I'll say, delineation around the play as well. But in terms of economics and where those wells fall in our set of opportunities, there's no doubt that the STACK oil opportunities compete at the very top of our Tier 1 inventory. And that's even been confirmed yet again with the 3 additional wells that have been brought to sales by -- within the acquisition between -- up to close. And so maybe I'll just let Lance fill in a few more details on just how the integration is going.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Lee. We took over the operations on Monday. It's been very seamless to date. Obviously, we look at the acquired acres. They're on the oil-bias side. We think it balances the portfolio across the breadth of the STACK basin very nicely for us.
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Lee. We took over the operations on Monday. It's been very seamless to date. Obviously, we look at the acquired acres. They're on the oil-bias side. We think it balances the portfolio across the breadth of the STACK basin very nicely for us. We're going to have the ongoing obligations there to defend the lease position. And our heritage Marathon acreage in STACK as well is ongoing in the acquired acres. We do have a bit of excess capacity there. I think one of the things that you would recognize in our activities to date. So for example, in the results we have reported this quarter, we've been transitioning to XL wells in our overpressured area to look at the value there. Those well results have been very compelling and we're very excited about those. We also purchased this acquisition on the oil-bias side based on the fact that they had among the very best productivity on a lateral-adjusted foot basis with very low capital costs, which together, create a great value opportunity for us. And so we're going to continue on that basis. And I think we also recognize the opportunity with about half the acres in the acquired package suitable for XL that we're going to move to also test the XL in that area to see what the best long-term result for Marathon is.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how much of your acreage across the entire -- not just the acquired acreage but across your entire STACK portfolio is conducive to long laterals?
componenttext: And how much of your acreage across the entire -- not just the acquired acreage but across your entire STACK portfolio is conducive to long laterals?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, in general, about half of that's conducive to long laterals, perhaps a bit more as we continue to consolidate and unitize in there. But that's where we stand today.
componenttext: I think, in general, about half of that's conducive to long laterals, perhaps a bit more as we continue to consolidate and unitize in there. But that's where we stand today.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Guy Baber from Simmons.
componenttext: We have a question from Guy Baber from Simmons.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just trying to understand the financial and operational framework you've set out here for 2017. So I had a follow-up there. But I believe you mentioned the early view is at about $1.4 billion in spending or so next year would be sufficient to return t
componenttext: I'm just trying to understand the financial and operational framework you've set out here for 2017. So I had a follow-up there. But I believe you mentioned the early view is at about $1.4 billion in spending or so next year would be sufficient to return the company to sequential growth assuming oil in the mid- to low 50s. I believe you also mentioned the desire to live within cash flow. So is $1.4 billion plus your dividend about the type of cash flow you expect to generate next year in a low to mid-50 world? Or are you incorporating some asset sales proceeds into your forecast to support that as well?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Guy -- yes, thanks for the follow-up question. First of all, I want to be very clear. The $1.4 billion I'm talking about, Guy, is for the resource play element only. That would not include other capital requirements and the conventional elements of o
componenttext: Yes, Guy -- yes, thanks for the follow-up question. First of all, I want to be very clear. The $1.4 billion I'm talking about, Guy, is for the resource play element only. That would not include other capital requirements and the conventional elements of our business. Although we would expect similar to what we did this year that the bulk of our capital investment in 2017 will in fact be allocated to the resource plays. But in that low 50 to mid-50 window, we would absolutely expect to cover that capital demand within operating cash flows. Does not mean we're not still pursuing noncore asset divestitures, but we're certainly not saying we're going to be reliant upon those. They give us optionality, but we don't feel that we need to rely on those if we're in that price band.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's very helpful. And then my follow-up is, understanding 2017 is something of a transitional year for you during which you attempt to return the company back to sequential growth. But once you get a better commodity price environment, you've im
componenttext: Great. That's very helpful. And then my follow-up is, understanding 2017 is something of a transitional year for you during which you attempt to return the company back to sequential growth. But once you get a better commodity price environment, you've improved the well results, the operational performance, I think, significantly. You've also made meaningful improvements to the portfolio and your opportunity set. When the time comes, what type of growth rate do you think Marathon is poised to fundamentally deliver longer term? I'm just trying to understand kind of that framework for longer-term growth.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, absolutely. Yes, I think first and foremost, you said it well. We've got this great opportunity set that very much competes for capital in the price band. A lot of that, I would say, growth aspiration, though, will be highly dependent upon the pr
componenttext: Yes. No, absolutely. Yes, I think first and foremost, you said it well. We've got this great opportunity set that very much competes for capital in the price band. A lot of that, I would say, growth aspiration, though, will be highly dependent upon the pricing that we see. Being a very oil-levered company, of course, we have a very strong response in operating cash flows as we see improvements to the oil price. So to the extent that we need to modulate between growth as well as generating free cash flows, we're prepared to do that. But the potential that we've got in the 3 resource plays definitely provides us an avenue for moving to a very competitive growth metric in the future. Without getting into specifics there, we have that potential.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We have a question from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question. Your Meramec, your legacy wells are performing better than your type curve. How large of a well sample production history do you need to raise your resource estimate? And I guess the same question applies to Eagle Ford with the 200-stag
componenttext: My first question. Your Meramec, your legacy wells are performing better than your type curve. How large of a well sample production history do you need to raise your resource estimate? And I guess the same question applies to Eagle Ford with the 200-stage spacing and Bakken wells with larger completion. I know the last time you lifted your resource estimate was September. How are you guys thinking about that?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Evan. This is Lance. So I'll start kind of in the order you asked them perhaps. But overall, it's clearly early in the STACK still. I mean, we're delineating the whole acreage, us and peers. Those well results we reported this quarter, the Irven Joh
componenttext: Sure, Evan. This is Lance. So I'll start kind of in the order you asked them perhaps. But overall, it's clearly early in the STACK still. I mean, we're delineating the whole acreage, us and peers. Those well results we reported this quarter, the Irven John and Olive June, are excellent well results. Other XL wells are performing above that type curve. They're also only about 40 or 50 days into their total production, so I think we're going need to let those run a while. I think we're excited that they're above that curve and so there's certainly an opportunity for resource upgrade. We'll also have, as you might recall, a number of other XL wells in the third quarter and fourth quarter in that same Blaine County area from our heritage acreage we get to talk about. So when we get the breadth of those and they've matured a bit, it would be a more appropriate time for that. Turning to the Bakken, I think the well results we reported there are really remarkable this quarter. All off of the same pad, the 3 best -- among the 3 best wells put in the basin in the last 3 years, that really demonstrates what technology application, the right landings on the right combination is and we have inventory like that. Similarly, we like to see those mature, but there are other wells in that area that also perform well, which is why we were aggressive in that area. So I think we need to let those mature, but there -- I'd just echo source [ph] upgrade there driven by that. Lastly, Eagle Ford, we continue to be really pleased with the results of tighter stage basin, particularly in the oil areas in the upper and lower Eagle Ford, responding very well. We've got a breadth of wells there now, almost 75 wells in that group. So it's maturing, which gives us more confidence. And I think we recognize there will be a need to do a resource update in the not-too-distant future.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. If I could follow-up in the Eagle Ford. I know you up-spaced. Your Austin Chalk assumptions state 80-acre spacing. I mean, could you walk us through what drove that change? And is that because you were getting well interference at th
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. If I could follow-up in the Eagle Ford. I know you up-spaced. Your Austin Chalk assumptions state 80-acre spacing. I mean, could you walk us through what drove that change? And is that because you were getting well interference at the 40-acre spacing? And I guess you're planning on draining the Austin Chalk with your Upper Eagle Ford laterals?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan. So I think we went last year from sort of unconstrained Austin Chalk, very quickly to 40-acre spacing in the Austin Chalk to try to find the bounds of productivity of that reservoir. I think what we've discovered over the last few quarters is t
componenttext: Yes, Evan. So I think we went last year from sort of unconstrained Austin Chalk, very quickly to 40-acre spacing in the Austin Chalk to try to find the bounds of productivity of that reservoir. I think what we've discovered over the last few quarters is that at 40-acre spacing, when we've had groups, really, our first groups of Austin Chalk wells together that are constrained, that the reservoir quality is very high. It's got a lot of natural fracturing, which we suspected but weren't certain of. And those wells are communicating laterally a bit. And that overall, we're going to get the best capital efficiency in the Austin Chalk at wider spacing. In that same time frame, we've also been testing the Upper Eagle Ford, really doubled the amount of our delineated acreage over that time in the Upper Eagle Ford. And recognize that it can -- we could backfill some of those Austin Chalk locations with Upper Eagle Ford, but both at wider spacing. They just interact better. But ultimately, we're looking for the highest recovery of hydrocarbon out of that unit at the lowest capital input. So we're trying to optimize the returns at the drilling unit level.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there a reasonable oil price in which we should go back to the 40-acre downspacing? Or how does that interplay work?
componenttext: Is there a reasonable oil price in which we should go back to the 40-acre downspacing? Or how does that interplay work?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think you have to take a view on price in any of this. And I would reflect that we started this density testing at north of $90 a barrel. It probably looks different at $40. So the higher commodity price, I think, the more you'd want to look at th
componenttext: Sure. I think you have to take a view on price in any of this. And I would reflect that we started this density testing at north of $90 a barrel. It probably looks different at $40. So the higher commodity price, I think, the more you'd want to look at that ultimate density, because that just drives the returns from that unit. We think where we are today -- evolving, making these adjustments is appropriate for today's commodity market.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We have a question from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up on the CapEx, $1.4 billion. I think you clarified on the earlier question that this is for the key resource areas. And I just wanted to kind of put that into context to make sure the base is right. Is this essentially off of about a
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up on the CapEx, $1.4 billion. I think you clarified on the earlier question that this is for the key resource areas. And I just wanted to kind of put that into context to make sure the base is right. Is this essentially off of about a $375 million spent for those resource plays in the first half of the year? And then can you talk about the trajectory for how you're thinking about the rest of the company? I think, if we look at least on a cash flow statement type perspective, you spent about $800 million overall for the company in the first half.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Certainly, in the first half of the year, Brian, there was a bit of a bias because we had a couple of long cycle projects that were running their course that are now, of course, both started up, which are the EG compression project as well as the non
componenttext: Yes. Certainly, in the first half of the year, Brian, there was a bit of a bias because we had a couple of long cycle projects that were running their course that are now, of course, both started up, which are the EG compression project as well as the non-operated Gunflint project. So there was probably a bit more bias to the conventional portfolio in the first half of the year. As we look forward to the second half of the year, that's going to largely be paced by the resource plays themselves. And that will really set the, I'll say, kind of that exit velocity that we achieved from a capital program standpoint as we move out of the year. We do anticipate, based on the activity we've described, including the additional rig in Oklahoma as well as some additional completion work in the Eagle Ford, that we will exit the fourth quarter with some pretty strong momentum going into 2017. To your point, I guess, on the rest of the portfolio, looking forward to 2017, you should expect us to continue to minimize the capital allocation to the conventional program, very similar to what we endeavored to do this cycle in 2016.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And now as a little bit of a follow-up to more of a strategic perspective, which is given your, I think, interest in the returns that you're seeing from the resource play portfolio, how strategically are you thinking about the assets elsewhere? Do
componenttext: Great. And now as a little bit of a follow-up to more of a strategic perspective, which is given your, I think, interest in the returns that you're seeing from the resource play portfolio, how strategically are you thinking about the assets elsewhere? Do you anticipate additional asset sales? Or as you perhaps just described, minimal levels of capital investment to try to use these assets for the free cash flow to offset potential outspending going on at the resource plays?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Brian, our conventional business is absolutely geared toward generating free cash flow that can then be redeployed. That's the model. That's what Mitch drives the team toward. And we'll look at some selective investments there. A great example is the
componenttext: Yes. Brian, our conventional business is absolutely geared toward generating free cash flow that can then be redeployed. That's the model. That's what Mitch drives the team toward. And we'll look at some selective investments there. A great example is the EG compression project, albeit a long-cycle project. It's very accretive. It's delivering very strong economics and performance in the portfolio. And it's simply going to add to the ability of Equatorial Guinea to add to our cash flows. I think a separate question, though, is more of the noncore asset question. We continue to scrutinize our portfolio and ensure that it is fully optimized. As I said in my opening remarks, we've achieved $1 billion year-to-date of noncore asset divestitures, but we believe there is more work to be done there. We don't think that will be to the scale of, say, a Wyoming, but we still believe there's some good solid portfolio work, particularly here in North America that we continue to drive. And again, it's all focused on that simplification and concentration of the portfolio toward the highest risk-adjusted returns.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.
componenttext: We have a question from Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A high-level question, if I could. I assume that you are basically planning the company at about a $50 outlook. How would things change if we would start assuming $40 or $60 in your mind? And I know you've been a little bit reluctant, probably quite right
componenttext: A high-level question, if I could. I assume that you are basically planning the company at about a $50 outlook. How would things change if we would start assuming $40 or $60 in your mind? And I know you've been a little bit reluctant, probably quite rightly, to commit to sort of levels of prices at which you'd start to think about faster growth and stuff, but I'm trying to pin you down on it.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, I appreciate your transparency. I'll maybe take those 2 bookends that you just talked about, the $40 and the $60. Obviously, I think at $40, similar to what we've experienced this year, we'd be looking to protect our balance sheet, to ensure that th
componenttext: Paul, I appreciate your transparency. I'll maybe take those 2 bookends that you just talked about, the $40 and the $60. Obviously, I think at $40, similar to what we've experienced this year, we'd be looking to protect our balance sheet, to ensure that though we continue to drive those leasehold and strategic objectives in the portfolio and then look with great discipline at some of those discretionary economic opportunities within the portfolio. We'd still be bearing down on cost. We'd still be bearing down on noncore asset sales. So those would be the behaviors and the objectives as we -- if we saw an environment moving into '17, that is more in the 4-handle range. I think conversely, if we see more constructive pricing moving into '17, at that $60 as we've talked about, a $10 move in pricing for us is a big impact on our operating cash flows. And we'd be looking to redeploy those pretty strongly back here into the U.S. resource plays to not only get back on sequential growth, but get back on that growth quite strongly if we saw that level of price support. We've protected the organization in such a way that we have the capacity to move to much higher activity levels. And if we saw that $60, we'd move toward that as quickly as we could.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's interesting. So on the dividend, is that still something that you aspire to return to be relatively a high-dividend payer? Or do you see yourselves shifting as to more of an unconventional growth story?
componenttext: That's interesting. So on the dividend, is that still something that you aspire to return to be relatively a high-dividend payer? Or do you see yourselves shifting as to more of an unconventional growth story?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think as you look at our portfolio, Paul, you look at our business model, we have made the shift. We made the shift in the dividend last year. Of course, it was helpful from an operating cash flow standpoint. But it was also much more consistent with wh
componenttext: I think as you look at our portfolio, Paul, you look at our business model, we have made the shift. We made the shift in the dividend last year. Of course, it was helpful from an operating cash flow standpoint. But it was also much more consistent with where we were headed in this very short-cycle investment resource play-intensive business that we're in. And we think from a competitive standpoint, given our opportunity outlook for growth and reinvestment, that's the right place for us to place our shareholder money.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And if I could just try one to Lance. Lance, we've seen something very interesting here which is the -- obviously there's been a significant improvement in cost performance, really across the industry at lower prices. But what's also interesting is
componenttext: Great. And if I could just try one to Lance. Lance, we've seen something very interesting here which is the -- obviously there's been a significant improvement in cost performance, really across the industry at lower prices. But what's also interesting is, I guess, the technical improvements are still being achieved even though activity is so much lower. If we did go back to higher prices, do you think technical improvements would accelerate? Or would they actually deteriorate because we'd be going into presumably into less high-quality acreage?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul. I think that's an insightful question. And I think what we would focus on at today's activity, which we are or at higher activity in the future would be in our Tier 1 inventory. As we've taken those technical advances and we've lifted up the re
componenttext: Yes, Paul. I think that's an insightful question. And I think what we would focus on at today's activity, which we are or at higher activity in the future would be in our Tier 1 inventory. As we've taken those technical advances and we've lifted up the returns of some of our portfolio, we have such a breadth of it now that we're going to focus within that Tier 1 first, and we'll take a portion of our activity to try to test some Tier 2 and lift it up to meet that thing. We need to stay disciplined in any price environment to make sure we're bringing our best opportunities forward, but also taking the view that we're going to bet on technology. We're going to bet on the innovation and the creativity of our people to keep bringing our portfolio up accretively over that time.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Can I just ask a follow-up? You said that you've retained -- is it that you haven't structured people? Or how have you retained your ability that both of you mentioned?
componenttext: Yes. Can I just ask a follow-up? You said that you've retained -- is it that you haven't structured people? Or how have you retained your ability that both of you mentioned?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. As we spun down our activity, we recognized that we have a cadre of early career talented people, and we don't necessarily have the direct activity to put them into. So we've taken them out to special projects across the company. They're out do
componenttext: Yes, sure. As we spun down our activity, we recognized that we have a cadre of early career talented people, and we don't necessarily have the direct activity to put them into. So we've taken them out to special projects across the company. They're out doing site supervision work on rigs and frac crews, production supervisors. So we are retaining them in very valuable functions, maturing their leadership and their technical skills and their business acumen. And then as we grow activity, we can recall them into other kind of petrotechnical focused roles, and they're going to be even better prepared to take those on. So that early activity ramp, those people are here for us.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.
componenttext: We have a question from Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I can ask you to kind of force-rank your Bakken and Eagle Ford opportunities. So you've been very clear, SCOOP and STACK will be the first call on capital. Which one goes second?
componenttext: Maybe I can ask you to kind of force-rank your Bakken and Eagle Ford opportunities. So you've been very clear, SCOOP and STACK will be the first call on capital. Which one goes second?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Lee. Just for clarity, at the top of our kind of batting order is going to be STACK oil. That clearly has the superior returns whether we look at a $40 environment or even a $50 environment. I think then, the league table gets pretty interest
componenttext: Yes, this is Lee. Just for clarity, at the top of our kind of batting order is going to be STACK oil. That clearly has the superior returns whether we look at a $40 environment or even a $50 environment. I think then, the league table gets pretty interesting because of all the good work the asset teams have been doing. We actually have more diversity within our Tier 1 kind of inventory that will compete for capital. But the ones that we would see really rising to the top are -- we're going to continue to see Eagle Ford, high GOR oil. We're going to continue to see Bakken, West Myrmidon specifically come into the mix. And then also the SCOOP condensate area is going to be a strong performer, which will also may be amplified in the event that we see stronger gas support as well. So that's really kind of the league table as we see it today.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just a point of clarification on the small drop in your full year production guidance. Is that purely the net effect of taking out Wyoming and putting in the new STACK acreage?

componenttext: That's an element of it, but there is also an element, of course, of just base decline and other elements of our business, specifically Eagle Ford, which we've already kind of talked about.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from Arun Jayaram from JPMorgan.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give us your outlook or expectations for how the U.S. resource play production could trend in the back half of the year. And secondly, is there going to be some more knock-on effect from the Eagle Ford completions -- high-dens
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give us your outlook or expectations for how the U.S. resource play production could trend in the back half of the year. And secondly, is there going to be some more knock-on effect from the Eagle Ford completions -- high-density completions you highlighted in 2015 in the update?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take maybe the question around the back half of the year on resource plays. And then maybe pitch it over to Lance to take on if there's any knock-on effect of the completion discussion. I think you've seen the releases that have come out over th
componenttext: Yes, I'll take maybe the question around the back half of the year on resource plays. And then maybe pitch it over to Lance to take on if there's any knock-on effect of the completion discussion. I think you've seen the releases that have come out over the last few days. There's clearly more optimism in the market, particularly, I think as you stretch into 2017. I think the sector in general was struggling with striking the correct balance between wanting to be prepared if they get a strong and sustainable price signal versus getting too far ahead of their headlights and losing, I think, the discipline that has been required during this downturn. So speaking from a Marathon Oil perspective, we do expect to build some momentum going into the fourth quarter, which we think would position us quite favorably in the event we do see more constructive pricing, and I would say that there's probably many others within our space that are looking to do the same. There, of course, will always be an element that may have to be more in a balance sheet repair mode as opposed to kind of being on their front foot and looking to drive toward incremental activity. But I don't see a dramatic adjustment just because of the declines have been pretty challenging this year and it's going to be hard, of course, to offset that completely with late-year activity. And maybe, Lance, if you want to chime in on the -- on just the question around the knock-on and the completion effects.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So specifically spoken on the Eagle Ford, I think as Lee referenced, our guidance takes into account our view on all that, so it's there in it. We have made some adjustments to the development plan. You'll see those reflected in the Eagle Ford secon
componenttext: Sure. So specifically spoken on the Eagle Ford, I think as Lee referenced, our guidance takes into account our view on all that, so it's there in it. We have made some adjustments to the development plan. You'll see those reflected in the Eagle Ford second half of the year, shift to focus on more 2/3 of that activity is in the high GOR oil areas, which are our highest value type curves at current pricing, and we have widened out that Austin Chalk from 40-acre to 80-acre spacing to mitigate those influences. And the 3- and 4-zone high density pads are really -- we're foregoing those for the rest of this year, and so that will help mitigate those concerns. I think otherwise, we've put into our guidance what we think the base decline from '15 is going to look like.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And my follow-up just, Lee, in terms of your comments earlier in the call about doubling maybe the rig count between now and year-end '17 in order to get to that, let's call it, flattish with some growth in the U.S. resource plays. Would you antici
componenttext: Great. And my follow-up just, Lee, in terms of your comments earlier in the call about doubling maybe the rig count between now and year-end '17 in order to get to that, let's call it, flattish with some growth in the U.S. resource plays. Would you anticipate kind of a stair-step kind of linear kind of move in activity over that time period?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. There will certainly be a ramp associated with that. I mean, that would not be a step-change, if you will. There would be a ramp across the year. So I was trying to just kind of project out kind of where we thought we might exit out of 2017 based on
componenttext: Yes. There will certainly be a ramp associated with that. I mean, that would not be a step-change, if you will. There would be a ramp across the year. So I was trying to just kind of project out kind of where we thought we might exit out of 2017 based on that kind of nominal $1.4 billion type investment, but there will absolutely be a ramp. And I think, too, you have to bear in mind that the rigs today are doing a lot more than the rigs did a year ago. And so we absolutely are taking advantage of that efficiency. In fact, in the Eagle Ford, we've actually gone down a rig in second quarter from 5 to 4 rigs, recognizing just the sheer efficiency of our drilling operations and the ability of our teams to continue to set a very strong pace on the drilling side of the business.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: We have no further questions at this time. I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Lee Tillman for closing remarks.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I would just like to thank everyone on the call for their questions and certainly their interest in Marathon Oil. It's been a busy and productive quarter for the company. I think the headlines speaks for -- speak for themselves. I won't go back
componenttext: Yes. Well, I would just like to thank everyone on the call for their questions and certainly their interest in Marathon Oil. It's been a busy and productive quarter for the company. I think the headlines speaks for -- speak for themselves. I won't go back through those. But we are preparing for that sustainable price environment where we can profitably grow our business within cash flows. In 2017, we can get our business back to sequential growth and live within our means with WTI in the low to mid-50s. And as I've stated during the call, we have the potential for even higher growth at higher pricing with an industry-leading leverage to oil. So thank you again for the time on the call. I appreciate it, and have a great day.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Marathon Oil Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Brandon, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this conference is being recorded, and I will now turn it over to Zach
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Marathon Oil Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Brandon, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this conference is being recorded, and I will now turn it over to Zach Dailey. You may begin, sir.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. Welcome to Marathon Oil's Third Quarter Earnings Call. Following the opening remarks from President and CEO, Lee Tillman, we'll open the call up for Q&A. Also joining us this morning are Mitch Little, E
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us today. Welcome to Marathon Oil's Third Quarter Earnings Call. Following the opening remarks from President and CEO, Lee Tillman, we'll open the call up for Q&A. Also joining us this morning are Mitch Little, Executive Vice President of Operations; and Pat Wagner, Interim CFO and Vice President of Corporate Development. 
As a reminder, today's call may contain forward-looking statements subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. Please read the disclosures in our earnings release and our SEC filings for a discussion of these items. Reconciliations of any non-GAAP financial measures we discuss can be found in the quarterly information package on our website. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Lee.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Zach, and let me add my good morning to everyone. I'll make a few brief comments, then open the call for questions. Our key takeaways today are: excellent well results and strong execution in the third quarter while achieving cash flow neutrality;
componenttext:
Thanks, Zach, and let me add my good morning to everyone. I'll make a few brief comments, then open the call for questions. Our key takeaways today are: excellent well results and strong execution in the third quarter while achieving cash flow neutrality; increasing rig activity in the fourth quarter within our original budget to prepare for sequential growth in the second half of 2017; and line of sight on 15% to 20% resource play CAGR at flat $55 WTI. Our total company third quarter production was above the top end of guidance and up sequentially. I'd like to recognize each of our asset teams for their contribution to this outcome. It's their hard work each and every day that delivers these outstanding results for our shareholders.
In the STACK and SCOOP, production was up over 50% from the prior quarter as we've benefited from new wells sales and a couple of months of contribution from our recent STACK acquisition. We continue to balance leasehold demands and acreage delineation in the STACK and brought some outstanding Meramec oil and the volatile oil wells to sales that are, on average, exceeding type curves on both our legacy and acquired acreage.
Our Bakken team delivered the best industry Three Forks well in the past 3 years on our East Myrmidon acreage, and extends the trend of basin leading [ph] performance set last quarter in West Myrmidon. The Eagle Ford asset team continued to drive down completed well costs. This quarter's wells averaged just under $4 million, further enhancing their outstanding returns. And our focus on the oil window at reduced stage spacing is improving the already strong economics in the play. 
Internationally, we had an excellent quarter, with Equatorial Guinea achieving their highest quarterly production since 2013, following the successful startup of the Alba B3 compression platform in July. That contributed to a 10% sequential increase in international E&P's quarterly production volumes. And OSM delivered record quarterly production in its lowest unit cost in the history of the mine.
On the portfolio side, we just sold some of our nonoperated waterflood and CO2 assets in West Texas and New Mexico for proceeds of $235 million before closing adjustments, which brings our total for noncore asset sales to over $1.5 billion since August of last year. You should expect portfolio management to continue as we drive to maximize capital allocation to our lowest-cost, highest-margin opportunities. 
With our ongoing noncore asset sales and recent STACK acquisition, our commitment to concentrating and simplifying our portfolio to the U.S. resource plays is clear. Couple that with the $5.3 billion of liquidity, including $2 billion of cash we have on our balance sheet, along with outstanding operational execution and a very competitive cost structure, we're poised to continue our execution momentum in 2017 and achieve profitable growth within cash flow at moderately higher prices. 
While our planning process is still underway, our preliminary 5-year view for resource play production supports a compound annual growth rate of 15% to 20% within cash flows at flat $55 WTI. 
With that, we can begin the Q&A.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And from Bank of America, we have Doug Leggate.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And from Bank of America, we have Doug Leggate.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: So Lee, back in September, you raised the type curve on your, I guess, your overpressured Meramec wells, but you're substantially outperforming, it seems, on those latest results you announced last night. I guess I could say the same thing about the normally pressured areas. So I guess can you lay out for us what inning you think you're in, in terms of revising your resource backlog in the basin? And maybe the same question on the drilling backlog also in terms of number of locations.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think you're right, Doug. We had given a bit of an update on our Meramec volatile oil curve in our last disclosure. We continue to be very encouraged by results in both the black oil window as well as the volatile oil window. And I would say,
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think you're right, Doug. We had given a bit of an update on our Meramec volatile oil curve in our last disclosure. We continue to be very encouraged by results in both the black oil window as well as the volatile oil window. And I would say, right now, it simply comes down to continuing to amass sufficient production history to have confidence with coming back out with the, of revision. [ph] But clearly, the bias, and I would say, across the STACK play, is with an upward vector. So I would just say, stay tuned on that count.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a quick clarification on that, Lee. The proppant loading is obviously substantially larger, but I don't think you gave any cost associated with that? Would you see that as a go-forward model, or are you still testing the limits at this point?
componenttext: Maybe just a quick clarification on that, Lee. The proppant loading is obviously substantially larger, but I don't think you gave any cost associated with that? Would you see that as a go-forward model, or are you still testing the limits at this point?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, this is Mitch Little. We didn't provide a cost update on the volatile oil wells, but we're in the neighborhood of between $8.5 million and $9 million on the wells we delivered in Q3, still fairly early in the learning curve. We would expect to be ab
componenttext: Doug, this is Mitch Little. We didn't provide a cost update on the volatile oil wells, but we're in the neighborhood of between $8.5 million and $9 million on the wells we delivered in Q3, still fairly early in the learning curve. We would expect to be able to continue to look for other efficiencies, certainly, as we go to pad drilling in some areas, we would capture efficiencies there. So we're never done focusing on trying to drive costs down and returns up.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: My  last one, if I can just squeeze it in real quick. You've given -- you've gone back to giving guidance on the unconventional growth, Lee, for the next 5 years. I'm just curious if you could put an activity level around that and maybe some range of what
componenttext: My  last one, if I can just squeeze it in real quick. You've given -- you've gone back to giving guidance on the unconventional growth, Lee, for the next 5 years. I'm just curious if you could put an activity level around that and maybe some range of what the bounce of the portfolio might look like in that timeline, and I'll leave it there.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, Doug, we did provide what I would kind of call some benchmark guidance link to a flat $55 deck. We're obviously still on our planning process and won't really release formal budget guidance until kind of February first quarter of next year. But w
componenttext: Yes. No, Doug, we did provide what I would kind of call some benchmark guidance link to a flat $55 deck. We're obviously still on our planning process and won't really release formal budget guidance until kind of February first quarter of next year. But we thought it was critical to provide some visibility of the growth potential within the resource play portfolio, and that's what really drove it. And again, although we didn't link it specifically to activity levels, I mean, you should expect that, that represents a ramp-up across all 3 of our plays, and it's somewhat indicative of the action that we're already taking in the fourth quarter of this year to begin the initial stages of that ramp-up to get to that sequential growth in the second half of 2017. So you already see us kind of taking rig count from 8 to 12. And as you extrapolate that over time, we should expect in that growth case that we would continue to build on that ramp-up.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Morgan Stanley, we have Evan Calio.
componenttext: From Morgan Stanley, we have Evan Calio.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Lee, maybe if I could just follow up on that, the growth guidance in your last response. I mean, I just -- could you help me put the scenario, the resource growth scenario in perspective? I mean, what is it? What does that assume for the nonresource portf
componenttext: Lee, maybe if I could just follow up on that, the growth guidance in your last response. I mean, I just -- could you help me put the scenario, the resource growth scenario in perspective? I mean, what is it? What does that assume for the nonresource portfolio under the same parameters within cash flow at $55? Is that a controlled decline? Or how much of that portfolio is funding the growth within cash flow of the resource portfolio?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, there's no doubt, Evan, that the conventional component of our portfolio, particularly in the areas like Equatorial Guinea and even OSM and the right [ph] commodity environment, those are providing significant free cash flow that allow us to re
componenttext: Yes. Well, there's no doubt, Evan, that the conventional component of our portfolio, particularly in the areas like Equatorial Guinea and even OSM and the right [ph] commodity environment, those are providing significant free cash flow that allow us to redeploy that into the unconventional business. But again, given that we're going to give much more granular guidance in the first quarter, what I would say, though, about 2017 and perhaps, the way to think about it, Evan, is that we would anticipate on the order of 90% of our capital program being allocated to the resource plays as we look toward 2017. So you should expect that we'll be minimizing, to the extent possible, any plow [ph] back into the conventional assets.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my second question, and I'll try and keep it outside of 2017 to front run the capital guidance, but can you talk about the capital allocation among the resource plays? I mean, I understand STACK has the first call on capital, but you've added 2 rigs h
componenttext: And my second question, and I'll try and keep it outside of 2017 to front run the capital guidance, but can you talk about the capital allocation among the resource plays? I mean, I understand STACK has the first call on capital, but you've added 2 rigs here into the Eagle Ford. I presume your strategy is to hold Eagle Ford flat, and I guess, the same is, the strategy as it relates to the Bakken, at least to East Myrmidon or any of the 200 [ph] locations. When will you further accelerate there relative to your other plays? If you could talk about that in the longer term, I'd appreciate it.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Certainly, capital allocation for us, it starts, first and foremost, with the objective of living within our cash flows, living within our means, that's the overarching objective. But within that objective, and certainly, this applies to '17 and beyo
componenttext: Yes. Certainly, capital allocation for us, it starts, first and foremost, with the objective of living within our cash flows, living within our means, that's the overarching objective. But within that objective, and certainly, this applies to '17 and beyond, our first call on capital, as you rightly described, Evan, is going to be in Oklahoma and specifically achieving our strategic objective in the STACK, which are, first and foremost, leasehold, after that, really, delineation, and then really, thirdly, is preparation for full fuel development in the STACK. As we meet those objectives over the next year or 2, from that point on, to the extent that we have free cash flow or cash flow to deploy, it's going to be done on the basis of the best risk adjusted return. And what we see today, of course, is that Eagle Ford is still very strongly competing. It  has some of the best economic returns in our portfolio. But with the recent results in the Bakken that we highlighted, including the East Myrmidon results this quarter, Bakken is now competing very strongly for capital allocation as well. So it's going to be a balance, it's going to be modulated based on our ability to deliver that within our means. But that's the way you should think about it.  First and foremost, our strategic objectives in Oklahoma, and then, we're going to allocate based on the best risk-adjusted return.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Yes, we would again expect -- many of the rigs that we're adding, which is the 4 rigs that we talked about, going from the 8 to the 12, actually the fifth rig has already been added into Oklahoma, and I believe will spud its first well tomorrow. So we've already added that rig. The incremental rigs in the Eagle Ford and the Bakken will be added a little bit towards the back end of the quarter, but again, it's preparing us for momentum into 2017. So we'll exit right at that 12 rig count number going into '17, and then we'll evaluate that as we look at our price view at the time we release our budget. We'll I just that as necessary to modulate the ramp again to deliver within cash flows.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Roger. This is Mitch again. And I guess what I would say or what I would share with you, it's a mixture of well types out there still. And we are in the delineation phase. But on average, across the STACK, our drilling efficiency is about a 40%
componenttext: Yes. Sure, Roger. This is Mitch again. And I guess what I would say or what I would share with you, it's a mixture of well types out there still. And we are in the delineation phase. But on average, across the STACK, our drilling efficiency is about a 40% increase in feed per day, if you look to us compared to a year ago and mixing the wells, kind of 10% to 20% lower completed well costs, and that's with higher intensity completions in most cases. So we're still on the efficiency curve, if you will. We haven't moved to full field development. The advantages of pad drilling, the advantages of continuity with drilling crudes and applying the latest technology. So we would still expect to be able to continue to see some learnings there, and our teams are certainly driving on that with a real focus on flat times as well as drilling rigs.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And kind of a follow-up to some of the earlier questions about -- the guidance for second half '17, the growth of $55 of oil environment, what should we think of, Lee, as the, I don't know, it's pretty easy to understand, I guess, the positive, yes,
componenttext: Okay. And kind of a follow-up to some of the earlier questions about -- the guidance for second half '17, the growth of $55 of oil environment, what should we think of, Lee, as the, I don't know, it's pretty easy to understand, I guess, the positive, yes, crude above [ph] $55, easy to spend more money. But is it a sub-$50 world we need to be concerned about in the first half of next year, as may be pushing these plans into '18 from '17? Or I don't know, I guess we're all just trying to understand kind of what are the guidelines how we should think about setting things up for '17 and beyond.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. Well certainly, Roger, I'm to provide a bit more granularity on that in the first quarter. But just looking at where we stand today, obviously, we are shaping our price forecast across 2017 to obviously reflect a bit lower price in the beginning
componenttext: Yes, yes. Well certainly, Roger, I'm to provide a bit more granularity on that in the first quarter. But just looking at where we stand today, obviously, we are shaping our price forecast across 2017 to obviously reflect a bit lower price in the beginning of the year and somewhat of strengthening to where the back end of the year and what we've talked about is we can maintain certainly that sequential growth case into the low 50s. And that's kind of x any hedging success that we have well. And so as you -- if were to say languished in the environment that we're in today, we would just have to assess that as we move into 2017, and we would adjust accordingly. If we see that being persistent, then you're right, then we may choose to push that ramp-up a bit in time. But today, we want to make sure that we're on a trajectory that's going to deliver that ramp, recognizing that we have full optionality and flexibility to adjust early next year as price dictates. But again, our overarching objective is going to free cash flow neutrality.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: From Goldman Sachs, we have Brian Singer online.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You touched on the oil sands operating costs. Can you talk about the operating cost trends elsewhere in the portfolio? It seems like it came down for the international business outside of oil sand, and parts of the domestic continue to come down as well.
componenttext: You touched on the oil sands operating costs. Can you talk about the operating cost trends elsewhere in the portfolio? It seems like it came down for the international business outside of oil sand, and parts of the domestic continue to come down as well. Can you just talk to the sustainability of some of these costs, cost productions that we've seen and how that might change in a $55 world that you're talking about potentially for 2017?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. I'll touch on it, and then others can add to this. But as you point out, we shared an update on our operating costs. And I think on an absolute basis, we're down 37% year-over-year in North America, and 31% overall. As you'd expect and as is
componenttext: Sure, Brian. I'll touch on it, and then others can add to this. But as you point out, we shared an update on our operating costs. And I think on an absolute basis, we're down 37% year-over-year in North America, and 31% overall. As you'd expect and as is common, that's a combination of some structural deficiencies that are sustainable and some commercial savings across the board. I think that's an impressive way to change and we've seen it across the industry. Our work is never done in that area. We'll continue to push for further efficiencies, probably not fair to think about it at the same rate of change going into the next year, but we're going to continue to do that. And I think we've traditionally talked on the order of 50% commercial, 50% structural and efficiency gains across the total spend. It's probably a little bit higher weighted to the structural and the operating side, with things like the water handling system that we've put in the Bakken, moving our water on pipe there. We're up to about 70% of our produced water on pipe now up there, and certainly some staff rationalizations, getting more efficient using technology across the operations, so a little bit heavy weighted on the structural, I would say.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would just add, in the case, just building on our discussion around OSM, assets like that, for instance, have a very large energy component to them. We'll have some flex, depending upon where prices go as well. So there is a plus and a minus th
componenttext: Yes. And I would just add, in the case, just building on our discussion around OSM, assets like that, for instance, have a very large energy component to them. We'll have some flex, depending upon where prices go as well. So there is a plus and a minus there from an asset like OSM's perspective, where yes, you may get a price response which is going to get you, of course, from a realization standpoint, but from a cost standpoint because a large component of your production costs are around energy, you're going to feel a little bit of the burn on the energy cost as well.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just to follow-up on Bakken with some of the well productivity and efficiency that you're seeing from your Slide 15, I think it is, it looks, it certainly looks like some of these wells are trending above that type curve. Is your focus, a
componenttext: Got it. And then just to follow-up on Bakken with some of the well productivity and efficiency that you're seeing from your Slide 15, I think it is, it looks, it certainly looks like some of these wells are trending above that type curve. Is your focus, as you start to increase activity in the Bakken, just more on the well performance and the well side? Or did you also see some -- did you also see the potential for your inventory in the Bakken to improve as a result of the results that you're seeing?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I certainly think that from an inventory standpoint, we have basically driven more inventory into what we would call a kind of Tier 1 and competing for capital allocation by these changes in well productivity. I mean kudos to the Bakken team. I thin
componenttext: Well, I certainly think that from an inventory standpoint, we have basically driven more inventory into what we would call a kind of Tier 1 and competing for capital allocation by these changes in well productivity. I mean kudos to the Bakken team. I think they have used this down cycle to really put themselves in a much more competitive stance in terms of capital allocation, but also just looking at their lease operating expense. Mitch mentioned the water handling system that was installed. And when we look at other operators, we feel very confident that we are one of the low-cost operators and that's just contributing to our margin in the Bakken. They had a limited amount of capital. We haven't been drilling in the Bakken since really early in 2016, but we've completed the Clark's [ph] Creek PUD, and then of course, the Maggie Pad, which have demonstrated these very song results and when we look these just from a sheer return basis, they're competing head-to-head with some of the best in our portfolio. And that team has again, positioned themselves now to participate fully in the capital allocation discussion and it's one of the key drivers of why we're putting our rig back to work there at the end of this year.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I'll just add a little bit to that, Brian. Certainly, some of the learnings in the Myrmidon area that we've employed in the last 2 quarters are going to be transferable and will be trialed in other areas as well. The team is very focused, as we a
componenttext: Yes. And I'll just add a little bit to that, Brian. Certainly, some of the learnings in the Myrmidon area that we've employed in the last 2 quarters are going to be transferable and will be trialed in other areas as well. The team is very focused, as we are across all basins, in upgrading all of our inventory. So watch this space. It's not 1 size fits all, certainly but we do think there are transferable learnings.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two different questions for you. First on the 15% to 20% long-term growth target for the resource plays. What rig count does that assume implicitly? And how it might -- that be allocated between the Bakken, Eagle Ford and Oklahoma?
componenttext: Two different questions for you. First on the 15% to 20% long-term growth target for the resource plays. What rig count does that assume implicitly? And how it might -- that be allocated between the Bakken, Eagle Ford and Oklahoma?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, we haven't provided specific rig count numbers with that CAGR. Our intent though, would certainly be to provide more definition specifically around 2017 and in the first quarter, when we do our capital budget release. But obviously, the growth
componenttext: Yes, well, we haven't provided specific rig count numbers with that CAGR. Our intent though, would certainly be to provide more definition specifically around 2017 and in the first quarter, when we do our capital budget release. But obviously, the growth engine for us going forward is going to be Oklahoma. So there is going to be a significant ramp-up in both capital allocation as well as rig activity in Oklahoma. The other assets, Bakken and Eagle Ford, just due to their potential to generate very high returns, we'll continue to compete. And they give us optionality to modulate between growth and cash flow generation in those particular assets. And we'll take full advantage of that.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Secondly, very different geography. You guys are one of the few international operators in Libya. We have heard sort of just in the headlines that Libyan volumes have doubled since roughly August. Are you seeing any of that substance on your own acr
componenttext: Okay. Secondly, very different geography. You guys are one of the few international operators in Libya. We have heard sort of just in the headlines that Libyan volumes have doubled since roughly August. Are you seeing any of that substance on your own acreage? Or is that mostly other people stuff?

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Pavel. This is Mitch. You're aware, I think, that our position is within the Waha concessions. And while we're encouraged with the lifting of force majeure and the restart of production there, production through the month of October has kind of rang
componenttext: Sure, Pavel. This is Mitch. You're aware, I think, that our position is within the Waha concessions. And while we're encouraged with the lifting of force majeure and the restart of production there, production through the month of October has kind of range between 30,000 and 50,000 gross barrels a day. Liftings have commenced from the [indiscernible] terminal, but they have not yet commenced from SEDAR. Through the various actions that have taken place in Libya over the last couple of years, there is certainly damage at the terminal that needs to be repaired and also out in the fields, particularly in some of the pipeline infrastructure. So we haven't seen a rapid increase above those levels. Repairs are going to be required. We -- they're working diligently on the terminal. We would expect a lifting to occur from SEDAR [ph] in the not too distant future, but kind of been in the 30,000 to 50,000-barrel a day through month of October, through most of the month.

And then, really, in the Bakken and the Eagle Ford, it becomes a matter of choices around how rapidly do we want to develop those more mature areas. We can again, modulate between the level of ramp-up and the level of free cash flow generation in both of those assets. And so we've made some assumptions within that kind of, if you will, 17 to 21 view because we

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Arun. This is Mitch. I think what we would say for starters is certainly encouraged with the aggregate performance, being about 30% over the type curve. We're stronger in delineation mode and protecting our valuable leasehold, so not surprisingly, w
componenttext: Sure, Arun. This is Mitch. I think what we would say for starters is certainly encouraged with the aggregate performance, being about 30% over the type curve. We're stronger in delineation mode and protecting our valuable leasehold, so not surprisingly, we're going to see a little bit of variability in results but the wells are delivering expected oil rates. They're delivering oil cuts within the range that we expected based on the wells drilled prior to the acquisition. We've seen a little bit of variability in the GOR, but certainly, too early to draw any conclusions from the limited data set that we have there and encouraged by the early results relative to the type curve.

certainly continued concentration, simplification of the portfolio and a peer leading leverage to oil. We are squarely focused on those aspects of our business that we control. Our execution and our costs, and we're going to continue to drive to lower the breakeven of our enterprise which will serve us well regardless of the poor commodity price environment.

headline: Marathon Oil Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
